<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Israel_(disambiguation)" title="Israel (disambiguation)">Israel (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/> $54,690<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd_19-5"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-19">[fn 4]</a></sup> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">15th</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(2018)</span></th><td class="infobox-data">34.8<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd_19-6"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-19">[fn 4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[18]</a></sup><br/><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:orange">medium</span></span></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">HDI</a> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886047488" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="nobold">(2019)</span></th><td class="infobox-data"><img alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/> 0.919<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd_19-7"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-19">[fn 4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-23">[19]</a></sup><br/><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:darkgreen">very high</span></span> · <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">19th</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Israeli_new_shekel" title="Israeli new shekel">New shekel</a> (<span title="Hebrew-language text"><span lang="he">₪</span></span>) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">ILS</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+2:00</span> (<a href="/wiki/Israel_Standard_Time" title="Israel Standard Time">IST</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">• Summer (<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>)</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+3:00</span> (<a href="/wiki/Israel_Summer_Time" title="Israel Summer Time">IDT</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><span title="Hebrew-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="he">יי-חח-שששש</span></span> (<a href="/wiki/Anno_Mundi" title="Anno Mundi">AM</a>)</li><li>dd-mm-yyyy (<a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>)</li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Israel" title="Telephone numbers in Israel">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data">+972</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:IL" title="ISO 3166-2:IL">IL</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.il" title=".il">.il</a></td></tr><tr><td class="infobox-full-data" colspan="2"><div class="ib-country-fn"><ol class="ib-country-fn-alpha">
<li value="1"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1041539562">.mw-parser-output .citation{word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}</style><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_area"><b><a href="#ref_area">^</a></b></span>  20,770 km<sup>2</sup> is Israel within the <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a>. 22,072 km<sup>2</sup> includes the annexed <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a> (c. 1,200 km<sup>2</sup> (460 sq mi)) and <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> (c. 64 km<sup>2</sup> (25 sq mi)).</li>
</ol></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1092331828">@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .contains-special-characters{width:22em}}</style><div class="side-box metadata side-box-right contains-special-characters noprint selfref">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_alphabet" title="Hebrew alphabet">Hebrew</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic_alphabet" title="Arabic alphabet">Arabic</a> text.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:Multilingual_support" title="Help:Multilingual support">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a>.</div></div>
</div>
<p><b>Israel</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/./: syllable break">.</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span>-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span></span>-/</a></span></span>; <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">יִשְׂרָאֵל</span>, <span title="Hebrew-language romanization"><i lang="he-Latn">Yīsrāʾēl</i></span>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">إِسْرَائِيل</span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">ʾIsrāʾīl</i></span>), officially the <b>State of Israel</b> (<span title="Hebrew-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="he">מְדִינַת יִשְׂרָאֵל</span></span>, <span title="Hebrew-language romanization"><i lang="he-Latn">Medīnat Yīsrāʾēl</i></span>; <span title="Arabic-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="ar">دَوْلَة إِسْرَائِيل</span></span>, <span title="Arabic-language romanization"><i lang="ar-Latn">Dawlat ʾIsrāʾīl</i></span>), is a country in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>. It is situated on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Mediterranean" title="Eastern Mediterranean">southeastern shore</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> and the northern shore of the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Israel" title="Borders of Israel">shares borders</a> with <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> to the east, and <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> to the southwest; it is also bordered by the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_territories" title="Palestinian territories">Palestinian territories</a> of the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a> to the east and west, respectively. <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Israel" title="Economy of Israel">economic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Israel" title="Science and technology in Israel">technological center</a> of the country, while its seat of government is in its proclaimed capital of <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, although <a href="/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem" title="Status of Jerusalem">Israeli sovereignty over East Jerusalem is unrecognized internationally</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[fn 5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Inhabited since the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Bronze_Age" title="Middle Bronze Age">Middle Bronze Age</a> by <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaanite</a> tribes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Golden_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Golden-27">[22]</a></sup> the land held by present-day Israel was once the setting for much of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biblical_history" title="Biblical history">Biblical history</a>, beginning with the 9th-century <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> <a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of ancient Israel and Judah">kingdoms of Israel and Judah</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finkelstein_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-Finkelstein-28">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pitcher_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pitcher-29">[24]</a></sup> which fell, respectively, to the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire" title="Neo-Assyrian Empire">Neo-Assyrian Empire</a> (c. 720 BCE) and <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Neo-Babylonian Empire</a> (586 BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Broshi_2001_174_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-Broshi_2001_174-30">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[26]</a></sup> Later rulers included the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hasmonean_dynasty" title="Hasmonean dynasty">Hasmonean dynasty</a>, and, from 63 BCE, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> and later <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BangScheidel2013_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-BangScheidel2013-32">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Malamat1976_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-Malamat1976-33">[28]</a></sup> From the 5th century CE, it was part of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, up until the 7th century <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun Caliphate</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_the_Levant" title="Muslim conquest of the Levant">conquest of the Levant</a>. With the <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">First Crusade</a> of 1096–1099, <a href="/wiki/Crusader_states" title="Crusader states">Crusader states</a> were established. Muslim rule was then restored in 1291 by the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate" title="Mamluk Sultanate">Mamluk Sultanate</a>, which later <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Mamluk_War_(1516%E2%80%931517)" title="Ottoman–Mamluk War (1516–1517)">ceded the territory</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>.
</p><p>During the 19th century, the <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionist</a> movement began promoting the creation of a <a href="/wiki/Homeland_for_the_Jewish_people" title="Homeland for the Jewish people">Jewish homeland</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Syria" title="Ottoman Syria">Ottoman Syria</a>. Following <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, Britain was granted control of the region by <a href="/wiki/Mandate_for_Palestine" title="Mandate for Palestine">League of Nations mandate</a>, in what became known as <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Mandatory Palestine</a>. After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the newly formed <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> adopted the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">Partition Plan for Palestine</a> in 1947, recommending the creation of independent Arab and Jewish states, and an <a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Jerusalem)" title="Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)">internationalized Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181(II)_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-181(II)-34">[29]</a></sup> Following a <a href="/wiki/1947%E2%80%931948_civil_war_in_Mandatory_Palestine" title="1947–1948 civil war in Mandatory Palestine">civil war within Mandatory Palestine</a> between <a href="/wiki/Yishuv" title="Yishuv">Yishuv</a> and Palestinian Arab forces, Israel <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">declared independence</a> at the termination of the <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">British Mandate</a>. A day later, several surrounding Arab countries intervened, leading to the  <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>, which concluded with the <a href="/wiki/1949_Armistice_Agreements" title="1949 Armistice Agreements">1949 Armistice Agreements</a> that saw Israel in control of most of the former mandate territory, while the <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_annexation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian annexation of the West Bank">West Bank</a> and <a href="/wiki/All-Palestine_Protectorate" title="All-Palestine Protectorate">Gaza</a> were held by Jordan and Egypt respectively. Over 700,000 <a href="/wiki/Palestinians" title="Palestinians">Palestinian Arabs</a>, about half of the pre-war Arab population, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1948_Palestinian_exodus" title="1948 Palestinian exodus">were expelled from or fled</a> the territory Israel would come to control. During and immediately after the war, around <a href="/wiki/Jewish_exodus_from_the_Muslim_world" title="Jewish exodus from the Muslim world">260,000 Jews emigrated or fled</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> to Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischbach200826–27_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischbach200826–27-35">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[fn 6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel has since fought <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab–Israeli conflict">wars with several Arab countries</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RoutledgeAtlas_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-RoutledgeAtlas-37">[31]</a></sup> and since the 1967 <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a> has occupied the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a> and the Palestinian territories of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Israeli occupation of the West Bank">West Bank, including East Jerusalem</a>,  and the Gaza Strip, though whether Gaza remains occupied following the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_disengagement_from_Gaza" title="Israeli disengagement from Gaza">Israeli disengagement</a> is disputed. Israel has <a href="/wiki/Israeli_annexation_of_East_Jerusalem" title="Israeli annexation of East Jerusalem">effectively annexed</a> <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights_Law" title="Golan Heights Law">the Golan Heights</a>, though these actions have been rejected as illegal by the international community, and established <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_settlements" title="Israeli settlements">settlements</a> within the occupied territories, which are also considered <a href="/wiki/International_law_and_Israeli_settlements" title="International law and Israeli settlements">illegal under international law</a>. While Israel has signed peace treaties with <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_peace_treaty" title="Egypt–Israel peace treaty">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_peace_treaty" title="Israel–Jordan peace treaty">Jordan</a>, and has <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Accords" title="Abraham Accords">normalized relations</a> with a number of other Arab countries, it remains <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israel-Syria_relations" title="Israel-Syria relations">formally at war</a> with <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> and with <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_peace_process" title="Israeli–Palestinian peace process">efforts</a> to resolve the <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict" title="Israeli–Palestinian conflict">Israeli–Palestinian conflict</a> have thus far stalled.
</p><p>In its <a href="/wiki/Basic_Laws_of_Israel" title="Basic Laws of Israel">Basic Laws</a>, Israel defines itself as a <a href="/wiki/Jewish_and_democratic_state" title="Jewish and democratic state">Jewish and democratic state</a>, and as the <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law:_Israel_as_the_Nation-State_of_the_Jewish_People" title="Basic Law: Israel as the Nation-State of the Jewish People">nation-state of the Jewish people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freedomhouse2008_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse2008-38">[32]</a></sup> The country has a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a>, <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel" title="Prime Minister of Israel">prime minister</a> serves as head of <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel" title="Cabinet of Israel">government</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral legislature</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-39">[33]</a></sup> Israel is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> and an <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> member,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-40">[34]</a></sup> with a <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Israel" title="Demographics of Israel">population of over 9 million people</a> as of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[35]</a></sup> It has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">29th-largest economy by nominal GDP</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFWEOIL_21-2"><a href="#cite_note-IMFWEOIL-21">[17]</a></sup> and ranks nineteenth in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-23">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-12"><a href="#Tectonics_and_seismicity"><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span> <span class="toctext">Tectonics and seismicity</span></a></li>

</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-14"><a href="#Demographics"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Demographics</span></a>
<ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology"><span class="anchor" id="Etymology"></span> Etymology</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="491" decoding="async" height="266" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg/170px-Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg/255px-Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg/340px-Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Merenptah_Israel_Stele_Cairo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Merneptah_Stele" title="Merneptah Stele">Merneptah Stele</a> (13th century BCE). The majority of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biblical_Archeology" title="Biblical Archeology">biblical archeologists</a> translate a set of hieroglyphs as "Israel," the first instance of the name in the record.</div></div></div>
<p>Under the <a href="/wiki/Mandate_for_Palestine" title="Mandate for Palestine">British Mandate</a> (1920–1948), the whole region was known as 'Palestine' (<a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">פלשתינה [א״י]</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a> </small>'Palestine [Eretz Israel]').<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[36]</a></sup> Upon <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">independence</a> in 1948, the country formally adopted the name 'State of Israel' (<a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">מְדִינַת יִשְׂרָאֵל</span>, <span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:He-Medinat_Israel2.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2b/He-Medinat_Israel2.ogg" title="He-Medinat Israel2.ogg"><span title="Hebrew-language romanization"><i lang="he-Latn"><i>Medīnat Yisrā'el</i></i></span></a></span></span> <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="he-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Hebrew" title="Help:IPA/Hebrew">[mediˈnat jisʁaˈʔel]</a></span>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">دَوْلَة إِسْرَائِيل</span>, <span title="American Library Association – Library of Congress transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn"><i>Dawlat Isrāʼīl</i></i></span>, <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="ar-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Arabic">[dawlat ʔisraːˈʔiːl]</a></span>) after other <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence#Name" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">proposed historical and religious names</a> including '<a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a>' (<i>Eretz Israel</i>), Ever (from ancestor <a href="/wiki/Eber" title="Eber">Eber</a>), <a href="/wiki/Zion" title="Zion">Zion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judea" title="Judea">Judea</a>, were considered but rejected,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[37]</a></sup> while the name 'Israel' was suggested by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ben-Gurion" title="Ben-Gurion">Ben-Gurion</a> and passed by a vote of 6–3.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[38]</a></sup> In the early weeks of independence, the government chose the term "<a href="/wiki/Israelis" title="Israelis">Israeli</a>" to denote a citizen of Israel, with the formal announcement made by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_Affairs_Minister_of_Israel" title="Foreign Affairs Minister of Israel">Minister of Foreign Affairs</a> <a href="/wiki/Moshe_Sharett" title="Moshe Sharett">Moshe Sharett</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>The names <a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Children_of_Israel" title="Children of Israel">Children of Israel</a> have historically been used to refer to the biblical <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy)" title="Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)">Kingdom of Israel</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_people" title="Jewish people">entire Jewish people</a> respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-levine_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-levine-46">[40]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Israel_(name)" title="Israel (name)">name 'Israel'</a> (Hebrew: <i>Yisraʾel</i>, <i>Isrāʾīl</i>; <a href="/wiki/Septuagint" title="Septuagint">Septuagint</a> <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">Ἰσραήλ</span>, <i>Israēl</i>, 'El (God) persists/rules', though after <a class="external text" href="https://bible.oremus.org/?passage=Hosea%2012:4&amp;version=nrsv" rel="nofollow">Hosea 12:4</a> often interpreted as 'struggle with God')<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[44]</a></sup> in these phrases refers to the patriarch <a href="/wiki/Jacob" title="Jacob">Jacob</a> who, according to the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_Bible" title="Hebrew Bible">Hebrew Bible</a>, was given the name after he successfully wrestled with the angel of the Lord.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[45]</a></sup> Jacob's twelve sons became the ancestors of the <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelites</a>, also known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Twelve_Tribes_of_Israel" title="Twelve Tribes of Israel">Twelve Tribes of Israel</a></i> or <i>Children of Israel</i>. Jacob and his sons had lived in <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaan</a> but were forced by famine to go into <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a> for four generations, lasting 430 years,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[46]</a></sup> until <a href="/wiki/Moses" title="Moses">Moses</a>, a great-great-grandson of Jacob,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[47]</a></sup> led the Israelites back into <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaan</a> during the "<a href="/wiki/The_Exodus" title="The Exodus">Exodus</a>". The earliest known archaeological artifact to mention the word "Israel" as a collective is the <a href="/wiki/Merneptah_Stele" title="Merneptah Stele">Merneptah Stele</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a> (dated to the late 13th century BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Israel" title="History of Israel">History of Israel</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Israeli_history" title="Timeline of Israeli history">Timeline of Israeli history</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_the_Levant" title="Prehistory of the Levant">Prehistory of the Levant</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Southern_Levant" title="Southern Levant">Southern Levant</a> experienced human residence, agricultural communities, and civilization among the first in the globe. The oldest evidence of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_humans" title="Early humans">early humans</a> in the territory of modern Israel, dating to 1.5 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Million_years_ago" title="Million years ago">million years ago</a>, was found in <a href="/wiki/Ubeidiya_prehistoric_site" title="Ubeidiya prehistoric site">Ubeidiya</a> near the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Galilee" title="Sea of Galilee">Sea of Galilee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[49]</a></sup> Other notable <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> sites include the caves <a href="/wiki/Tabun_Cave" title="Tabun Cave">Tabun</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qesem_Cave" title="Qesem Cave">Qesem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manot_Cave" title="Manot Cave">Manot</a>. The oldest fossils of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_human" title="Anatomically modern human">anatomically modern humans</a> found <a href="/wiki/Recent_African_origin_of_modern_humans" title="Recent African origin of modern humans">outside Africa</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Skhul_and_Qafzeh_hominins" title="Skhul and Qafzeh hominins">Skhul and Qafzeh hominins</a>, who lived in the area that is now northern Israel 120,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[50]</a></sup> Around 10th millennium BCE, the <a href="/wiki/Natufian_culture" title="Natufian culture">Natufian culture</a> existed in the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of ancient Israel and Judah">History of ancient Israel and Judah</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)" title="Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)">Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Kingdom of Judah</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG/220px-City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG/330px-City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG/440px-City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:City_of_David_-_King_David%27s_Palace_IMG_5815.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Large_Stone_Structure" title="Large Stone Structure">Large Stone Structure</a>, an archaeological site in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Canaan" title="Canaan">Canaanites</a> are archaeologically attested in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_bronze_age" title="Middle bronze age">Middle Bronze Age</a> (2100–1550 BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Golden_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-Golden-27">[22]</a></sup> During the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late_Bronze_Age" title="Late Bronze Age">Late Bronze Age</a> (1550–1200 BCE), large parts of Canaan formed <a href="/wiki/Vassal_state" title="Vassal state">vassal states</a> paying tribute to the <a href="/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Egypt" title="New Kingdom of Egypt">New Kingdom of Egypt</a>, whose administrative headquarters lay in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaza_city" title="Gaza city">Gaza</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[52]</a></sup> As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Late_Bronze_Age_collapse" title="Late Bronze Age collapse">Late Bronze Age collapse</a>, Canaan fell into chaos, and Egyptian control over the region collapsed completely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[54]</a></sup> There is evidence that urban centers such as <a href="/wiki/Tel_Hazor" title="Tel Hazor">Hazor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beit_She%27an" title="Beit She'an">Beit She'an</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tel_Megiddo" title="Tel Megiddo">Megiddo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ekron" title="Ekron">Ekron</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ashdod" title="Ashdod">Ashdod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ashkelon" title="Ashkelon">Ashkelon</a> were damaged or destroyed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>A people named Israel appear for the first time in the <a href="/wiki/Merneptah_Stele" title="Merneptah Stele">Merneptah Stele</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egyptian</a> inscription which dates to about 1200 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NollMerneptah_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-NollMerneptah-62">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ThompsonMerneptah_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-ThompsonMerneptah-63">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[59]</a></sup> Ancestors of the Israelites are thought to have included <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Semitic-speaking_peoples" title="Ancient Semitic-speaking peoples">ancient Semitic-speaking peoples</a> native to this area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Miller1986_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-Miller1986-66">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 78–79">: 78–79 </span></sup> According to the modern archaeological account, the Israelites and their culture branched out of the Canaanite peoples and their cultures through the development of a distinct <a href="/wiki/Monolatry" title="Monolatry">monolatristic</a>—and later <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheistic</a>—religion centered on <a href="/wiki/Yahweh" title="Yahweh">Yahweh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[63]</a></sup> They spoke an archaic form of the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew language</a>, known as <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew" title="Biblical Hebrew">Biblical Hebrew</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[64]</a></sup> The archaeological evidence indicates a society of village-like centers, but with more limited resources and a small population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[65]</a></sup> Villages had populations of up to 300 or 400,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199970_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199970-72">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller201298_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller201298-73">[67]</a></sup> which lived by farming and herding, and were largely self-sufficient;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199972_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcNutt199972-74">[68]</a></sup> economic interchange was prevalent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller201299_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller201299-75">[69]</a></sup> Writing was known and available for recording, even in small sites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller2012105_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller2012105-76">[70]</a></sup> Around the same time, the <a href="/wiki/Philistines" title="Philistines">Philistines</a> settled on the southern <a href="/wiki/Israeli_coastal_plain" title="Israeli coastal plain">coastal plain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKillebrew2005230_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKillebrew2005230-77">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShahin20056_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShahin20056-78">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern <a href="/wiki/Archaeology" title="Archaeology">archaeology</a> has largely discarded <a href="/wiki/Historicity_of_the_Bible" title="Historicity of the Bible">the historicity</a> of the narrative in the <a href="/wiki/Torah" title="Torah">Torah</a> concerning the <a href="/wiki/Patriarchs_(Bible)" title="Patriarchs (Bible)">patriarchs</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Exodus" title="The Exodus">The Exodus</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Israelite_campaigns" title="Early Israelite campaigns">the conquest of Canaan</a> described in the <a href="/wiki/Book_of_Joshua" title="Book of Joshua">Book of Joshua</a>, and instead views the narrative as constituting the <a href="/wiki/Israelites" title="Israelites">Israelites</a>' <a href="/wiki/National_myth" title="National myth">national myth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[73]</a></sup>  However, some elements of these traditions do appear to have historical roots.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFaust2015p.476:_"While_there_is_a_consensus_among_scholars_that_the_Exodus_did_not_take_place_in_the_manner_described_in_the_Bible,_surprisingly_most_scholars_agree_that_the_narrative_has_a_historical_core,_and_that_some_of_the_highland_settlers_came,_one_way_or_another,_from_Egypt.."_80-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFaust2015p.476:_"While_there_is_a_consensus_among_scholars_that_the_Exodus_did_not_take_place_in_the_manner_described_in_the_Bible,_surprisingly_most_scholars_agree_that_the_narrative_has_a_historical_core,_and_that_some_of_the_highland_settlers_came,_one_way_or_another,_from_Egypt.."-80'>[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERedmount200161_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERedmount200161-81">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:03_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-:03-82">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="859" data-file-width="720" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg/170px-Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg/255px-Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg/340px-Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kingdoms_of_Israel_and_Judah_map_830.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)" title="Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)">Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Judah</a> in the 9th century BCE</div></div></div><p>There is debate about the earliest existence of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of ancient Israel and Judah">Kingdoms of Israel and Judah</a> and their extent and power. While is unclear if there was ever a <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(united_monarchy)" title="Kingdom of Israel (united monarchy)">United Kingdom of Israel</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lipschits_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-lipschits-83">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kuhrtp438_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kuhrtp438-84">[78]</a></sup> historians and archaeologists agree that the northern <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Israel_(Samaria)" title="Kingdom of Israel (Samaria)">Kingdom of Israel</a> existed by <abbr title="circa">ca.</abbr> 900 BCE<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finkelstein_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-Finkelstein-28">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 169–195">: 169–195 </span></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wright-85">[79]</a></sup> and that the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Judah" title="Kingdom of Judah">Kingdom of Judah</a> existed by <abbr title="circa">ca.</abbr> 850 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finkelstein,_Israel,_(2020)_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-Finkelstein,_Israel,_(2020)-86">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pitcher_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-Pitcher-29">[24]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Israel was the more prosperous of the two kingdoms and soon developed into a regional power;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002146–7_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002146–7-87">[81]</a></sup> during the days of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Omride_Dynasty" title="Omride Dynasty">Omride dynasty</a>, it controlled <a href="/wiki/Samaria" title="Samaria">Samaria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a>, the upper <a href="/wiki/Jordan_Valley" title="Jordan Valley">Jordan Valley</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sharon_plain" title="Sharon plain">Sharon</a> and large parts of the <a href="/wiki/Transjordan_(region)" title="Transjordan (region)">Transjordan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-88">[82]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Samaria_(ancient_city)" title="Samaria (ancient city)">Samaria</a>, the capital, was home to one of the largest Iron Age structures in the Levant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:04_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-:04-89">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[84]</a></sup> The kingdom was destroyed around 720 BCE, when it was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire" title="Neo-Assyrian Empire">Neo-Assyrian Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Broshi_2001_174_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-Broshi_2001_174-30">[25]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Judah, with its capital in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, later became a <a href="/wiki/Client_state" title="Client state">client state</a> of first the Neo-Assyrian Empire and then the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Neo-Babylonian Empire</a>. It is estimated that <a href="/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Palestine_(region)" title="Demographic history of Palestine (region)">the region's population</a> was around 400,000 in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iron_Age_II" title="Iron Age II">Iron Age II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:42_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-:42-91">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 587/6 BCE, the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Babylonians</a> <a href="/wiki/Judah%27s_revolts_against_Babylon" title="Judah's revolts against Babylon">conquered Judah</a>. King <a href="/wiki/Nebuchadnezzar_II" title="Nebuchadnezzar II">Nebuchadnezzar II</a> <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(587_BC)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (587 BC)">besieged and destroyed Jerusalem</a> and Solomon's Temple,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002307_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002307-92">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[87]</a></sup> and exiled the Jews to <a href="/wiki/Babylon" title="Babylon">Babylon</a>. The defeat was also recorded in the <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_Chronicles" title="Babylonian Chronicles">Babylonian Chronicles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BabylonianChronicles_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-BabylonianChronicles-94">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[89]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_captivity" title="Babylonian captivity">Babylonian captivity</a> ended around 538 BCE under the rule of the Medo-Persian <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a> after he captured Babylon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rennert_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-rennert-96">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[91]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple" title="Second Temple">Second Temple</a> was constructed around 520 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rennert_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-rennert-96">[90]</a></sup> As part of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian Empire</a>, the former Kingdom of Judah became the province of Judah (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yehud_Medinata" title="Yehud Medinata">Yehud Medinata</a></i>) with different borders, covering a smaller territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grabbe355_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grabbe355-98">[92]</a></sup> The population of the province was greatly reduced from that of the kingdom, archaeological surveys showing a population of around 30,000 people in the 5th to 4th centuries BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Finkelstein_28-2"><a href="#cite_note-Finkelstein-28">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference nowrap"><span title="Page / location: 308">: 308 </span></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_period">Classical period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_period" title="Second Temple period">Second Temple period</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hasmonean_dynasty" title="Hasmonean dynasty">Hasmonean dynasty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herodian_dynasty" title="Herodian dynasty">Herodian dynasty</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_wars" title="Jewish–Roman wars">Jewish–Roman wars</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Temple_Scroll.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1189" data-file-width="1083" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Temple_Scroll.png/170px-Temple_Scroll.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Temple_Scroll.png/255px-Temple_Scroll.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Temple_Scroll.png/340px-Temple_Scroll.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Temple_Scroll.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Portion of the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Scroll" title="Temple Scroll">Temple Scroll</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a>, written during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Temple_period" title="Second Temple period">Second Temple period</a></div></div></div>
<p>With successive <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian rule</a>, the autonomous province <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yehud_Medinata" title="Yehud Medinata">Yehud Medinata</a></i> was gradually developing back into urban society, largely dominated by Judeans. The <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_Greece" title="Hellenistic Greece">Greek</a> conquests largely skipped the region without any resistance or interest. Incorporated into the <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom" title="Ptolemaic Kingdom">Ptolemaic</a> and finally the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid</a> empires, the southern Levant was heavily <a href="/wiki/Coele-Syria" title="Coele-Syria">hellenized</a>, building the tensions between Judeans and Greeks. The conflict erupted in 167 BCE with the <a href="/wiki/Maccabean_Revolt" title="Maccabean Revolt">Maccabean Revolt</a>, which succeeded in establishing an independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hasmonean_Kingdom" title="Hasmonean Kingdom">Hasmonean Kingdom</a> in Judah, which later expanded over much of modern Israel and parts of Jordan and Lebanon, as the Seleucids gradually lost control in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Republic" title="Roman Republic">Roman Republic</a> invaded the region in 63 BCE, first <a href="/wiki/Third_Mithridatic_War" title="Third Mithridatic War">taking control of Syria</a>, and then intervening in the <a href="/wiki/Hasmonean_Civil_War" title="Hasmonean Civil War">Hasmonean Civil War</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Parthian_Wars" title="Roman–Parthian Wars">struggle</a> between pro-Roman and pro-<a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian</a> factions in Judea eventually led to the installation of <a href="/wiki/Herod_the_Great" title="Herod the Great">Herod the Great</a> and consolidation of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Herodian_kingdom" title="Herodian kingdom">Herodian kingdom</a> as a vassal Judean state of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Rome</a>. Herod undertook many colossal building projects, including fully rebuilding the Second Temple and expanding the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a>. With the decline of the <a href="/wiki/Herodian_dynasty" title="Herodian dynasty">Herodian dynasty</a>, Judea transformed into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judea_(Roman_province)" title="Judea (Roman province)">a Roman province</a>.
</p><p>The first and second centuries CE saw a series of unsuccessful large-scale <a href="/wiki/Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_wars" title="Jewish–Roman wars">Jewish rebellions against Rome</a>. The Roman suppression of these revolts led to wide-scale destruction, a very high toll of life and enslavement. The <a href="/wiki/First_Jewish%E2%80%93Roman_War" title="First Jewish–Roman War">First Jewish-Roman War</a> (66–73 CE) resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(70_CE)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)">destruction of Jerusalem and the Second Temple</a>. Judaism had to reshape itself for survival without a temple, resulting in the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Rabbinic_Judaism" title="Rabbinic Judaism">Rabbinic Judaism</a>, which eventually became the religion's mainstream form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-102">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-:5-103">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[98]</a></sup> Two generations later, the <a href="/wiki/Bar_Kokhba_revolt" title="Bar Kokhba revolt">Bar Kokhba Revolt</a> (132-136 CE) erupted. Judea's countryside was devastated, and many were killed, displaced or sold into slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Taylor_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-Taylor-105">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-:02-108">[102]</a></sup> Jerusalem was rebuilt as a <a href="/wiki/Colonia_(Roman)" title="Colonia (Roman)">Roman colony</a> under the name of <a href="/wiki/Aelia_Capitolina" title="Aelia Capitolina">Aelia Capitolina</a>, and the province of Judea was renamed <a href="/wiki/Syria_Palaestina" title="Syria Palaestina">Syria Palaestina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-H.H._Ben-Sasson,_1976,_page_334_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-H.H._Ben-Sasson,_1976,_page_334-109">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ariel_Lewin_p._33_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ariel_Lewin_p._33-110">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jewish presence in the region significantly dwindled after the failure of the Bar Kokhba revolt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[105]</a></sup> Nevertheless, there was a continuous small Jewish presence and <a href="/wiki/Galilee" title="Galilee">Galilee</a> became its religious center.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[107]</a></sup> Jewish communities continued to reside in the southern <a href="/wiki/Hebron_Hills" title="Hebron Hills">Hebron Hills</a> and on the coastal plain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_108-1"><a href="#cite_note-:02-108">[102]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Mishnah" title="Mishnah">Mishnah</a> and part of the <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Talmud" title="Jerusalem Talmud">Talmud</a>, central Jewish texts, were composed during the 2nd to 4th centuries CE in <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[108]</a></sup> When the area stood under <a href="/wiki/Diocese_of_the_East" title="Diocese of the East">Byzantine rule</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Christianity" title="Early Christianity">Christianity</a> gradually evolved over <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Paganism" title="Roman Paganism">Roman Paganism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_and_modern_period">Medieval and modern period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Jerusalem_during_the_Middle_Ages" title="History of Jerusalem during the Middle Ages">History of Jerusalem during the Middle Ages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_the_Levant" title="Muslim conquest of the Levant">Muslim conquest of the Levant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crusades" title="Crusades">Crusades</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Old_Yishuv" title="Old Yishuv">Old Yishuv</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3040" data-file-width="4048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg/220px-Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg/330px-Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg/440px-Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ruins_of_the_Ancient_Synagogue_at_Bar%27am.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kfar_Bar%27am" title="Kfar Bar'am">Kfar Bar'am</a>, an ancient Jewish village, abandoned some time between the 7th–13th centuries CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[110]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>With the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conversion_of_Constantine" title="Conversion of Constantine">conversion of Constantine</a> in the 4th century, the situation for the Jewish majority in Palestine "became more difficult".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kessler2010_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kessler2010-117">[111]</a></sup> Many Jews had emigrated to flourishing <a href="/wiki/Jewish_diaspora" title="Jewish diaspora">Diaspora</a> communities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[112]</a></sup> while locally there was both Christian immigration and local conversion. Together, this led to the formation of a Christian majority by the middle of the 5th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CHJ2_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-CHJ2-119">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[114]</a></sup> Towards the end of the 5th century, the <a href="/wiki/Samaritan_revolts" title="Samaritan revolts">Samaritan revolts</a>, which continued until the late 6th century, resulted in a large decrease in the Samaritan population, further increasing the Christian majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[115]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_conquest_of_Jerusalem" title="Sasanian conquest of Jerusalem">Persian conquest</a> and the installation of a short-lived <a href="/wiki/Jewish_revolt_against_Heraclius" title="Jewish revolt against Heraclius">Jewish Commonwealth</a> in 614 CE, the Byzantine Empire <a href="/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian_War_of_602%E2%80%93628" title="Byzantine–Sasanian War of 602–628">reconquered</a> the country in 628.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 634–641 CE, the region, including Jerusalem, was <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_the_Levant" title="Muslim conquest of the Levant">conquered</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">Arabs</a> who had recently adopted <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>. Control of the region transferred between the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun" title="Rashidun">Rashidun</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caliph" title="Caliph">Caliphs</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umayyad" title="Umayyad">Umayyads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimids</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seljuks" title="Seljuks">Seljuks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crusader_states" title="Crusader states">Crusaders</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty" title="Ayyubid dynasty">Ayyubids</a> throughout the next three centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MosheGil_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-MosheGil-123">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Jerusalem_(1099)" title="Siege of Jerusalem (1099)">siege of Jerusalem</a> by the <a href="/wiki/First_Crusade" title="First Crusade">First Crusade</a> in 1099, the Jewish inhabitants of the city fought side by side with the Fatimid garrison and the Muslim population who tried in vain to defend the city against the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crusaders" title="Crusaders">Crusaders</a>. When the city fell, around 60,000 people were massacred, including 6,000 Jews seeking refuge in a synagogue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cooper2009_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cooper2009-124">[118]</a></sup> At this time, a full thousand years after the fall of the Jewish state, there were Jewish communities all over the country. Fifty of them are known and include Jerusalem, <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramla" title="Ramla">Ramleh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ashkelon" title="Ashkelon">Ashkelon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caesarea" title="Caesarea">Caesarea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gaza_City" title="Gaza City">Gaza</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[119]</a></sup> According to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Albert_of_Aachen" title="Albert of Aachen">Albert of Aachen</a>, the Jewish residents of <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a> were the main fighting force of the city, and "mixed with Saracen [Fatimid] troops", they fought bravely for close to a month until forced into retreat by the Crusader fleet and land army.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634to1099_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-634to1099-126">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Resnick2012_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-Resnick2012-127">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1187, <a href="/wiki/Saladin" title="Saladin">Saladin</a>, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty" title="Ayyubid dynasty">Ayyubid dynasty</a>, defeated the Crusaders in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hattin" title="Battle of Hattin">Battle of Hattin</a> and subsequently captured Jerusalem and almost all of Palestine. In time, Saladin issued a proclamation inviting Jews to return and settle in Jerusalem,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloch1987_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloch1987-128">[122]</a></sup> and according to <a href="/wiki/Yehuda_Alharizi" title="Yehuda Alharizi">Judah al-Harizi</a>, they did: "From the day the Arabs took Jerusalem, the Israelites inhabited it."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ben-Gurion1974_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ben-Gurion1974-129">[123]</a></sup> Al-Harizi compared Saladin's decree allowing Jews to re-establish themselves in Jerusalem to the one issued by the Persian king <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a> over 1,600 years earlier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindley2007_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindley2007-130">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ramban_shul.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Ramban_shul.jpg/220px-Ramban_shul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Ramban_shul.jpg/330px-Ramban_shul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Ramban_shul.jpg/440px-Ramban_shul.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ramban_shul.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The 13th-century <a href="/wiki/Ramban_Synagogue" title="Ramban Synagogue">Ramban Synagogue</a> in Jerusalem</div></div></div>
<p>In 1211, the Jewish community in the country was strengthened by the arrival of a group headed by over 300 <a href="/wiki/Rabbi" title="Rabbi">rabbis</a> from France and England,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CarmelSchäfer1990_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-CarmelSchäfer1990-131">[125]</a></sup> among them Rabbi <a href="/wiki/Samson_ben_Abraham_of_Sens" title="Samson ben Abraham of Sens">Samson ben Abraham of Sens</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[126]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nachmanides" title="Nachmanides">Nachmanides</a> (Ramban), the 13th-century Spanish rabbi and recognized leader of Jewry, greatly praised the Land of Israel and viewed its settlement as a positive commandment incumbent on all Jews. He wrote "If the <a href="/wiki/Gentile" title="Gentile">gentiles</a> wish to make peace, we shall make peace and leave them on clear terms; but as for the land, we shall not leave it in their hands, nor in the hands of any nation, not in any generation."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lichtman2006_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lichtman2006-133">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1260, control passed to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate_(Cairo)" title="Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)">Mamluk sultans of Egypt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GudrunKramer_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-GudrunKramer-134">[128]</a></sup> The country was located between the two centers of Mamluk power, <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Damascus" title="Damascus">Damascus</a>, and only saw some development along the postal road connecting the two cities. Jerusalem, although left without the protection of any <a href="/wiki/Walls_of_Jerusalem" title="Walls of Jerusalem">city walls</a> since 1219, also saw a flurry of new construction projects centered around the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Haram al-Sharif</a> (the Temple Mount). In 1266, the Mamluk Sultan <a href="/wiki/Baybars" title="Baybars">Baybars</a> converted the <a href="/wiki/Cave_of_the_Patriarchs" title="Cave of the Patriarchs">Cave of the Patriarchs</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a> into an exclusive Islamic sanctuary and banned Christians and Jews from entering, who previously had been able to enter it for a fee. The ban remained in place until Israel took control of the building in 1967.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils,_1870s.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2313" data-file-width="2978" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg/220px-Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg/330px-Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg/440px-Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils%2C_1870s.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Jews_at_Western_Wall_by_Felix_Bonfils,_1870s.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Jews at the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a> in the 1870s</div></div></div>
<p>In 1470, Isaac b. Meir Latif arrived from Italy and counted 150 Jewish families in Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bahat1976_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bahat1976-137">[131]</a></sup>
Thanks to <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Saragossi" title="Joseph Saragossi">Joseph Saragossi</a> who had arrived in the closing years of the 15th century, <a href="/wiki/Safed" title="Safed">Safed</a> and its environs had developed into the largest concentration of Jews in Palestine. With the help of the <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">Sephardic</a> immigration from Spain, the Jewish population had increased to 10,000 by the early 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Andrews1976_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-Andrews1976-138">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1516, the region was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>; it remained under <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Syria" title="Ottoman Syria">Turkish rule</a> until the end of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">First World War</a>, when Britain defeated the Ottoman forces and set up a <a href="/wiki/Occupied_Enemy_Territory_Administration" title="Occupied Enemy Territory Administration">military administration</a> across the former <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Syria" title="Ottoman Syria">Ottoman Syria</a>. In 1660, a <a href="/wiki/Druze_power_struggle_(1658%E2%80%931667)#Lebanon_and_Galilee_campaign" title="Druze power struggle (1658–1667)">Druze revolt</a> led to the destruction of <a href="/wiki/1660_destruction_of_Safed" title="1660 destruction of Safed">Safed</a> and <a href="/wiki/1660_destruction_of_Tiberias" title="1660 destruction of Tiberias">Tiberias</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[133]</a></sup> In the late 18th century, local Arab <a href="/wiki/Sheikh" title="Sheikh">Sheikh</a> <a href="/wiki/Zahir_al-Umar" title="Zahir al-Umar">Zahir al-Umar</a> created a de facto independent Emirate in the Galilee. Ottoman attempts to subdue the Sheikh failed, but after Zahir's death the Ottomans regained control of the area. In 1799 governor <a href="/wiki/Jazzar_Pasha" title="Jazzar Pasha">Jazzar Pasha</a> successfully repelled an <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Acre_(1799)" title="Siege of Acre (1799)">assault on Acre</a> by troops of <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>, prompting the French to abandon the Syrian campaign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[134]</a></sup> In 1834 a <a href="/wiki/Peasants%27_revolt_in_Palestine" title="Peasants' revolt in Palestine">revolt by Palestinian Arab peasants</a> broke out against Egyptian conscription and taxation policies under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Muhammad Ali</a>. Although the revolt was suppressed, Muhammad Ali's army retreated and Ottoman rule was restored with British support in 1840.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[135]</a></sup> Shortly after, the <a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a> reforms were implemented across the Ottoman Empire. In 1920, after the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">conquered the Levant during World War I</a>, the territory was divided between Britain and France under the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate" title="League of Nations mandate">mandate system</a>, and the British-administered area which included modern day Israel was named <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Mandatory Palestine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GudrunKramer_134-1"><a href="#cite_note-GudrunKramer-134">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[136]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[137]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Zionism_and_British_Mandate">Zionism and British Mandate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yishuv" title="Yishuv">Yishuv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mutasarrifate_of_Jerusalem" title="Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem">Mutasarrifate of Jerusalem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine" title="Mandatory Palestine">Mandatory Palestine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mandate_for_Palestine" title="Mandate for Palestine">Mandate for Palestine</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Balfour_Declaration" title="Balfour Declaration">Balfour Declaration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Intercommunal_conflict_in_Mandatory_Palestine" title="Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory Palestine">Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory Palestine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg/220px-THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg/330px-THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg/440px-THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:THEODOR_HERZL_AT_THE_FIRST_ZIONIST_CONGRESS_IN_BASEL_ON_25.8.1897._%D7%AA%D7%90%D7%95%D7%93%D7%95%D7%A8_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%A6%D7%9C_%D7%91%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%92%D7%A8%D7%A1_%D7%94%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%A0%D7%99_%D7%94%D7%A8%D7%90%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9F_-_1897.8.25.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/First_Zionist_Congress" title="First Zionist Congress">First Zionist Congress</a> (1897) in <a href="/wiki/Basel" title="Basel">Basel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since the existence of the earliest <a href="/wiki/Jewish_diaspora" title="Jewish diaspora">Jewish diaspora</a>, many Jews have aspired to <a href="/wiki/Aliyah" title="Aliyah">return</a> to "Zion" and the "Land of Israel",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[138]</a></sup> though the amount of effort that should be spent towards such an aim was a matter of dispute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[139]</a></sup> After the Jews were <a href="/wiki/Alhambra_Decree" title="Alhambra Decree">expelled from Spain</a> in 1492, some communities settled in Palestine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[140]</a></sup> During the 16th century, Jewish communities struck roots in the <a href="/wiki/Four_Holy_Cities" title="Four Holy Cities">Four Holy Cities</a>—<a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Safed" title="Safed">Safed</a>—and in 1697, Rabbi Yehuda Hachasid led a group of 1,500 Jews to Jerusalem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[141]</a></sup> In the second half of the 18th century, Eastern European <a href="/wiki/Misnagdim" title="Misnagdim">opponents</a> of <a href="/wiki/Hasidic_Judaism" title="Hasidic Judaism">Hasidism</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/Perushim" title="Perushim">Perushim</a>, settled in Palestine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[143]</a></sup>
</p>
