<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1062260506">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:.5em 1.4em .8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{overflow:hidden;position:relative;margin:.5em auto .8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft span,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright span{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox>blockquote{margin:0;padding:0;border-left:0;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote>:first-child{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote:last-child>:last-child{margin-bottom:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" “ ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" ” ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quote-title,.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quotebox-quote{display:block}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 .8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class="quotebox pullquote floatleft" style="width:240px; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>"Therefore I believe that a wonderous generation of Jews will spring into existence. The Maccabaeans will rise again. Let me repeat once more my opening words: The Jews wish to have a State, and they shall have one. We shall live at last as free men on our own soil, and die peacefully in our own home. The world will be freed by our liberty, enriched by our wealth, magnified by our greatness. And whatever we attempt there to accomplish for our own welfare will react with beneficent force for the good of humanity."
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="left-aligned" style=""><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation cs1" id="CITEREFTheodor_Herzl1896">Theodor Herzl (1896). <span class="cs1-ws-icon" title="s:A Jewish State (1917 translation)/Conclusion"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/A_Jewish_State_(1917_translation)/Conclusion"><i>A Jewish State</i> </a></span> – via <a href="/wiki/Wikisource" title="Wikisource">Wikisource</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Jewish+State&amp;rft.date=1896&amp;rft.au=Theodor+Herzl&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span> [<span style="font-size:85%;"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Page:A_Jewish_State_1917.djvu/60" title="wikisource:Page:A Jewish State 1917.djvu/60"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886049405">.mw-parser-output .noitalic{font-style:normal}</style><span class="noitalic">scan</span></a></span> <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wikisource-logo.svg"><img alt="Wikisource link" class="noviewer" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="410" decoding="async" height="13" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/12px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/18px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg/24px-Wikisource-logo.svg.png 2x" width="12"/></a>]</cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>The first wave of modern Jewish migration to <a href="/wiki/Southern_Syria" title="Southern Syria">Ottoman-ruled Palestine</a>, known as the <a href="/wiki/First_Aliyah" title="First Aliyah">First Aliyah</a>, began in 1881, as Jews fled <a href="/wiki/Pogrom#Pogroms_against_Jews" title="Pogrom">pogroms</a> in Eastern Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[144]</a></sup> Although the Zionist movement already existed in practice, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian" title="Austro-Hungarian">Austro-Hungarian</a> journalist <a href="/wiki/Theodor_Herzl" title="Theodor Herzl">Theodor Herzl</a> is credited with founding political <a href="/wiki/Zionism" title="Zionism">Zionism</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[145]</a></sup> a movement that sought to establish a <a href="/wiki/Jewish_state" title="Jewish state">Jewish state</a> in the Land of Israel, thus offering a solution to the so-called <a href="/wiki/Jewish_question" title="Jewish question">Jewish question</a> of the European states, in conformity with the goals and achievements of other national projects of the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[146]</a></sup> In 1896, Herzl published <i><a href="/wiki/Der_Judenstaat" title="Der Judenstaat">Der Judenstaat</a></i> (<i>The Jewish State</i>), offering his vision of a future Jewish state; the following year he presided over the <a href="/wiki/First_Zionist_Congress" title="First Zionist Congress">First Zionist Congress</a> in <a href="/wiki/Basel" title="Basel">Basel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[147]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Second_Aliyah" title="Second Aliyah">Second Aliyah</a> (1904–14) began after the <a href="/wiki/Kishinev_pogrom" title="Kishinev pogrom">Kishinev pogrom</a>; some 40,000 Jews settled in Palestine, although nearly half of them left eventually. Both the first and second waves of migrants were mainly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Orthodox_Jews" title="Orthodox Jews">Orthodox Jews</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[148]</a></sup> although the Second Aliyah included <a href="/wiki/Labor_Zionism" title="Labor Zionism">socialist</a> groups who established the <i><a href="/wiki/Kibbutz" title="Kibbutz">kibbutz</a></i> movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[149]</a></sup> Though the immigrants of the Second Aliyah largely sought to create communal agricultural settlements, the period also saw the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv" title="Tel Aviv">Tel Aviv</a> in 1909 as the "first Hebrew city." This period also saw the appearance of Jewish armed self-defense organizations as a means of defense for Jewish settlements. The first such organization was <a href="/wiki/Bar-Giora_(organization)" title="Bar-Giora (organization)">Bar-Giora</a>, a small secret guard founded in 1907. Two years later, larger <a href="/wiki/Hashomer" title="Hashomer">Hashomer</a> organization was founded as its replacement. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, British Foreign Secretary <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Balfour" title="Arthur Balfour">Arthur Balfour</a> sent the <a href="/wiki/Balfour_Declaration" title="Balfour Declaration">Balfour Declaration</a> to <a href="/wiki/Walter_Rothschild,_2nd_Baron_Rothschild" title="Walter Rothschild, 2nd Baron Rothschild">Lord Rothschild</a> (Walter Rothschild, 2nd Baron Rothschild), a leader of the British Jewish community, that stated that Britain intended for the creation of a Jewish "<a href="/wiki/Homeland_for_the_Jewish_people" title="Homeland for the Jewish people">national home</a>" in Palestine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-macintyre_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-macintyre-156">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1918, the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Legion" title="Jewish Legion">Jewish Legion</a>, a group primarily of Zionist volunteers, assisted in the British <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sinai_and_Palestine_Campaign" title="Sinai and Palestine Campaign">conquest of Palestine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[152]</a></sup> Arab opposition to British rule and Jewish immigration led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1920_Palestine_riots" title="1920 Palestine riots">1920 Palestine riots</a> and the formation of a Jewish militia known as the <a href="/wiki/Haganah" title="Haganah">Haganah</a> (meaning "The Defense" in Hebrew) in 1920 as an outgrowth of Hashomer, from which the <a href="/wiki/Irgun" title="Irgun">Irgun</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lehi_(group)" title="Lehi (group)">Lehi</a> (or the Stern Gang) paramilitaries later split off.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[153]</a></sup> In 1922, the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> granted Britain the <a href="/wiki/Mandate_for_Palestine" title="Mandate for Palestine">Mandate for Palestine</a> under terms which included the Balfour Declaration with its promise to the Jews, and with similar provisions regarding the Arab Palestinians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[154]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Palestine_(region)" title="Demographic history of Palestine (region)">population of the area</a> at this time was predominantly Arab and Muslim, with Jews accounting for about 11%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[155]</a></sup> and Arab Christians about 9.5% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Third_Aliyah" title="Third Aliyah">Third</a> (1919–23) and <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Aliyah" title="Fourth Aliyah">Fourth Aliyahs</a> (1924–29) brought an additional 100,000 Jews to Palestine. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hitler%27s_rise_to_power" title="Hitler's rise to power">rise of Nazism</a> and the increasing persecution of Jews in 1930s Europe led to the <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Aliyah" title="Fifth Aliyah">Fifth Aliyah</a>, with an influx of a quarter of a million Jews. This was a major cause of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1936%E2%80%9339_Arab_revolt_in_Palestine" title="1936–39 Arab revolt in Palestine">Arab revolt of 1936–39</a>, which was launched as a reaction to continued Jewish immigration and land purchases. Several hundred Jews and British security personnel were killed, while the British Mandate authorities alongside the Zionist militias of the Haganah and Irgun killed 5,032 Arabs and wounded 14,760,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[158]</a></sup> resulting in over ten percent of the adult male <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_Arab" title="Palestinian Arab">Palestinian Arab</a> population killed, wounded, imprisoned or exiled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[159]</a></sup> The British introduced restrictions on Jewish immigration to Palestine with the <a href="/wiki/White_Paper_of_1939" title="White Paper of 1939">White Paper of 1939</a>. With countries around the world turning away <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_refugees" title="Jewish refugees">Jewish refugees</a> fleeing <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">the Holocaust</a>, a clandestine movement known as <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_Bet" title="Aliyah Bet">Aliyah Bet</a> was organized to bring Jews to Palestine. By the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the Jewish population of Palestine had increased to 31% of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="After_World_War_II">After World War II</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1947%E2%80%931949_Palestine_war" title="1947–1949 Palestine war">1947–1949 Palestine war</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">Israeli Declaration of Independence</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:199px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2838" data-file-width="1370" decoding="async" height="408" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg/197px-UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg/296px-UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg/394px-UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg 2x" width="197"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UN_Palestine_Partition_Versions_1947.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">UN Map</a>, "Palestine plan of partition with economic union"</div></div></div>
<p>After World War II, the UK found itself facing a Jewish <a href="/wiki/Jewish_insurgency_in_Mandatory_Palestine" title="Jewish insurgency in Mandatory Palestine">guerrilla campaign</a> over Jewish immigration restrictions, as well as continued conflict with the Arab community over limit levels. The Haganah joined Irgun and Lehi in an armed struggle against British rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[161]</a></sup> At the same time, hundreds of thousands of Jewish <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_survivors" title="Holocaust survivors">Holocaust survivors</a> and refugees sought a new life far from their destroyed communities in Europe. The Haganah attempted to bring these refugees to Palestine in a program called <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_Bet" title="Aliyah Bet">Aliyah Bet</a> in which tens of thousands of Jewish refugees attempted to enter Palestine by ship. Most of the ships were intercepted by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> and the refugees rounded up and placed in detention camps in <a href="/wiki/Atlit_detainee_camp" title="Atlit detainee camp">Atlit</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_internment_camps" title="Cyprus internment camps">Cyprus</a> by the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Golani2013_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Golani2013-168">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 22 July 1946, Irgun <a href="/wiki/King_David_Hotel_bombing" title="King David Hotel bombing">bombed</a> the British administrative headquarters for Palestine, which was housed in the southern wing<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[164]</a></sup> of the <a href="/wiki/King_David_Hotel" title="King David Hotel">King David Hotel</a> in <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-brtca_irgun_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-brtca_irgun-172">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[167]</a></sup> A total of 91 people of various nationalities were killed and 46 were injured.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tclarke81_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-tclarke81-174">[168]</a></sup> The hotel was the site of the Secretariat of the Government of Palestine and the Headquarters of the British Armed Forces in Mandatory Palestine and <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Transjordan" title="Emirate of Transjordan">Transjordan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tclarke81_174-1"><a href="#cite_note-tclarke81-174">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bethell_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-bethell-175">[169]</a></sup> The attack initially had the approval of the Haganah. It was conceived as a response to <a href="/wiki/Operation_Agatha" title="Operation Agatha">Operation Agatha</a> (a series of widespread raids, including one on the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Agency_for_Israel" title="Jewish Agency for Israel">Jewish Agency</a>, conducted by the British authorities) and was the deadliest directed at the British during the Mandate era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tclarke81_174-2"><a href="#cite_note-tclarke81-174">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bethell_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-bethell-175">[169]</a></sup> The Jewish insurgency continued throughout the rest of 1946 and 1947 despite concerted efforts by the British military and <a href="/wiki/Palestine_Police_Force" title="Palestine Police Force">Palestine Police Force</a> to suppress it. British efforts to mediate a negotiated solution with Jewish and Arab representatives also failed as the Jews were unwilling to accept any solution that did not involve a Jewish state and suggested a partition of Palestine into Jewish and Arab states, while the Arabs were adamant that a Jewish state in any part of Palestine was unacceptable and that the only solution was a unified Palestine under Arab rule. In February 1947, the British referred the Palestine issue to the newly formed <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>. On 15 May 1947, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_United_Nations" title="General Assembly of the United Nations">General Assembly</a> of the United Nations resolved that the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Special_Committee_on_Palestine" title="United Nations Special Committee on Palestine">United Nations Special Committee on Palestine</a> be created "to prepare for consideration at the next regular session of the Assembly a report on the question of Palestine."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[170]</a></sup> In the Report of the Committee dated 3 September 1947 to the General Assembly,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[171]</a></sup> the majority of the Committee in Chapter VI <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">proposed a plan</a> to replace the British Mandate with "an independent Arab State, an independent Jewish State, and the City of Jerusalem [...] the last to be under an International Trusteeship System."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[172]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the Jewish insurgency continued and peaked in July 1947, with a series of widespread guerrilla raids culminating in <a href="/wiki/The_Sergeants_affair" title="The Sergeants affair">the Sergeants affair</a>. After three Irgun fighters had been sentenced to death for their role in the <a href="/wiki/Acre_Prison_break" title="Acre Prison break">Acre Prison break</a>, a May 1947 Irgun raid on <a href="/wiki/Acre_Prison" title="Acre Prison">Acre Prison</a> in which 27 Irgun and Lehi militants were freed, the Irgun captured two British sergeants and held them hostage, threatening to kill them if the three men were executed. When the British carried out the executions, the Irgun responded by killing both hostages and hanged their bodies from eucalyptus trees, booby-trapping one of them with a mine which injured a British officer as he cut the body down. The hangings caused widespread outrage in Britain and were a major factor in the consensus forming in Britain that it was time to evacuate Palestine.
</p><p>In September 1947, the British cabinet decided that the Mandate was no longer tenable, and to evacuate Palestine. According to Colonial Secretary <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Creech_Jones" title="Arthur Creech Jones">Arthur Creech Jones</a>, four major factors led to the decision to evacuate Palestine: the inflexibility of Jewish and Arab negotiators who were unwilling to compromise on their core positions over the question of a Jewish state in Palestine, the economic pressure that stationing a large garrison in Palestine to deal with the Jewish insurgency and the possibility of a wider Jewish rebellion and the possibility of an Arab rebellion put on a British economy already strained by World War II, the "deadly blow to British patience and pride" caused by the hangings of the sergeants, and the mounting criticism the government faced in failing to find a new policy for Palestine in place of the <a href="/wiki/White_Paper_of_1939" title="White Paper of 1939">White Paper of 1939</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 29 November 1947, the General Assembly adopted <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">Resolution 181 (II)</a> recommending the adoption and implementation of the <i>Plan of Partition with Economic Union</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181(II)_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-181(II)-34">[29]</a></sup> The plan attached to the resolution was essentially that proposed by the majority of the Committee in the report of 3 September. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_Agency" title="Jewish Agency">Jewish Agency</a>, which was the recognized representative of the Jewish community, accepted the plan, which assigned to Jews – a third of the population owning less than 7% of the land – 55–56% of Mandatory Palestine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris200875_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris200875-181">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008396_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008396-182">[176]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arab_Higher_Committee" title="Arab Higher Committee">Arab Higher Committee</a> of Palestine rejected it, and indicated that they would reject any other plan of partition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris200866_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris200866-183">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman200240–41_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman200240–41-184">[178]</a></sup> On the following day, 1 December 1947, the Arab Higher Committee proclaimed a three-day strike, and <a href="/wiki/1947_Jerusalem_riots" title="1947 Jerusalem riots">riots broke out in Jerusalem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[179]</a></sup> The situation spiraled into a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1947%E2%80%9348_Civil_War_in_Mandatory_Palestine" title="1947–48 Civil War in Mandatory Palestine">civil war</a>; just two weeks after the UN vote, Colonial Secretary <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Creech_Jones" title="Arthur Creech Jones">Arthur Creech Jones</a> announced that the British Mandate would end on 15 May 1948, at which point the British would evacuate. As Arab militias and gangs attacked Jewish areas, they were faced mainly by the <a href="/wiki/Haganah" title="Haganah">Haganah</a>, as well as the smaller Irgun and Lehi. In April 1948, the Haganah moved onto the offensive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris200877–78_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris200877–78-186">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[181]</a></sup> During this period 250,000 Palestinian Arabs fled or were expelled, due to <a href="/wiki/Causes_of_the_1948_Palestinian_exodus" title="Causes of the 1948 Palestinian exodus">a number of factors</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008-188">[182]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti style="width:332px;max-width:332px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:226px;max-width:226px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" Declaration of Independence</a> on 14 May 1948</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:102px;max-width:102px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_(Eilat).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2821" data-file-width="1844" decoding="async" height="153" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg/150px-Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg/200px-Raising_the_Ink_Flag_at_Umm_Rashrash_%28Eilat%29.jpg 2x" width="100"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Raising of the <a href="/wiki/Ink_Flag" title="Ink Flag">Ink Flag</a> on 10 March 1949, marking the end of the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 war</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>On 14 May 1948, the day before the expiration of the British Mandate, <a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a>, the head of the Jewish Agency, <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Israeli Declaration of Independence">declared</a> "the establishment of a Jewish state in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eretz-Israel" title="Eretz-Israel">Eretz-Israel</a>, to be known as the State of Israel."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Declaration_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-Declaration-189">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[184]</a></sup> The only reference in the text of the Declaration to the borders of the new state is the use of the term <i>Eretz-Israel</i> ("<a href="/wiki/Land_of_Israel" title="Land of Israel">Land of Israel</a>").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[185]</a></sup> The following day, the armies of four Arab countries—<a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Egypt" title="Kingdom of Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian_Republic_(1946%E2%80%9363)" title="Syrian Republic (1946–63)">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Transjordan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Iraq" title="Kingdom of Iraq">Iraq</a>—entered into parts of what had been British Mandatory Palestine, launching the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[188]</a></sup> contingents from <a href="/wiki/Yemen" title="Yemen">Yemen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a> joined the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008205_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008205-195">[189]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[190]</a></sup> The apparent purpose of the invasion was to prevent the establishment of the Jewish state at inception, and some Arab leaders talked about "driving the Jews into the sea".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008396_182-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008396-182">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008187_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008187-198">[192]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Benny_Morris" title="Benny Morris">Benny Morris</a>, Jews were worried that the invading Arab armies held the intent to slaughter them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008198_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008198-199">[193]</a></sup> The Arab league stated the invasion was to restore law and order and to prevent further bloodshed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cablegram_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-cablegram-200">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>After a year of fighting, a <a href="/wiki/1949_Armistice_Agreements" title="1949 Armistice Agreements">ceasefire was declared</a> and temporary borders, known as the <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a>, were established.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[195]</a></sup> Jordan <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_annexation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian annexation of the West Bank">annexed</a> what became known as the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, including <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, and Egypt <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Gaza_Strip_by_Egypt" title="Occupation of the Gaza Strip by Egypt">occupied</a> the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a>. The UN estimated that more than 700,000 Palestinians were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1948_Palestinian_exodus" title="1948 Palestinian exodus">expelled by or fled from</a> advancing <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israeli forces</a> during the conflict—what would become known in Arabic as the <i><a href="/wiki/Nakba" title="Nakba">Nakba</a></i> ("catastrophe").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[196]</a></sup> Some 156,000 remained and became <a href="/wiki/Arab_citizens_of_Israel" title="Arab citizens of Israel">Arab citizens of Israel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years_of_the_State_of_Israel">Early years of the State of Israel</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab–Israeli conflict">Arab–Israeli conflict</a></div>
<p>Israel <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_273" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 273">was admitted</a> as a member of the UN by majority vote on 11 May 1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[198]</a></sup> An Israeli-Jordanian attempt at negotiating a peace agreement broke down after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_government" title="British government">British government</a>, fearful of the Egyptian reaction to such a treaty, expressed their opposition to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_of_Jordan" title="Government of Jordan">Jordanian government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[199]</a></sup> In the early years of the state, the <a href="/wiki/Labor_Zionism" title="Labor Zionism">Labor Zionist</a> movement led by Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/David_Ben-Gurion" title="David Ben-Gurion">David Ben-Gurion</a> dominated <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel" title="Politics of Israel">Israeli politics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>Immigration to Israel during the late 1940s and early 1950s was aided by the Israeli Immigration Department and the non-government sponsored <a href="/wiki/Mossad_LeAliyah_Bet" title="Mossad LeAliyah Bet">Mossad LeAliyah Bet</a> (<abbr class="small" title="literally">lit.</abbr> "Institute for <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_Bet" title="Aliyah Bet">Immigration B</a>") which organized illegal and clandestine immigration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[202]</a></sup> Both groups facilitated regular immigration logistics like arranging transportation, but the latter also engaged in clandestine operations in countries, particularly in the Middle East and Eastern Europe, where the lives of Jews were believed to be in danger and exit from those places was difficult. Mossad LeAliyah Bet was disbanded in 1953.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[203]</a></sup> The immigration was in accordance with the <a href="/wiki/One_Million_Plan" title="One Million Plan">One Million Plan</a>. The immigrants came for differing reasons: some held Zionist beliefs or came for the promise of a better life in Israel, while others moved to escape persecution or were expelled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>An <a href="/wiki/Aliyah#Early_statehood_(1948–1960)" title="Aliyah">influx of Holocaust survivors</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_exodus_from_Arab_and_Muslim_countries" title="Jewish exodus from Arab and Muslim countries">Jews from Arab and Muslim countries</a> to Israel during the first three years increased the number of Jews from 700,000 to 1,400,000. By 1958, the population of Israel rose to two million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[206]</a></sup> Between 1948 and 1970, approximately 1,150,000 Jewish refugees relocated to Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[207]</a></sup> Some new immigrants arrived as refugees with no possessions and were housed in temporary camps known as <i><a href="/wiki/Ma%27abarot" title="Ma'abarot">ma'abarot</a></i>; by 1952, over 200,000 people were living in these tent cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[208]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">Jews of European background</a> were often treated more favorably than Jews from <a href="/wiki/Mizrahi_Jews" title="Mizrahi Jews">Middle Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">North African</a> countries—housing units reserved for the latter were often re-designated for the former, with the result that Jews newly arrived from Arab lands generally ended up staying in transit camps for longer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[210]</a></sup> During this period, food, clothes and furniture had to be rationed in what became known as the <a href="/wiki/Austerity_in_Israel" title="Austerity in Israel">austerity period</a>. The need to solve the crisis led Ben-Gurion to sign a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reparations_Agreement_between_Israel_and_West_Germany" title="Reparations Agreement between Israel and West Germany">reparations agreement with West Germany</a> that triggered mass protests by Jews angered at the idea that Israel could accept monetary compensation for the Holocaust.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[211]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><video class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="74" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv" height="155" id="mwe_player_1" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv/220px--1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv.jpg" preload="none" width="220"><source data-bandwidth="391353" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="276" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file, 392 × 276 (391 kbps)" data-width="392" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/34/1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv" type='video/ogg; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="314968" data-framerate="29.97002997003" data-height="240" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="340" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/3/34/1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv/1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv.240p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3A1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="español ‪(es)‬" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3A1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv&amp;lang=es&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="es" type="text/vtt"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="suomi ‪(fi)‬" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3A1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv&amp;lang=fi&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="fi" type="text/vtt"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="português ‪(pt)‬" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3A1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv&amp;lang=pt&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="pt" type="text/vtt"/></video> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1961-04-13_Tale_Of_Century_-_Eichmann_Tried_For_War_Crimes.ogv" title="Enlarge"></a></div>U.S. newsreel on the trial of <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Eichmann" title="Adolf Eichmann">Adolf Eichmann</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the 1950s, Israel was frequently <a href="/wiki/List_of_attacks_against_Israeli_civilians_before_1967" title="List of attacks against Israeli civilians before 1967">attacked</a> by <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_fedayeen" title="Palestinian fedayeen">Palestinian fedayeen</a>, nearly always against civilians,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[212]</a></sup> mainly from the Egyptian-occupied Gaza Strip,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[213]</a></sup> leading to several Israeli <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reprisal_operations" title="Reprisal operations">reprisal operations</a>. In 1956, the United Kingdom and France aimed at regaining control of the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a>, which the Egyptians had nationalized. The continued blockade of the Suez Canal and <a href="/wiki/Straits_of_Tiran" title="Straits of Tiran">Straits of Tiran</a> to Israeli shipping, together with the growing amount of Fedayeen attacks against Israel's southern population, and recent Arab grave and threatening statements, prompted Israel to attack Egypt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[216]</a></sup> Israel joined <a href="/wiki/Protocol_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Protocol of Sèvres">a secret alliance</a> with the United Kingdom and France and overran the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> but was pressured to withdraw by the UN in return for guarantees of Israeli shipping rights in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> via the Straits of Tiran and the Canal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[217]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[219]</a></sup> The war, known as the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a>, resulted in significant reduction of Israeli border infiltration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[220]</a></sup> In the early 1960s, Israel captured Nazi war criminal <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Eichmann" title="Adolf Eichmann">Adolf Eichmann</a> in Argentina and brought him to Israel for <a href="/wiki/Eichmann_trial" title="Eichmann trial">trial</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBascomb2009219–229_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBascomb2009219–229-227">[221]</a></sup> The trial had a major impact on public awareness of the Holocaust.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[222]</a></sup> Eichmann remains the only person executed in Israel by conviction in an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_judicial_system" title="Israeli judicial system">Israeli civilian court</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[223]</a></sup> During the spring and summer of 1963 Israel was engaged in a diplomatic standoff with the United States due to the Israeli <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Israel" title="Nuclear weapons and Israel">nuclear program</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haaretz2019_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haaretz2019-230">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Six_Day_War_Territories.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Six_Day_War_Territories.svg/170px-Six_Day_War_Territories.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Six_Day_War_Territories.svg/255px-Six_Day_War_Territories.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Six_Day_War_Territories.svg/340px-Six_Day_War_Territories.svg.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Six_Day_War_Territories.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Territory held by Israel: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffffd0; color:black;"> </span> before the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#f7d3aa; color:black;"> </span> after the war</div> The <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> was returned to Egypt in 1982.</div></div></div>
<p>Since 1964, Arab countries, concerned over Israeli plans to divert waters of the <a href="/wiki/Jordan_River" title="Jordan River">Jordan River</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_coastal_plain" title="Israeli coastal plain">coastal plain</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[226]</a></sup> had been trying to divert the headwaters to deprive Israel of water resources, provoking <a href="/wiki/War_over_Water_(Jordan_river)" title="War over Water (Jordan river)">tensions</a> between Israel on the one hand, and Syria and Lebanon on the other. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_nationalist" title="Arab nationalist">Arab nationalists</a> led by Egyptian President <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a> refused to recognize Israel and called for its destruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RoutledgeAtlas_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-RoutledgeAtlas-37">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[228]</a></sup> By 1966, Israeli-Arab relations had deteriorated to the point of actual battles taking place between Israeli and Arab forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[229]</a></sup> In May 1967, Egypt massed its army near the border with Israel, expelled <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Emergency_Force" title="United Nations Emergency Force">UN peacekeepers</a>, stationed in the Sinai Peninsula since 1957, and blocked Israel's access to the Red Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[232]</a></sup> Other Arab states mobilized their forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[233]</a></sup> Israel reiterated that these actions were a <i><a href="/wiki/Casus_belli" title="Casus belli">casus belli</a></i> and, on 5 June, launched a <a href="/wiki/Operation_Focus" title="Operation Focus">pre-emptive strike</a> against Egypt. Jordan, Syria and Iraq responded and attacked Israel. In a <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>, Israel captured and occupied the West Bank from Jordan, the Gaza Strip and Sinai Peninsula from Egypt, and the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a> from Syria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[234]</a></sup> Jerusalem's boundaries were enlarged, incorporating <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, and the 1949 <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a> became the administrative boundary between Israel and the <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Israeli-occupied territories">occupied territories</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Following the 1967 war and the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Three_Nos" title="Three Nos">Three Nos</a>" resolution of the Arab League, Israel faced attacks from the Egyptians in the Sinai Peninsula during the 1967–1970 <a href="/wiki/War_of_Attrition" title="War of Attrition">War of Attrition</a>, and from Palestinian groups targeting Israelis in the occupied territories, in Israel proper, and around the world. Most important among the various Palestinian and Arab groups was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_Liberation_Organization" title="Palestinian Liberation Organization">Palestinian Liberation Organization</a> (PLO), established in 1964, which initially committed itself to "armed struggle as the only way to liberate the homeland".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[236]</a></sup> In the late 1960s and early 1970s, Palestinian groups launched a <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_political_violence" title="Palestinian political violence">wave of attacks</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[238]</a></sup> against Israeli and Jewish targets around the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[239]</a></sup> including <a href="/wiki/Munich_massacre" title="Munich massacre">a massacre of Israeli athletes</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics" title="1972 Summer Olympics">1972 Summer Olympics</a> in Munich. The Israeli government responded with an <a href="/wiki/Operation_Wrath_of_God" title="Operation Wrath of God">assassination campaign</a> against the organizers of the massacre, a <a href="/wiki/1972_Israeli_air_raid_in_Syria_and_Lebanon" title="1972 Israeli air raid in Syria and Lebanon">bombing</a> and a <a href="/wiki/1973_Israeli_raid_on_Lebanon" title="1973 Israeli raid on Lebanon">raid on the PLO headquarters in Lebanon</a>.
</p><p>On 6 October 1973, as Jews were observing <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur" title="Yom Kippur">Yom Kippur</a>, the Egyptian and Syrian armies launched <a href="/wiki/Operation_Badr_(1973)" title="Operation Badr (1973)">a surprise attack</a> against Israeli forces in the Sinai Peninsula and Golan Heights, that opened the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a>. The war ended on 25 October with Israel successfully repelling Egyptian and Syrian forces but having suffered over 2,500 soldiers killed in a war which collectively took 10–35,000 lives in about 20 days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[240]</a></sup> An <a href="/wiki/Agranat_Commission" title="Agranat Commission">internal inquiry</a> exonerated <a href="/wiki/Fifteenth_government_of_Israel" title="Fifteenth government of Israel">the government</a> of responsibility for failures before and during the war, but public anger forced Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Golda_Meir" title="Golda Meir">Golda Meir</a> to resign.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[241]</a></sup> In July 1976, an airliner was hijacked during its flight from Israel to France by Palestinian guerrillas and landed at <a href="/wiki/Entebbe_International_Airport" title="Entebbe International Airport">Entebbe International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uganda" title="Uganda">Uganda</a>. Israeli commandos carried out <a href="/wiki/Operation_Entebbe" title="Operation Entebbe">an operation</a> in which 102 out of 106 Israeli hostages were successfully rescued.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_conflict_and_peace_process">Further conflict and peace process</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_peace_process" title="Israeli–Palestinian peace process">Israeli–Palestinian peace process</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict" title="Iran–Israel proxy conflict">Iran–Israel proxy conflict</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/One-state_solution" title="One-state solution">One-state solution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Two-state_solution" title="Two-state solution">Two-state solution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Three-state_solution" title="Three-state solution">Three-state solution</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lieberman_Plan" title="Lieberman Plan">Lieberman Plan</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/1977_Israeli_legislative_election" title="1977 Israeli legislative election">1977 Knesset elections</a> marked a major turning point in Israeli political history as <a href="/wiki/Menachem_Begin" title="Menachem Begin">Menachem Begin</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Likud" title="Likud">Likud</a> party took control from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_Party_(Israel)" title="Labor Party (Israel)">Labor Party</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[fn 7]</a></sup> Later that year, Egyptian President <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anwar_El_Sadat" title="Anwar El Sadat">Anwar El Sadat</a> made a trip to Israel and spoke before the <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> in what was the first recognition of Israel by an Arab head of state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002171–174_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002171–174-250">[243]</a></sup> In the two years that followed, Sadat and Begin signed the <a href="/wiki/Camp_David_Accords" title="Camp David Accords">Camp David Accords</a> (1978) and the <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_peace_treaty" title="Egypt–Israel peace treaty">Egypt–Israel peace treaty</a> (1979).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002186–187_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002186–187-251">[244]</a></sup> In return, Israel withdrew from the Sinai Peninsula and agreed to enter negotiations over an autonomy for Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002186–187_251-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002186–187-251">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 11 March 1978, a PLO guerilla raid from Lebanon led to the <a href="/wiki/Coastal_Road_massacre" title="Coastal Road massacre">Coastal Road massacre</a>. Israel responded by launching an <a href="/wiki/1978_South_Lebanon_conflict" title="1978 South Lebanon conflict">invasion of southern Lebanon</a> to destroy the PLO bases south of the <a href="/wiki/Litani_River" title="Litani River">Litani River</a>. Most PLO fighters withdrew, but Israel was able to secure southern Lebanon until a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Force_in_Lebanon" title="United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon">UN force</a> and the Lebanese army could take over. The PLO soon resumed its <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_insurgency_in_South_Lebanon" title="Palestinian insurgency in South Lebanon">policy of attacks</a> against Israel. In the next few years, the PLO infiltrated the south and kept up a sporadic shelling across the border. Israel carried out numerous retaliatory attacks by air and on the ground.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg/220px-View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg/330px-View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg/440px-View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:View_from_Tayelet_during_Snow_07.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Israel's 1980 <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">law</a> declared that "<a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, complete and united, is the capital of Israel."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[245]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Meanwhile, Begin's government provided incentives for Israelis to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_settlements" title="Israeli settlements">settle</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Israeli occupation of the West Bank">occupied West Bank</a>, increasing friction with the Palestinians in that area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[246]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Basic Law: Jerusalem, Capital of Israel</a>, passed in 1980, was believed by some to reaffirm Israel's 1967 annexation of Jerusalem by government decree, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council_Resolution_478" title="UN Security Council Resolution 478">reignited international controversy</a> over the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">status of the city</a>. No Israeli legislation has defined the territory of Israel and no act specifically included East Jerusalem therein.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[247]</a></sup> In 1981 Israel <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights_Law" title="Golan Heights Law">effectively annexed</a> the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>, although annexation was not recognized internationally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_golan_profile_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc_golan_profile-255">[248]</a></sup> The international community largely rejected these moves, with the UN Security Council declaring both the Jerusalem Law and the Golan Heights Law null and void.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[250]</a></sup> Israel's population diversity expanded in the 1980s and 1990s. Several waves of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Jews" title="Ethiopian Jews">Ethiopian Jews</a> <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_from_Ethiopia" title="Aliyah from Ethiopia">immigrated</a> to Israel since the 1980s, while between 1990 and 1994, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">immigration from the post-Soviet states</a> increased Israel's population by twelve percent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[251]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 7 June 1981, during the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War" title="Iran–Iraq War">Iran–Iraq War</a>, the Israeli air force <a href="/wiki/Operation_Opera" title="Operation Opera">destroyed</a> Iraq's sole <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Osirak" title="Osirak">nuclear reactor</a> under construction just outside <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, in order to impede Iraq's nuclear weapons program. Following a series of PLO attacks in 1982, Israel <a href="/wiki/1982_Lebanon_War" title="1982 Lebanon War">invaded</a> Lebanon that year to destroy the bases from which the PLO launched attacks and missiles into northern Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002199_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002199-259">[252]</a></sup> In the first six days of fighting, the Israelis destroyed the military forces of the PLO in Lebanon and decisively defeated the Syrians. An Israeli government inquiry—the <a href="/wiki/Kahan_Commission" title="Kahan Commission">Kahan Commission</a>—would later hold Begin and several Israeli generals as indirectly responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Sabra_and_Shatila_massacre" title="Sabra and Shatila massacre">Sabra and Shatila massacre</a> and hold <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Defense_Minister_of_Israel" title="Defense Minister of Israel">Defense minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Ariel_Sharon" title="Ariel Sharon">Ariel Sharon</a> as bearing "personal responsibility" for the massacre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[253]</a></sup> Sharon was forced to resign as Defense Minister.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[254]</a></sup> In 1985, Israel responded to a Palestinian <a href="/wiki/Larnaca_yacht_killings" title="Larnaca yacht killings">terrorist attack</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> by <a href="/wiki/Operation_Wooden_Leg" title="Operation Wooden Leg">bombing</a> the PLO headquarters in Tunisia. Israel withdrew from most of Lebanon in 1986, but maintained a <a href="/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_Southern_Lebanon" title="Israeli occupation of Southern Lebanon">borderland buffer zone</a> in southern Lebanon until 2000, from where Israeli forces <a href="/wiki/South_Lebanon_conflict_(1985%E2%80%932000)" title="South Lebanon conflict (1985–2000)">engaged in conflict</a> with <a href="/wiki/Hezbollah" title="Hezbollah">Hezbollah</a>. The <a href="/wiki/First_Intifada" title="First Intifada">First Intifada</a>, a Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[255]</a></sup> broke out in 1987, with waves of uncoordinated demonstrations and violence occurring in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Over the following six years, the Intifada became more organized and included economic and cultural measures aimed at disrupting the Israeli occupation. More than a thousand people were killed in the violence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[256]</a></sup> During the 1991 <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a>, the PLO supported <a href="/wiki/Saddam_Hussein" title="Saddam Hussein">Saddam Hussein</a> and Iraqi Scud missile <a href="/wiki/Iraqi_rocket_attacks_on_Israel" title="Iraqi rocket attacks on Israel">attacks against Israel</a>. Despite public outrage, Israel heeded American calls to refrain from hitting back and did not participate in that war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[257]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[258]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_(GPO)_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2021" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg/220px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg/330px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg/440px-Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_%28GPO%29_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Government_Press_Office_(GPO)_-_Foreign_Min._Peres_and_King_Hussein.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shimon_Peres" title="Shimon Peres">Shimon Peres</a> (left) with <a href="/wiki/Yitzhak_Rabin" title="Yitzhak Rabin">Yitzhak Rabin</a> (center) and King <a href="/wiki/Hussein_of_Jordan" title="Hussein of Jordan">Hussein of Jordan</a> (right), prior to signing the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_peace_treaty" title="Israel–Jordan peace treaty">Israel–Jordan peace treaty</a> in 1994.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1992, <a href="/wiki/Yitzhak_Rabin" title="Yitzhak Rabin">Yitzhak Rabin</a> became prime minister following <a href="/wiki/1992_Israeli_legislative_election" title="1992 Israeli legislative election">an election</a> in which his party called for compromise with Israel's neighbors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002236_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002236-266">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[260]</a></sup> The following year, <a href="/wiki/Shimon_Peres" title="Shimon Peres">Shimon Peres</a> on behalf of Israel, and <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Abbas" title="Mahmoud Abbas">Mahmoud Abbas</a> for the PLO, signed the <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Accords" title="Oslo Accords">Oslo Accords</a>, which gave the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian National Authority</a> the right to govern <a href="/wiki/West_Bank_Areas_in_the_Oslo_II_Accord" title="West Bank Areas in the Oslo II Accord">parts of the West Bank</a> and the Gaza Strip.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[261]</a></sup> The PLO also <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Palestine_Liberation_Organization_letters_of_recognition" title="Israel–Palestine Liberation Organization letters of recognition">recognized</a> Israel's right to exist and pledged an end to terrorism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[262]</a></sup> In 1994, the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_peace_treaty" title="Israel–Jordan peace treaty">Israel–Jordan peace treaty</a> was signed, making Jordan the second Arab country to normalize relations with Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[263]</a></sup> Arab public support for the Accords was damaged by the continuation of Israeli settlements<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[264]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_checkpoint" title="Israeli checkpoint">checkpoints</a>, and the deterioration of economic conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[265]</a></sup> Israeli public support for the Accords waned as Israel was struck by <a href="/wiki/List_of_Palestinian_suicide_attacks" title="List of Palestinian suicide attacks">Palestinian suicide attacks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[266]</a></sup> In November 1995, Yitzhak Rabin <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Yitzhak_Rabin" title="Assassination of Yitzhak Rabin">was assassinated</a> as he left a peace rally by <a href="/wiki/Yigal_Amir" title="Yigal Amir">Yigal Amir</a>, a far-right Jew who opposed the Accords.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[267]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG/330px-PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG/440px-PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_19099_ruins_of_tel_aviv_dolphinarium.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The site of the 2001 Tel Aviv <a href="/wiki/Dolphinarium_discotheque_massacre" title="Dolphinarium discotheque massacre">Dolphinarium discotheque massacre</a>, in which 21 Israelis were killed.</div></div></div>
<p>Under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu" title="Benjamin Netanyahu">Benjamin Netanyahu</a> at the end of the 1990s, Israel <a href="/wiki/Protocol_Concerning_the_Redeployment_in_Hebron" title="Protocol Concerning the Redeployment in Hebron">withdrew</a> from <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002257_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002257-275">[268]</a></sup> and signed the <a href="/wiki/Wye_River_Memorandum" title="Wye River Memorandum">Wye River Memorandum</a>, giving greater control to the Palestinian National Authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[269]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ehud_Barak" title="Ehud Barak">Ehud Barak</a>, <a href="/wiki/1999_Israeli_general_election" title="1999 Israeli general election">elected</a> Prime Minister in 1999, began the new millennium by withdrawing forces from Southern Lebanon and conducting negotiations with Palestinian Authority Chairman <a href="/wiki/Yasser_Arafat" title="Yasser Arafat">Yasser Arafat</a> and U.S. President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2000_Camp_David_Summit" title="2000 Camp David Summit">2000 Camp David Summit</a>. During the summit, Barak offered a plan for the establishment of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_state" title="Palestinian state">Palestinian state</a>. The proposed state included the entirety of the Gaza Strip and over 90% of the West Bank with Jerusalem as a shared capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[270]</a></sup> Each side blamed the other for the failure of the talks. After a controversial visit by Likud leader <a href="/wiki/Ariel_Sharon" title="Ariel Sharon">Ariel Sharon</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Intifada" title="Second Intifada">Second Intifada</a> began. Some commentators contend that the uprising was pre-planned by Arafat due to the collapse of peace talks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[272]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jewishweek_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-jewishweek-280">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-atlantic_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-atlantic-281">[274]</a></sup> Sharon became prime minister in a <a href="/wiki/2001_Israeli_prime_ministerial_election" title="2001 Israeli prime ministerial election">2001 special election</a>. During his tenure, Sharon carried out his plan to <a href="/wiki/Israeli_disengagement_from_Gaza" title="Israeli disengagement from Gaza">unilaterally withdraw</a> from the Gaza Strip and also spearheaded the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier" title="Israeli West Bank barrier">Israeli West Bank barrier</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[275]</a></sup> ending the Intifada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rage_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-rage-283">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[277]</a></sup> Between 2000 and 2008, 1,063 Israelis, 5,517 Palestinians and 64 foreign citizens had been killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2006, a Hezbollah artillery assault on Israel's northern border communities and a <a href="/wiki/2006_Hezbollah_cross-border_raid" title="2006 Hezbollah cross-border raid">cross-border abduction</a> of two Israeli soldiers precipitated the month-long <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Lebanon_War" title="Second Lebanon War">Second Lebanon War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN1701_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN1701-286">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HRTZ_Harel_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-HRTZ_Harel-287">[280]</a></sup> On 6 September 2007, the Israeli Air Force <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Orchard" title="Operation Orchard">destroyed</a> a nuclear reactor in Syria. At the end of 2008, Israel entered another conflict as <a href="/wiki/2008_Israel%E2%80%93Hamas_ceasefire" title="2008 Israel–Hamas ceasefire">a ceasefire</a> between <a href="/wiki/Hamas" title="Hamas">Hamas</a> and Israel collapsed. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaza_War_(2008%E2%80%9309)" title="Gaza War (2008–09)">2008–09 Gaza War</a> lasted three weeks and ended after Israel announced a unilateral ceasefire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ravid_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-ravid-289">[282]</a></sup> Hamas announced its own ceasefire, with its own conditions of complete withdrawal and opening of <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip" title="Blockade of the Gaza Strip">border crossings</a>. Despite neither the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel" title="Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel">rocket launchings</a> nor Israeli <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_attacks_on_the_Gaza_strip" title="List of Israeli attacks on the Gaza strip">retaliatory strikes</a> having completely stopped, the fragile ceasefire remained in order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[283]</a></sup> In what Israel described as a response to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel,_2012" title="List of Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel, 2012">more than a hundred Palestinian rocket attacks</a> on southern Israeli cities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pound_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-pound-291">[284]</a></sup> Israel began an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Pillar_of_Defense" title="Operation Pillar of Defense">operation</a> in Gaza on 14 November 2012, lasting eight days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[285]</a></sup> Israel started another <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Protective_Edge" title="Operation Protective Edge">operation</a> in Gaza following an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel,_2014" title="List of Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel, 2014">escalation of rocket attacks</a> by Hamas in July 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[286]</a></sup> In May 2021, another <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls" title="Operation Guardian of the Walls">round of fighting</a> took place in Gaza and Israel, lasting eleven days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[287]</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2010, Israel was invited to join the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-40">[34]</a></sup> Israel has also signed <a href="/wiki/Free_trade_agreement" title="Free trade agreement">free trade agreements</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Israel–United States Free Trade Agreement">United States</a>, the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">European Free Trade Association</a>, Turkey, Mexico, <a href="/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93Israel_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Canada–Israel Free Trade Agreement">Canada</a>, Jordan, and Egypt, and in 2007, it became the first non-Latin-American country to sign a free trade agreement with the <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosur</a> trade bloc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[289]</a></sup> By the 2010s, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_states%E2%80%93Israeli_alliance_against_Iran" title="Arab states–Israeli alliance against Iran">increasing regional cooperation</a> between Israel and <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> countries, with many of whom peace agreements (Jordan, Egypt) diplomatic relations (UAE, Palestine) and unofficial relations (Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Morocco, Tunisia), have been established, the Israeli security situation shifted from the traditional <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab–Israeli conflict">Arab–Israeli hostility</a> towards regional rivalry with <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> and its proxies. The <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict" title="Iran–Israel proxy conflict">Iran–Israel proxy conflict</a> gradually emerged from the declared hostility of post-revolutionary Islamic Republic of Iran towards Israel since the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1979_Revolution" title="1979 Revolution">1979 Revolution</a>, into covert Iranian support of Hezbollah during the <a href="/wiki/South_Lebanon_conflict_(1985%E2%80%932000)" title="South Lebanon conflict (1985–2000)">South Lebanon conflict (1985–2000)</a> and essentially developed into a proxy regional conflict from 2005. With increasing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_involvement_in_the_Syrian_Civil_War" title="Iranian involvement in the Syrian Civil War">Iranian involvement in the Syrian Civil War</a> from 2011 the conflict shifted from proxy warfare into direct confrontation by early 2018.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography_and_environment">Geography and environment</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Israel" title="Geography of Israel">Geography of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Israel" title="Wildlife of Israel">Wildlife of Israel</a></div>
<div class="floatright noresize" role="img" style="width: 220px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><img alt="" data-file-height="1141" data-file-width="614" decoding="async" height="409" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Israel_relief_location_map.jpg/220px-Israel_relief_location_map.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Israel_relief_location_map.jpg/330px-Israel_relief_location_map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Israel_relief_location_map.jpg/440px-Israel_relief_location_map.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
<div style="position:absolute; left:0.6px; top:7.4px"><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Israel" title="Geography of Israel">Geography of Israel</a></div>
