</tbody></table></div><p><small><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1041539562" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_jerusalem"><b><a href="#ref_jerusalem">^a</a></b> This number includes <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a> areas, which had a total population of 573,330 inhabitants in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[355]</a></sup> Israeli sovereignty over East Jerusalem is <a href="/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem" title="Status of Jerusalem">internationally unrecognized</a>.</span> </small>
</p><h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Israel" title="Languages of Israel">Languages of Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_(3777232251).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg/220px-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg/330px-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg/440px-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_%283777232251%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%98_%D7%A8%D7%97%D7%95%D7%91_%D7%99%D7%94%D7%95%D7%93%D7%94_(3777232251).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Road_signs_in_Israel" title="Road signs in Israel">Road sign</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a></div></div></div>
<p>Israel has one official language, <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>. Until 2018, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language_in_Israel" title="Arabic language in Israel">Arabic</a> was also one of two official languages of the State of Israel;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang1_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-lang1-11">[9]</a></sup> in 2018 <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law:_Israel_as_the_Nation-State_of_the_Jewish_People" title="Basic Law: Israel as the Nation-State of the Jewish People">it was downgraded</a> to having a 'special status in the state' with its use by state institutions to be set in law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang2_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-lang2-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang3_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-lang3-13">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang4_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-lang4-14">[12]</a></sup> Hebrew is the primary language of the state and is spoken every day by the majority of the population. Arabic is spoken by the Arab minority, with Hebrew taught in Arab schools.
</p><p>As a country of <a href="/wiki/Aliyah" title="Aliyah">immigrants</a>, many languages can be heard on the streets. Due to mass immigration from the former Soviet Union and <a href="/wiki/Aliyah_from_Ethiopia" title="Aliyah from Ethiopia">Ethiopia</a> (some 130,000 <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Jews_in_Israel" title="Ethiopian Jews in Israel">Ethiopian Jews live in Israel</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Ethiopian_Population_In_Israel_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Ethiopian_Population_In_Israel-363">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[357]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_in_Israel" title="Russian language in Israel">Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a> are widely spoken.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[358]</a></sup> More than one million Russian-speaking immigrants <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">arrived</a> in Israel from the post-Soviet states between 1990 and 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[359]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> is spoken by around 700,000 Israelis,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[360]</a></sup> mostly originating <a href="/wiki/French_Jews_in_Israel" title="French Jews in Israel">from France</a> and North Africa (see <a href="/wiki/Maghrebi_Jews" title="Maghrebi Jews">Maghrebi Jews</a>). <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> was an official language during the Mandate period; it lost this status after the establishment of Israel, but retains a role comparable to that of an official language,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[362]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[363]</a></sup> as may be seen in <a href="/wiki/Road_signs_in_Israel" title="Road signs in Israel">road signs</a> and official documents. Many Israelis communicate reasonably well in English, as many television programs are broadcast in English with <a href="/wiki/Subtitles" title="Subtitles">subtitles</a> and the language is taught from the early grades in elementary school. In addition, Israeli universities offer courses in the English language on various subjects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[364]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Israel" title="Religion in Israel">Religion in Israel</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1034237262">.mw-parser-output .stack{box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .stack>div{margin:1px;overflow:hidden}@media all and (min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .stack-clear-left{float:left;clear:left}.mw-parser-output .stack-clear-right{float:right;clear:right}.mw-parser-output .stack-left{float:left}.mw-parser-output .stack-right{float:right}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-clear-left{float:left;clear:left;margin-right:1em}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-clear-right{float:right;clear:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-left{float:left;margin-right:1em}.mw-parser-output .stack-margin-right{float:right;margin-left:1em}}</style><div class="stack stack-right"><div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1045256916">.mw-parser-output .navbar-header{text-align:center;position:relative;white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .navbar-header .navbar{position:absolute;right:0;top:0;margin:0 5px}</style><div class="navbar-header"><a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Israel" title="Religion in Israel">Religion in Israel</a><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Religion_in_Israel_chart" title="Template:Religion in Israel chart"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Religion_in_Israel_chart" title="Template talk:Religion in Israel chart"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Religion_in_Israel_chart&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></div>
<div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1039153519">@media all and (max-width:720px){body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .mw-graph{min-width:100%!important;max-width:100%;overflow-x:auto;overflow-y:visible}}.mw-parser-output .mw-graph-img{width:inherit;height:inherit}</style><div class="mw-graph mw-graph-always mw-graph-nofallback" data-graph-id="9f2bcef95078c90c5945901c386b588868e567cb" style="min-width:220px;min-height:150px"></div></div>
<div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:navy; color:navy;">    </span> <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Jews" title="Israeli Jews">Jewish</a></span> <b>·</b> <span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:green; color:green;">    </span> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Israel" title="Islam in Israel">Muslim</a></span> <b>·</b> <span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:red; color:red;">    </span> <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Israel" title="Christianity in Israel">Christian</a></span> <b>·</b> <span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:black; color:black;">    </span> <a href="/wiki/Druze_in_Israel" title="Druze in Israel">Druze</a></span> <b>·</b> <span style="margin:0px; font-size:90%;"><span style="border:none; background-color:gray; color:gray;">    </span> <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Israel" title="Religion in Israel">Other</a></span>.<br/>
Until 1995, figures for Christians also included Others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[365]</a></sup></div>
</div></div>
<p>Israel comprises a major part of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a>, a region of significant importance to all <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samaritanism" title="Samaritanism">Samaritanism</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze Faith</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí Faith</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Jewish_religious_movements" title="Jewish religious movements">religious affiliation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Jews" title="Israeli Jews">Israeli Jews</a> varies widely: a social survey from 2016 made by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pew_Research" title="Pew Research">Pew Research</a> indicates that 49% self-identify as <a href="/wiki/Hiloni" title="Hiloni">Hiloni</a> (secular), 29% as <a href="/wiki/Masortim" title="Masortim">Masorti</a> (traditional), 13% as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dati" title="Dati">Dati</a> (religious) and 9% as <a href="/wiki/Haredi_Judaism" title="Haredi Judaism">Haredi</a> (ultra-Orthodox).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[366]</a></sup> Haredi Jews are expected to represent more than 20% of Israel's Jewish population by 2028.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[367]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Israel" title="Islam in Israel">Muslims</a> constitute Israel's largest religious minority, making up about 17.6% of the population. About 2% of the population is <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Israel" title="Christianity in Israel">Christian</a> and 1.6% is <a href="/wiki/Druze_in_Israel" title="Druze in Israel">Druze</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_297-1"><a href="#cite_note-cia-297">[290]</a></sup> The Christian population is composed primarily of <a href="/wiki/Arab_Christians" title="Arab Christians">Arab Christians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arameans_in_Israel" title="Arameans in Israel">Aramean Christians</a>, but also includes post-Soviet immigrants, the foreign laborers of multinational origins, and followers of <a href="/wiki/Messianic_Judaism" title="Messianic Judaism">Messianic Judaism</a>, considered by most Christians and Jews to be a form of Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[368]</a></sup> Members of many other religious groups, including <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Israel" title="Hinduism in Israel">Hindus</a>, maintain a presence in Israel, albeit in small numbers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[369]</a></sup> Out of more than one million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">immigrants</a> from the former Soviet Union, about 300,000 are considered not Jewish by the <a href="/wiki/Chief_Rabbinate_of_Israel" title="Chief Rabbinate of Israel">Chief Rabbinate of Israel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[370]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Westernwall2.jpg"><img alt="A large open area with people bounded by old stone walls. To the left is a mosque with large golden dome." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Westernwall2.jpg/220px-Westernwall2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Westernwall2.jpg/330px-Westernwall2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Westernwall2.jpg/440px-Westernwall2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Westernwall2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Dome_of_the_Rock" title="Dome of the Rock">Dome of the Rock</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a>, Jerusalem.</div></div></div>
<p>The city of <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> is of <a href="/wiki/Religious_significance_of_Jerusalem" title="Religious significance of Jerusalem">special importance</a> to Jews, Muslims, and Christians, as it is the home of <a href="/wiki/List_of_places_in_Jerusalem" title="List of places in Jerusalem">sites</a> that are pivotal to their religious beliefs, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_City_(Jerusalem)" title="Old City (Jerusalem)">Old City</a> that incorporates the <a href="/wiki/Western_Wall" title="Western Wall">Western Wall</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Temple_Mount" title="Temple Mount">Temple Mount</a> (Al-Aqsa Mosque compound) and the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Sepulchre" title="Church of the Holy Sepulchre">Church of the Holy Sepulchre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[371]</a></sup> Other locations of religious importance in Israel are <a href="/wiki/Nazareth" title="Nazareth">Nazareth</a> (holy in Christianity as the site of the <a href="/wiki/Annunciation" title="Annunciation">Annunciation</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mary_(mother_of_Jesus)" title="Mary (mother of Jesus)">Mary</a>), <a href="/wiki/Tiberias" title="Tiberias">Tiberias</a> and <a href="/wiki/Safed" title="Safed">Safed</a> (two of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Holy_Cities" title="Four Holy Cities">Four Holy Cities</a> in Judaism), the <a href="/wiki/White_Mosque,_Ramla" title="White Mosque, Ramla">White Mosque</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ramla" title="Ramla">Ramla</a> (holy in Islam as the shrine of the prophet <a href="/wiki/Salih" title="Salih">Saleh</a>), and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Church_of_Saint_George,_Lod" title="Church of Saint George, Lod">Church of Saint George</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lod" title="Lod">Lod</a> (holy in Christianity and Islam as the tomb of <a href="/wiki/Saint_George" title="Saint George">Saint George</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Al_Khidr" title="Al Khidr">Al Khidr</a>). A number of other religious landmarks are located in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, among them <a href="/wiki/Joseph%27s_Tomb" title="Joseph's Tomb">Joseph's Tomb</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nablus" title="Nablus">Nablus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Nativity" title="Church of the Nativity">birthplace of Jesus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rachel%27s_Tomb" title="Rachel's Tomb">Rachel's Tomb</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem" title="Bethlehem">Bethlehem</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Cave_of_the_Patriarchs" title="Cave of the Patriarchs">Cave of the Patriarchs</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hebron" title="Hebron">Hebron</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arc_(Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD)" title="Arc (Baháʼí)">administrative center</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí Faith</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_B%C3%A1b" title="Shrine of the Báb">Shrine of the Báb</a> are located at the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_World_Centre" title="Baháʼí World Centre">Baháʼí World Centre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a>; the leader of the faith is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shrine_of_Bah%C3%A1%27u%27ll%C3%A1h" title="Shrine of Bahá'u'lláh">buried</a> in <a href="/wiki/Acre,_Israel" title="Acre, Israel">Acre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[372]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[374]</a></sup> A few kilometres south of the Baháʼí World Centre is <a href="/wiki/Mahmood_Mosque,_Haifa" title="Mahmood Mosque, Haifa">Mahmood Mosque</a> affiliated with the reformist <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya_in_Israel" title="Ahmadiyya in Israel">Ahmadiyya</a> movement. <a href="/wiki/Kababir" title="Kababir">Kababir</a>, Haifa's mixed neighbourhood of Jews and Ahmadi Arabs is one of a few of its kind in the country, others being <a href="/wiki/Jaffa" title="Jaffa">Jaffa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Acre,_Israel" title="Acre, Israel">Acre</a>, other <a href="/wiki/Haifa" title="Haifa">Haifa</a> neighborhoods, <a href="/wiki/Harish,_Israel" title="Harish, Israel">Harish</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upper_Nazareth" title="Upper Nazareth">Upper Nazareth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[376]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Israel" title="Education in Israel">Education in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="463" data-file-width="700" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg/220px-Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg/330px-Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg/440px-Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brain_research_labs-Bar_Ilan_university.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bar-Ilan_University#Leslie_and_Susan_Gonda_Multidisciplinary_Brain_Research_Center" title="Bar-Ilan University">Multidisciplinary Brain Research Center</a> at <a href="/wiki/Bar-Ilan_University" title="Bar-Ilan University">Bar-Ilan University</a></div></div></div>
<p>Education is highly valued in the Israeli culture and was viewed as a <a href="/wiki/History_of_education_in_ancient_Israel_and_Judah" title="History of education in ancient Israel and Judah">fundamental block of ancient Israelites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[377]</a></sup> Jewish communities in the Levant were the first to introduce <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory education</a> for which the organized community, not less than the parents was responsible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[378]</a></sup> Many international business leaders such as Microsoft founder <a href="/wiki/Bill_Gates" title="Bill Gates">Bill Gates</a> have praised Israel for its high quality of education in helping spur Israel's economic development and technological boom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-David_Adler_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-David_Adler-386">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[381]</a></sup> In 2015, the country <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_tertiary_education_attainment" title="List of countries by tertiary education attainment">ranked</a> third among <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> members (after Canada and Japan) for the percentage of 25–64 year-olds that have attained <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary education</a> with 49% compared with the OECD average of 35%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_education_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_education-389">[382]</a></sup> In 2012, the country ranked third in the world in the number of academic degrees per capita (20 percent of the population).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-consulate_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-consulate-390">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[384]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel has a <a href="/wiki/School_life_expectancy" title="School life expectancy">school life expectancy</a> of 16 years and a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_literacy_rate" title="List of countries by literacy rate">literacy rate</a> of 97.8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_297-2"><a href="#cite_note-cia-297">[290]</a></sup> The State Education Law, passed in 1953, established five types of schools: state secular, state religious, ultra orthodox, communal settlement schools, and Arab schools. The public secular is the largest school group, and is attended by the majority of Jewish and non-Arab pupils in Israel. Most Arabs send their children to schools where Arabic is the language of instruction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[385]</a></sup> Education is compulsory in Israel for children between the ages of three and eighteen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[387]</a></sup> Schooling is divided into three tiers – primary school (grades 1–6), <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">middle school</a> (grades 7–9), and high school (grades 10–12) – culminating with <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bagrut" title="Bagrut">Bagrut</a></i> matriculation exams. Proficiency in core subjects such as mathematics, the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew language</a>, Hebrew and general literature, the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English language</a>, history, Biblical scripture and civics is necessary to receive a Bagrut certificate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-moia_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-moia-395">[388]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel's Jewish population maintains a relatively high level of educational attainment where just under half of all Israeli Jews (46%) hold post-secondary degrees. This figure has remained stable in their already high levels of educational attainment over recent generations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[390]</a></sup> Israeli Jews (among those ages 25 and older) have average of 11.6 years of schooling making them one of the most highly educated of all major religious groups in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[391]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[392]</a></sup> In Arab, Christian and <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> schools, the exam on Biblical studies is replaced by an exam on Muslim, Christian or Druze heritage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[393]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Maariv_(newspaper)" title="Maariv (newspaper)">Maariv</a></i> described the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Arabs" title="Christian Arabs">Christian Arabs</a> sectors as "the most successful in education system",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-המגזר_הערבי_נוצרי_הכי_מצליח_במערכת_החינוך_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-המגזר_הערבי_נוצרי_הכי_מצליח_במערכת_החינוך-401">[394]</a></sup> since Christians fared the best in terms of education in comparison to any other religion in Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Christians_in_Israel:_Strong_in_education_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-Christians_in_Israel:_Strong_in_education-402">[395]</a></sup> Israeli children from Russian-speaking families have a higher bagrut pass rate at high-school level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[396]</a></sup> Amongst immigrant children born in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Former_Soviet_Union" title="Former Soviet Union">former Soviet Union</a>, the bagrut pass rate is higher amongst those families from European FSU states at 62.6% and lower amongst those from Central Asian and Caucasian FSU states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[397]</a></sup> In 2014, 61.5% of all Israeli twelfth graders earned a matriculation certificate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG/220px-Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG/330px-Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG/440px-Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hebrew_University_Jerusalem_IL_WV.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mount_Scopus" title="Mount Scopus">Mount Scopus</a> Campus of the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a></div></div></div>
<p>Israel has a tradition of higher education where its quality university education has been largely responsible in spurring the nation's modern economic development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[399]</a></sup> Israel has <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_universities_and_colleges" title="List of Israeli universities and colleges">nine public universities that are subsidized by the state and 49 private colleges</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-moia_395-1"><a href="#cite_note-moia-395">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[401]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a>, Israel's second-oldest university after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technion" title="Technion">Technion</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[403]</a></sup> houses the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel" title="National Library of Israel">National Library of Israel</a>, the world's largest repository of Judaica and Hebraica.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[404]</a></sup> The Technion and the Hebrew University consistently ranked among world's 100 top universities by the prestigious <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">ARWU</a> academic ranking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARWU_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-ARWU-412">[405]</a></sup> Other major universities in the country include the <a href="/wiki/Weizmann_Institute_of_Science" title="Weizmann Institute of Science">Weizmann Institute of Science</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University" title="Tel Aviv University">Tel Aviv University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben-Gurion_University_of_the_Negev" title="Ben-Gurion University of the Negev">Ben-Gurion University of the Negev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bar-Ilan_University" title="Bar-Ilan University">Bar-Ilan University</a>, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Haifa" title="University of Haifa">University of Haifa</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Open_University_of_Israel" title="Open University of Israel">Open University of Israel</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ariel_University" title="Ariel University">Ariel University</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, is the newest university institution, upgraded from college status, and the first in over thirty years.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Israel" title="Politics of Israel">Politics of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_system_of_government" title="Israeli system of government">Israeli system of government</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Criticism_of_the_Israeli_government" title="Criticism of the Israeli government">Criticism of the Israeli government</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:252px;max-width:252px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:127px;max-width:127px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:166px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Isaac_Herzog.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="750" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Isaac_Herzog.jpg/125px-Isaac_Herzog.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Isaac_Herzog.jpg/188px-Isaac_Herzog.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Isaac_Herzog.jpg/250px-Isaac_Herzog.jpg 2x" width="125"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">President</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Isaac_Herzog" title="Isaac Herzog">Isaac Herzog</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:121px;max-width:121px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:166px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yair_Lapid_February_2022.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1066" data-file-width="759" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Yair_Lapid_February_2022.jpg/119px-Yair_Lapid_February_2022.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Yair_Lapid_February_2022.jpg/179px-Yair_Lapid_February_2022.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Yair_Lapid_February_2022.jpg/238px-Yair_Lapid_February_2022.jpg 2x" width="119"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel" title="Prime Minister of Israel">Prime Minister</a><br/><a href="/wiki/Yair_Lapid" title="Yair Lapid">Yair Lapid</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg/220px-PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg/330px-PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg/440px-PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PikiWiki_Israel_7260_Knesset-Room.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a> chamber, home to the Israeli parliament</div></div></div>
<p>Israel is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">parliamentary democracy</a> with <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>. A member of parliament supported by a parliamentary majority becomes the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Israel" title="Prime Minister of Israel">prime minister</a>—usually this is the chair of the largest party. The prime minister is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> and head of the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel" title="Cabinet of Israel">cabinet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia2_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia2-413">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[407]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel is governed by a 120-member parliament, known as the <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">Knesset</a>. Membership of the Knesset is based on <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a> of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Israel" title="List of political parties in Israel">political parties</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[408]</a></sup> with a 3.25% electoral threshold, which in practice has resulted in coalition governments. Residents of Israeli settlements in the West Bank are eligible to vote<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[409]</a></sup> and after the <a href="/wiki/2015_Israeli_legislative_election" title="2015 Israeli legislative election">2015 election</a>, 10 of the 120 MKs (<span data-sort-value="7000833333333333333♠" style="display:none"></span>8%) were settlers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[410]</a></sup> Parliamentary <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Israel" title="Elections in Israel">elections</a> are scheduled every four years, but unstable coalitions or a <a href="/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence" title="Motion of no confidence">no-confidence vote</a> by the Knesset can dissolve a government earlier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cnn_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-cnn-39">[33]</a></sup> The first Arab-led party was established in 1988 and the main Arab bloc, the <a href="/wiki/Joint_List" title="Joint List">Joint List</a>, holds about 10% of the parliament's seats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[411]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:311px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Israel%27s_political_system.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="616" data-file-width="813" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Israel%27s_political_system.svg/309px-Israel%27s_political_system.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Israel%27s_political_system.svg/464px-Israel%27s_political_system.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Israel%27s_political_system.svg/618px-Israel%27s_political_system.svg.png 2x" width="309"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Israel%27s_political_system.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Political system of state of Israel</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Basic_Laws_of_Israel" title="Basic Laws of Israel">Basic Laws of Israel</a> function as an <a href="/wiki/Uncodified_constitution" title="Uncodified constitution">uncodified constitution</a>. In 2003, the Knesset began to draft an official <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Israel" title="Constitution of Israel">constitution</a> based on these laws.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_297-3"><a href="#cite_note-cia-297">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[412]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">president of Israel</a> is <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, with limited and largely ceremonial duties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia2_413-1"><a href="#cite_note-cia2-413">[406]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel has no official religion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[415]</a></sup> but the definition of the state as "<a href="/wiki/Jewish_and_democratic_state" title="Jewish and democratic state">Jewish and democratic</a>" creates a strong connection with Judaism, as well as a conflict between state law and religious law. Interaction between the political parties keeps <a href="/wiki/Status_quo_(Israel)" title="Status quo (Israel)">the balance</a> between state and religion largely as it existed during the British Mandate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 19 July 2018, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_Parliament" title="Israeli Parliament">Israeli Parliament</a> passed a Basic Law that characterizes the State of Israel as principally a "<a href="/wiki/Basic_Law:_Israel_as_the_Nation-State_of_the_Jewish_People" title="Basic Law: Israel as the Nation-State of the Jewish People">Nation State of the Jewish People</a>," and Hebrew as its official language. The bill ascribes "special status" to the Arabic language. The same bill gives Jews a unique right to national self-determination, and views the developing of Jewish settlement in the country as "a national interest," empowering the government to "take steps to encourage, advance and implement this interest."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[417]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_system">Legal system</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Israel" title="Judiciary of Israel">Judiciary of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_law" title="Israeli law">Israeli law</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2767" data-file-width="4217" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/220px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/330px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg/440px-Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Israel_Supreme_Court.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel" title="Supreme Court of Israel">Supreme Court of Israel</a>, Givat Ram, Jerusalem</div></div></div>
<p>Israel has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_judicial_system" title="Israeli judicial system">three-tier court system</a>. At the lowest level are <a href="/wiki/Magistrate" title="Magistrate">magistrate</a> courts, situated in most cities across the country. Above them are <a href="/wiki/District_court" title="District court">district courts</a>, serving as both <a href="/wiki/Appeal" title="Appeal">appellate</a> courts and <a href="/wiki/Trial_court" title="Trial court">courts of first instance</a>; they are situated in five of Israel's six <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">districts</a>. The third and highest tier is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Israel" title="Supreme Court of Israel">Supreme Court</a>, located in Jerusalem; it serves a dual role as the highest court of appeals and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justice_(Israel)" title="High Court of Justice (Israel)">High Court of Justice</a>. In the latter role, the Supreme Court rules as a court of first instance, allowing individuals, both citizens and non-citizens, to petition against the decisions of state authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-judiciary_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-judiciary-425">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[419]</a></sup> Although Israel supports the goals of the <a href="/wiki/International_Criminal_Court" title="International Criminal Court">International Criminal Court</a>, it has not ratified the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rome_Statute_of_the_International_Criminal_Court" title="Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court">Rome Statute</a>, citing concerns about the ability of the court to remain free from political impartiality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel's legal system combines three legal traditions: <a href="/wiki/English_law" title="English law">English</a> <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Halakha" title="Halakha">Jewish law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_297-4"><a href="#cite_note-cia-297">[290]</a></sup> It is based on the principle of <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stare_decisis" title="Stare decisis">stare decisis</a></i> (precedent) and is an <a href="/wiki/Adversarial_system" title="Adversarial system">adversarial system</a>, where the parties in the suit bring evidence before the court. Court cases are decided by professional judges with no role for juries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-judiciary_425-1"><a href="#cite_note-judiciary-425">[418]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marriage_in_Israel" title="Marriage in Israel">Marriage</a> and divorce are under the jurisdiction of the religious courts: <a href="/wiki/Beth_din" title="Beth din">Jewish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Muslim</a>, Druze, and Christian. The election of judges is carried out by a <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Selection_Committee_(Israel)" title="Judicial Selection Committee (Israel)">committee</a> of two Knesset members, three Supreme Court justices, two <a href="/wiki/Israel_Bar_Association" title="Israel Bar Association">Israeli Bar</a> members and two ministers (one of which, Israel's <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Justice (Israel)">justice minister</a>, is the committee's chairman). The committee's members of the Knesset are <a href="/wiki/Secret_ballot" title="Secret ballot">secretly elected</a> by the Knesset, and one of them is traditionally a member of the opposition, the committee's Supreme Court justices are chosen by tradition from all Supreme Court justices by seniority, the Israeli Bar members are elected by the bar, and the second minister is appointed by the Israeli cabinet. The current justice minister and committee's chairman is <a href="/wiki/Gideon_Sa%27ar" title="Gideon Sa'ar">Gideon Sa'ar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[422]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[423]</a></sup> Administration of Israel's courts (both the "General" courts and the <a href="/wiki/Labor_Courts_of_Israel" title="Labor Courts of Israel">Labor Courts</a>) is carried by the Administration of Courts, situated in Jerusalem. Both General and Labor courts are paperless courts: the storage of court files, as well as court decisions, are conducted electronically. Israel's <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law:_Human_Dignity_and_Liberty" title="Basic Law: Human Dignity and Liberty">Basic Law: Human Dignity and Liberty</a> seeks to defend <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Israel" title="Human rights in Israel">human rights and liberties in Israel</a>. As a result of "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Enclave_law" title="Enclave law">Enclave law</a>", large portions of Israeli <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> are applied to Israeli settlements and Israeli residents in the occupied territories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ben-NaftaliSfard2018_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ben-NaftaliSfard2018-431">[424]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">Districts of Israel</a></div>
<div class="floatright noresize" role="img" style="width: 220px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><img alt="" data-file-height="1141" data-file-width="614" decoding="async" height="409" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Israel_location_map.svg/220px-Israel_location_map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Israel_location_map.svg/330px-Israel_location_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Israel_location_map.svg/440px-Israel_location_map.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
<div style="position:absolute; left:0.6px; top:7.4px"><a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">Districts of Israel</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:126px; top:49.2px"><a href="/wiki/Northern_District_(Israel)" title="Northern District (Israel)">Northern</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:93px; top:69px"><a href="/wiki/Haifa_District" title="Haifa District">Haifa</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:73.2px; top:113px"><a href="/wiki/Central_District_(Israel)" title="Central District (Israel)">Central</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:55.6px; top:132.8px"><a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_District" title="Tel Aviv District">Tel Aviv</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:110.6px; top:108.6px"><a href="/wiki/Judea_and_Samaria_Area" title="Judea and Samaria Area">Judea<br/>and<br/>Samaria<br/>Area</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:86.4px; top:163.6px"><a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:75.4px; top:216.4px"><a href="/wiki/Southern_District_(Israel)" title="Southern District (Israel)">Southern</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; left:2.8px; top:388px"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Israel_Labelled_Map" title="Template:Israel Labelled Map"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Israel_Labelled_Map" title="Template talk:Israel Labelled Map"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Israel_Labelled_Map&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></div>
</div>
<p>The State of Israel is divided into six main administrative <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Israel" title="Districts of Israel">districts</a>, known as <i>mehozot</i> (Hebrew: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">מחוזות</span>; singular: <i>mahoz</i>) – <a href="/wiki/Central_District_(Israel)" title="Central District (Israel)">Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haifa_District" title="Haifa District">Haifa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_District" title="Jerusalem District">Jerusalem</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northern_District_(Israel)" title="Northern District (Israel)">North</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southern_District_(Israel)" title="Southern District (Israel)">South</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_District" title="Tel Aviv District">Tel Aviv</a> districts, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Judea_and_Samaria_Area" title="Judea and Samaria Area">Judea and Samaria Area</a> in the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>. All of the Judea and Samaria Area and parts of the Jerusalem and Northern districts are not recognized internationally as part of Israel. Districts are further divided into fifteen sub-districts known as <i>nafot</i> (Hebrew: <span dir="rtl" lang="he">נפות</span>; singular: <i>nafa</i>), which are themselves partitioned into fifty natural regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[425]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Israeli-occupied_territories">Israeli-occupied territories</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Israeli-occupied territories">Israeli-occupied territories</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Israeli occupation of the West Bank">Israeli occupation of the West Bank</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Israel,_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="721" data-file-width="559" decoding="async" height="387" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg/300px-Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg/450px-Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg/600px-Map_of_Israel%2C_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Israel,_neighbours_and_occupied_territories.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of Israel showing the West Bank, the Gaza Strip, and the Golan Heights</div></div></div>
<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1061467846">.mw-parser-output .navbox{box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #a2a9b1;width:100%;clear:both;font-size:88%;text-align:center;padding:1px;margin:1em auto 0}.mw-parser-output .navbox .navbox{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .navbox+.navbox,.mw-parser-output <td><a class="mw-selflink selflink">Israel</a>

</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In 1967, as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>, Israel captured and <a href="/wiki/Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Israeli-occupied territories">occupied</a> the <a href="/wiki/West_Bank" title="West Bank">West Bank</a>, including <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights" title="Golan Heights">Golan Heights</a>. Israel also captured the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a>, but returned it to Egypt as part of the 1979 <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_peace_treaty" title="Egypt–Israel peace treaty">Egypt–Israel peace treaty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002186–187_251-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002186–187-251">[244]</a></sup> Between 1982 and 2000, Israel occupied <a href="/wiki/Israeli_occupation_of_Southern_Lebanon" title="Israeli occupation of Southern Lebanon">part of southern Lebanon</a>, in what was known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Lebanon_Security_Belt" title="South Lebanon Security Belt">Security Belt</a>. Since Israel's capture of these territories, <a href="/wiki/Israeli_settlement" title="Israeli settlement">Israeli settlements</a> and military installations have been built within each of them, except Lebanon.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Golan_Heights_Law" title="Golan Heights Law">Golan Heights</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">East Jerusalem</a> have been fully incorporated into Israel under Israeli law, but not under international law. Israel has applied civilian law to both areas and granted their inhabitants permanent residency status and the ability to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_nationality_law" title="Israeli nationality law">apply for citizenship</a>. The UN Security Council has declared the annexation of the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem to be "null and void" and continues to view the territories as occupied.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[427]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Positions_on_Jerusalem" title="Positions on Jerusalem">status</a> of East Jerusalem in any future peace settlement has at times been a difficult issue in <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_peace_process" title="Israeli–Palestinian peace process">negotiations</a> between Israeli governments and representatives of the Palestinians, as Israel views it as its sovereign territory, as well as part of its capital.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="504" data-file-width="770" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG/220px-West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG/330px-West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG/440px-West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:West_Bank_Fence_South_Hebron.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier" title="Israeli West Bank barrier">Israeli West Bank barrier</a> is a separation barrier built by Israel along the Green Line and inside parts of the West Bank.</div></div></div>
<p>The West Bank excluding East Jerusalem is known in Israeli law as the <a href="/wiki/Judea_and_Samaria_Area" title="Judea and Samaria Area">Judea and Samaria Area</a>; the almost 400,000 Israeli settlers residing in the area are considered part of Israel's population, have Knesset representation, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Enclave_law" title="Enclave law">large part of Israel's civil and criminal laws</a> applied to them, and their output is considered part of Israel's economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sher_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sher-435">[428]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd_19-8"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-19">[fn 4]</a></sup> The land itself is not considered part of Israel under Israeli law, as Israel has consciously refrained from annexing the territory, without ever relinquishing its legal claim to the land or defining a border with the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sher_435-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sher-435">[428]</a></sup> There is no border between Israel-proper and the West Bank for Israeli vehicles. Israeli political opposition to annexation is primarily due to the perceived "demographic threat" of incorporating the West Bank's Palestinian population into Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sher_435-2"><a href="#cite_note-Sher-435">[428]</a></sup> Outside of the Israeli settlements, the West Bank remains under direct Israeli military rule, and Palestinians in the area cannot become Israeli citizens. The international community maintains that Israel does not have sovereignty in the West Bank, and considers Israel's control of the area to be the longest military occupation is modern history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-occhist_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-occhist-438">[431]</a></sup> The West Bank <a href="/wiki/Jordanian_annexation_of_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian annexation of the West Bank">was occupied and annexed</a> by Jordan in 1950, following the Arab rejection of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Partition_Plan_for_Palestine" title="United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine">UN decision</a> to create two states in Palestine. Only Britain recognized this annexation and Jordan has since <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jordanian_disengagement_from_the_West_Bank" title="Jordanian disengagement from the West Bank">ceded</a> its claim to the territory to the PLO. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Demographics_of_the_Palestinian_territories" title="Demographics of the Palestinian territories">population</a> are mainly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_people" title="Palestinian people">Palestinians</a>, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palestinian_refugee" title="Palestinian refugee">refugees</a> of the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[432]</a></sup> From their occupation in 1967 until 1993, the Palestinians living in these territories were under <a href="/wiki/Coordinator_of_Government_Activities_in_the_Territories" title="Coordinator of Government Activities in the Territories">Israeli military administration</a>. Since the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Palestine_Liberation_Organization_letters_of_recognition" title="Israel–Palestine Liberation Organization letters of recognition">Israel–PLO letters of recognition</a>, most of the Palestinian population and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_administered_by_the_State_of_Palestine" title="List of cities administered by the State of Palestine">cities</a> have been under the internal jurisdiction of the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_National_Authority" title="Palestinian National Authority">Palestinian Authority</a>, and only partial Israeli military control, although Israel has on several occasions redeployed its <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">troops</a> and reinstated full military administration during periods of unrest. In response to increasing attacks during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Intifada" title="Second Intifada">Second Intifada</a>, the Israeli government started to construct the Israeli West Bank barrier.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[433]</a></sup> When completed, approximately 13% of the barrier will be constructed on the <a href="/wiki/Green_Line_(Israel)" title="Green Line (Israel)">Green Line</a> or in Israel with 87% inside the West Bank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[435]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank,_Area_C.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="9295" data-file-width="6523" decoding="async" height="256" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank%2C_Area_C.png/180px-Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank%2C_Area_C.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank%2C_Area_C.png/270px-Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank%2C_Area_C.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank%2C_Area_C.png/360px-Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank%2C_Area_C.png 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Restricted_space_in_the_West_Bank,_Area_C.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Area_C_(West_Bank)" title="Area C (West Bank)">Area C</a> of the West Bank, controlled by Israel <a href="/wiki/West_Bank_Areas_in_the_Oslo_II_Accord" title="West Bank Areas in the Oslo II Accord">under Oslo Accords</a>, in blue and red, in December 2011</div></div></div>
<p>The Gaza Strip is considered to be a "foreign territory" under Israeli law; however, since Israel operates a land, air, and sea <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip" title="Blockade of the Gaza Strip">blockade of the Gaza Strip</a>, together with Egypt, the international community considers Israel to be the occupying power. The Gaza Strip was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Gaza_Strip_by_Egypt" title="Occupation of the Gaza Strip by Egypt">occupied by Egypt</a> from 1948 to 1967 and then by Israel after 1967. In 2005, as part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israel%27s_unilateral_disengagement_plan" title="Israel's unilateral disengagement plan">Israel's unilateral disengagement plan</a>, Israel removed all of its settlers and forces from the territory, however, it continues to maintain <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_the_Gaza_Strip" title="Blockade of the Gaza Strip">control</a> of its airspace and waters. The international community, including numerous international humanitarian organizations and various bodies of the UN, consider Gaza to remain occupied.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[440]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gaza_(2007)" title="Battle of Gaza (2007)">2007 Battle of Gaza</a>, when <a href="/wiki/Governance_of_the_Gaza_Strip" title="Governance of the Gaza Strip">Hamas assumed power in the Gaza Strip</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gaza_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-gaza-448">[441]</a></sup> Israel tightened its control of the Gaza crossings along <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Gaza_barrier" title="Israel–Gaza barrier">its border</a>, as well as by sea and air, and prevented persons from entering and exiting the area except for isolated cases it deemed humanitarian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gaza_448-1"><a href="#cite_note-gaza-448">[441]</a></sup> Gaza has a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaza%E2%80%93Egypt_border" title="Gaza–Egypt border">border with Egypt</a>, and an agreement between Israel, the European Union, and the PA governed how border crossing would take place (it was monitored by European observers).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[442]</a></sup> The application of democracy to its Palestinian citizens, and the selective application of Israeli democracy in the Israeli-controlled Palestinian territories, has been criticized.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Slater2020_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-Slater2020-450">[443]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-White2012_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-White2012-451">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">International Court of Justice</a>, principal judicial organ of the UN, asserted, in its <a href="/wiki/International_law_and_the_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict#Ruling_of_the_ICJ" title="International law and the Arab–Israeli conflict">2004 advisory opinion</a> on the legality of the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_West_Bank_barrier" title="Israeli West Bank barrier">Israeli West Bank barrier</a>, that the lands captured by Israel in the Six-Day War, including East Jerusalem, are occupied territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[445]</a></sup> Most negotiations relating to the territories have been on the basis of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_242" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 242">UN Security Council Resolution 242</a>, which emphasizes "the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war", and calls on Israel to withdraw from occupied territories in return for normalization of relations with Arab states, a principle known as "<a href="/wiki/Land_for_peace" title="Land for peace">Land for peace</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[446]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[448]</a></sup> According to some observers,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words" title="Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words"><span title="Who says this? (April 2017)">weasel words</span></a></i>]</sup> Israel has engaged in systematic and widespread violations of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_Israeli-occupied_territories" title="Human rights in the Israeli-occupied territories">human rights in the occupied territories</a>, including the occupation itself<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[449]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/War_crime" title="War crime">war crimes</a> against civilians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tny1_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-tny1-457">[450]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[451]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[453]</a></sup> The allegations include violations of international humanitarian law<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[454]</a></sup> by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">UN Human Rights Council</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[455]</a></sup> with local residents having "limited ability to hold governing authorities accountable for such abuses" by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._State_Department" title="U.S. State Department">U.S. State Department</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[456]</a></sup> mass arbitrary arrests, torture, unlawful killings, systemic abuses and impunity by <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> and others<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[459]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[461]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[462]</a></sup> and a denial of the right to <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_self-determination" title="Palestinian self-determination">Palestinian self-determination</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[464]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[465]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[466]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[467]</a></sup> In response to such allegations, Prime Minister Netanyahu has defended the country's security forces for protecting the innocent from terrorists<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[468]</a></sup> and expressed contempt for what he describes as a lack of concern about the human rights violations committed by "criminal killers".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[469]</a></sup> Some observers, such as Israeli officials, scholars,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[470]</a></sup> United States Ambassador to the UN <a href="/wiki/Nikki_Haley" title="Nikki Haley">Nikki Haley</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[471]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[472]</a></sup> and UN secretary-generals <a href="/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon" title="Ban Ki-moon">Ban Ki-moon</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[473]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kofi_Annan" title="Kofi Annan">Kofi Annan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[474]</a></sup> also assert that the UN is disproportionately concerned with Israeli misconduct.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Opinion" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:TERSE" title="Wikipedia:TERSE"><span title="Statements that may be excessive (April 2017)">excessive detail?</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/International_community" title="International community">international community</a> widely regards Israeli settlements in the occupied territories <a href="/wiki/International_law_and_Israeli_settlements" title="International law and Israeli settlements">illegal under international law</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[475]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2334" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 2334">United Nations Security Council Resolution 2334</a>, passed on 23 December 2016  in a 14–0 vote by members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">U.N. Security Council</a> (UNSC) with the United States abstaining. The resolution states that Israel's settlement activity constitutes a "flagrant violation" of <a href="/wiki/International_law" title="International law">international law</a>, has "no legal validity" and demands that Israel stop such activity and fulfill its obligations as an <a href="/wiki/Military_occupation#The_occupying_power" title="Military occupation">occupying power</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Geneva_Convention" title="Fourth Geneva Convention">Fourth Geneva Convention</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-toi_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-toi-483">[476]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel's treatment of the Palestinians within the occupied territories has drawn <a href="/wiki/Israel_and_apartheid" title="Israel and apartheid">accusations that it is guilty of</a> the <a href="/wiki/Crime_of_apartheid" title="Crime of apartheid">crime of apartheid</a> by Israeli human rights groups <a href="/wiki/Yesh_Din" title="Yesh Din">Yesh Din</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/B%27tselem" title="B'tselem">B'tselem</a>, and other international organizations including <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a>, with the criticism extending to its treatment of <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_citizens_of_Israel" title="Palestinian citizens of Israel">Palestinians within Israel</a> as well.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[478]</a></sup> Amnesty's report was criticized by politicians and government representatives from Israel, the United States, the United Kingdom, Netherlands and Germany, while it was welcomed by Palestinians, representatives from other states, and organizations such as the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[479]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[481]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[483]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[484]</a></sup> A 2021 survey of academic experts on the Middle East found an increase from 59%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[485]</a></sup> to 65% of these scholars describing Israel as a "one-state reality akin to apartheid".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[486]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Israel" title="Foreign relations of Israel">Foreign relations of Israel</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_recognition_of_Israel" title="International recognition of Israel">International recognition of Israel</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_foreign_aid" title="Israeli foreign aid">Israeli foreign aid</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Foreign_relations_of_Israel_(map).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="628" data-file-width="1425" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Foreign_relations_of_Israel_%28map%29.png/300px-Foreign_relations_of_Israel_%28map%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Foreign_relations_of_Israel_%28map%29.png/450px-Foreign_relations_of_Israel_%28map%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Foreign_relations_of_Israel_%28map%29.png/600px-Foreign_relations_of_Israel_%28map%29.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Foreign_relations_of_Israel_(map).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#0000ff; color:white;"> </span> Diplomatic relations</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#80ffff; color:black;"> </span> Diplomatic relations suspended</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#00ff00; color:black;"> </span> Former diplomatic relations</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff00ff; color:black;"> </span> No diplomatic relations, but former trade relations</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ff8040; color:black;"> </span> No diplomatic relations</div></div></div></div>
<p>Israel maintains diplomatic relations with 164 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_member_states" title="United Nations member states">member states</a> of the United Nations, as well as with the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">Cook Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Niue" title="Niue">Niue</a>. It has 107 <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Israel" title="List of diplomatic missions of Israel">diplomatic missions</a> around the world;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[487]</a></sup> countries with whom they have no diplomatic relations include most Muslim countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[488]</a></sup> Six out of twenty-two nations in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a> have normalized relations with Israel. <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Egypt–Israel relations">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_relations" title="Israel–Jordan relations">Jordan</a> signed peace treaties in <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_peace_treaty" title="Egypt–Israel peace treaty">1979</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Jordan_Treaty_of_Peace" title="Israel–Jordan Treaty of Peace">1994</a>, respectively, but Israel remains formally in a <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Syria_relations" title="Israel–Syria relations">state of war with Syria</a>, a status that dates back uninterrupted to 1948. It has been in a similarly <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Lebanon_relations" title="Israel–Lebanon relations">formal state of war with Lebanon</a> since the end of the <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_Civil_War" title="Lebanese Civil War">Lebanese Civil War</a> in 2000, with the Israel–Lebanon border remaining unagreed by treaty.
