</p><p>In late 2020, Israel normalized relations with four more Arab countries: the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain in September (known as the <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Accords" title="Abraham Accords">Abraham Accords</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[489]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Sudan_normalization_agreement" title="Israel–Sudan normalization agreement">Sudan in October</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[490]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Morocco_normalization_agreement" title="Israel–Morocco normalization agreement">Morocco in December</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[491]</a></sup> Despite the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, Israel is still widely considered an enemy country among Egyptians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[492]</a></sup> Iran <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Iran–Israel relations">had diplomatic relations</a> with Israel under the <a href="/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty" title="Pahlavi dynasty">Pahlavi dynasty</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[493]</a></sup> but withdrew its recognition of Israel during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolution" title="Islamic Revolution">Islamic Revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[494]</a></sup> Israeli citizens may not visit Syria, Lebanon, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, and Yemen (countries Israel fought in the 1948 Arab–Israeli War that Israel does not have a peace treaty with) without permission from the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Interior (Israel)">Ministry of the Interior</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[495]</a></sup> As a result of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gaza_War_(2008%E2%80%9309)" title="Gaza War (2008–09)">2008–09 Gaza War</a>, Mauritania, Qatar, Bolivia, and Venezuela suspended political and economic ties with Israel,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-al-jaz-eng_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-al-jaz-eng-503">[496]</a></sup> though Bolivia renewed ties in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[497]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="China–Israel relations">China</a> maintains good ties with both Israel and the Arab world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[498]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Israel–United States relations">United States</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="Israel–Russia relations">Soviet Union</a> were the first two countries to recognize the State of Israel, having declared recognition roughly simultaneously.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[499]</a></sup> Diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union were broken in 1967, following the <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">Six-Day War</a>, and renewed in October 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[500]</a></sup> The United States regards Israel as its "most reliable partner in the Middle East,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[501]</a></sup> based on "common democratic values, religious affinities, and security interests".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[502]</a></sup> The United States has provided $68 billion in <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_military_relations" title="Israel–United States military relations">military assistance</a> and $32 billion in grants to Israel since 1967, under the <a href="/wiki/Foreign_Assistance_Act" title="Foreign Assistance Act">Foreign Assistance Act</a> (period beginning 1962),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNADR900_510-0"><a href="#cite_note-PNADR900-510">[503]</a></sup> more than any other country for that period until 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNADR900_510-1"><a href="#cite_note-PNADR900-510">[503]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[505]</a></sup> Most surveyed Americans have also held consistently favorable views of Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[507]</a></sup> The United Kingdom is seen as having a "natural" <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations" title="Israel–United Kingdom relations">relationship</a> with Israel on account of the Mandate for Palestine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[508]</a></sup> Relations between the two countries were also made stronger by former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Tony_Blair" title="Tony Blair">Tony Blair</a>'s efforts for a two state resolution. By 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, <a href="/wiki/Germany%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Germany–Israel relations">Germany</a> had paid 25 billion euros in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reparations_Agreement_between_Israel_and_West_Germany" title="Reparations Agreement between Israel and West Germany">reparations</a> to the Israeli state and individual Israeli Holocaust survivors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[509]</a></sup> Israel is included in the European Union's <a href="/wiki/European_Neighbourhood_Policy" title="European Neighbourhood Policy">European Neighbourhood Policy</a> (ENP), which aims at bringing the EU and its neighbours closer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[510]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bill_Clinton,_Yitzhak_Rabin,_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="411" data-file-width="602" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Bill_Clinton%2C_Yitzhak_Rabin%2C_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg/220px-Bill_Clinton%2C_Yitzhak_Rabin%2C_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Bill_Clinton%2C_Yitzhak_Rabin%2C_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg/330px-Bill_Clinton%2C_Yitzhak_Rabin%2C_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Bill_Clinton%2C_Yitzhak_Rabin%2C_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg/440px-Bill_Clinton%2C_Yitzhak_Rabin%2C_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bill_Clinton,_Yitzhak_Rabin,_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Yitzhak Rabin and Yasser Arafat at the signing ceremony of the <a href="/wiki/Oslo_Accords" title="Oslo Accords">Oslo Accords</a> with then US President <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a></div></div></div>
<p>Although Turkey and Israel did not establish full diplomatic relations until 1991,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[511]</a></sup> Turkey has <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="Israel–Turkey relations">cooperated</a> with the Jewish state since its recognition of Israel in 1949. Turkey's ties to other Muslim-majority nations in the region have at times resulted in pressure from Arab and Muslim states to temper its relationship with Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[512]</a></sup> Relations between Turkey and Israel took a downturn after the 2008–09 Gaza War and Israel's <a href="/wiki/Gaza_flotilla_raid" title="Gaza flotilla raid">raid of the Gaza flotilla</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[513]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Greece%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Greece–Israel relations">Relations between Greece and Israel</a> have improved since 1995 due to the decline of Israeli–Turkish relations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[514]</a></sup> The two countries have a defense cooperation agreement and in 2010, the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Air_Force" title="Israeli Air Force">Israeli Air Force</a> hosted Greece's <a href="/wiki/Hellenic_Air_Force" title="Hellenic Air Force">Hellenic Air Force</a> in a joint exercise at the <a href="/wiki/Ovda_Airport" title="Ovda Airport">Uvda base</a>. The joint Cyprus-Israel oil and gas explorations centered on the <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_gas_field" title="Leviathan gas field">Leviathan gas field</a> are an important factor for Greece, given its <a href="/wiki/Cyprus%E2%80%93Greece_relations" title="Cyprus–Greece relations">strong links</a> with Cyprus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[515]</a></sup> Cooperation in the world's longest <a href="/wiki/Submarine_power_cable" title="Submarine power cable">subsea electric power cable</a>, the <a href="/wiki/EuroAsia_Interconnector" title="EuroAsia Interconnector">EuroAsia Interconnector</a>, has strengthened <a href="/wiki/Cyprus%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Cyprus–Israel relations">relations between Cyprus and Israel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[516]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> is one of the few majority Muslim countries to develop strategic and economic <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Azerbaijan–Israel relations">relations</a> with Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_524-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-524">[517]</a></sup> Azerbaijan supplies the country with a substantial amount of its oil needs, and Israel is a critical arms supplier for Azerbaijan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_524-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-524">[517]</a></sup> Kazakhstan also has an economic and strategic partnership with Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[518]</a></sup> India established full <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="India–Israel relations">diplomatic ties</a> with Israel in 1992 and has fostered a strong military, technological and cultural partnership with the country since then.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[519]</a></sup> A 2009 survey done on behalf of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Israel)" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)">Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a> listed India as more pro-Israel than 12 other countries surveyed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[520]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[521]</a></sup> India is the largest customer of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_military_equipment" title="Israeli military equipment">Israeli military equipment</a> and Israel is the second-largest military partner of India after Russia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[522]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Ethiopia–Israel relations">Ethiopia</a> is Israel's main ally in Africa due to common political, religious and security interests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[523]</a></sup> Israel provides expertise to Ethiopia on irrigation projects and thousands of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Jews_in_Israel" title="Ethiopian Jews in Israel">Ethiopian Jews live in Israel</a>.
</p><p>Israel has a history of providing emergency aid and humanitarian response teams to disasters across the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[524]</a></sup> In 1955 Israel began its foreign aid program in Burma. The program's focus subsequently shifted to Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geldenhuys_532-0"><a href="#cite_note-Geldenhuys-532">[525]</a></sup> Israel's humanitarian efforts officially began in 1957, with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Mashav" title="Mashav">Mashav</a>, the Israel's Agency for International Development Cooperation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[526]</a></sup> In this early period, whilst Israel's aid represented only a small percentage of total aid to Africa, its program was effective in creating goodwill throughout the continent; however, following the 1967 war relations soured.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ismael_534-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ismael-534">[527]</a></sup> Israel's foreign aid program subsequently shifted its focus to Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Geldenhuys_532-1"><a href="#cite_note-Geldenhuys-532">[525]</a></sup> Since the late 1970s Israel's foreign aid has gradually decreased, although in recent years Israel has tried to reestablish its aid to Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yacobi_535-0"><a href="#cite_note-Yacobi-535">[528]</a></sup> There are additional Israeli humanitarian and emergency response groups that work with the Israel government, including <a href="/wiki/IsraAid" title="IsraAid">IsraAid</a>, a joint programme run by 14 Israeli organizations and North American Jewish groups,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[529]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/ZAKA" title="ZAKA">ZAKA</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[530]</a></sup> The Fast Israeli Rescue and Search Team (FIRST),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[531]</a></sup> Israeli Flying Aid (IFA),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[532]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Save_a_Child%27s_Heart" title="Save a Child's Heart">Save a Child's Heart</a> (SACH)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[533]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Latet" title="Latet">Latet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[534]</a></sup> Between 1985 and 2015, Israel sent 24 delegations of IDF search and rescue unit, the <a href="/wiki/Home_Front_Command" title="Home Front Command">Home Front Command</a>, to 22 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[535]</a></sup> Currently Israeli foreign aid <a href="/wiki/List_of_development_aid_country_donors" title="List of development aid country donors">ranks</a> low among <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a> nations, spending less than 0.1% of its <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">GNI</a> on development assistance.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The UN has set a target of 0.7%. In 2015 six nations reached the UN target.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Quinn_543-0"><a href="#cite_note-Quinn-543">[536]</a></sup> The country ranked 38th in the 2018 <a href="/wiki/World_Giving_Index" title="World Giving Index">World Giving Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[537]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israel Defense Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_security_forces" title="Israeli security forces">Israeli security forces</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Israel" title="List of wars involving Israel">List of wars involving Israel</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_the_Israel_Defense_Forces_operations" title="List of the Israel Defense Forces operations">List of the Israel Defense Forces operations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Israel_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Israel and weapons of mass destruction">Israel and weapons of mass destruction</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1038" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg/220px-The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg/330px-The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg/440px-The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Southern_Lions._Squadron_116._I.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-35" title="F-35">F-35</a> fighter jets of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Air_Force" title="Israeli Air Force">Israeli Air Force</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Israel Defense Forces">Israel Defense Forces</a> (IDF) is the sole military wing of the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_security_forces" title="Israeli security forces">Israeli security forces</a>, and is headed by its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chief_of_General_Staff_(Israel)" title="Chief of General Staff (Israel)">Chief of General Staff</a>, the <i>Ramatkal</i>, subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Israel" title="Cabinet of Israel">Cabinet</a>. The IDF consists of the <a href="/wiki/GOC_Army_Headquarters" title="GOC Army Headquarters">army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Air_Force" title="Israeli Air Force">air force</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Navy" title="Israeli Navy">navy</a>. It was founded during the <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a> by consolidating paramilitary organizations—chiefly the <a href="/wiki/Haganah" title="Haganah">Haganah</a>—that preceded the establishment of the state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[538]</a></sup> The IDF also draws upon the resources of the <a href="/wiki/Military_Intelligence_Directorate_(Israel)" title="Military Intelligence Directorate (Israel)">Military Intelligence Directorate</a> (<i>Aman</i>), which works with <a href="/wiki/Mossad" title="Mossad">Mossad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shin_Bet" title="Shin Bet">Shabak</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[539]</a></sup> The Israel Defense Forces have been involved in several <a href="/wiki/List_of_wars_involving_Israel" title="List of wars involving Israel">major wars</a> and border conflicts in its short history, making it one of the most battle-trained armed forces in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[540]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[541]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most Israelis are <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Israel" title="Conscription in Israel">drafted into the military</a> at the age of 18. Men serve two years and eight months and <a href="/wiki/Women_in_the_Israel_Defense_Forces" title="Women in the Israel Defense Forces">women</a> two years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[542]</a></sup> Following mandatory service, Israeli men join the reserve forces and usually do up to several weeks of <a href="/wiki/Reserve_duty_(Israel)" title="Reserve duty (Israel)">reserve duty</a> every year until their forties. Most women are exempt from reserve duty. <a href="/wiki/Arab_citizens_of_Israel" title="Arab citizens of Israel">Arab citizens of Israel</a> (except the <a href="/wiki/Druze_in_Israel" title="Druze in Israel">Druze</a>) and those engaged in full-time religious studies are <a href="/wiki/Exemption_from_military_service_in_Israel" title="Exemption from military service in Israel">exempt from military service</a>, although the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tal_committee" title="Tal committee">exemption of yeshiva students</a> has been a source of contention in Israeli society for many years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[543]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[544]</a></sup> An alternative for those who receive exemptions on various grounds is <i><a href="/wiki/Sherut_Leumi" title="Sherut Leumi">Sherut Leumi</a></i>, or national service, which involves a program of service in hospitals, schools and other social welfare frameworks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[545]</a></sup> A small minority of Israeli Arabs also volunteer to serve in the army.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[546]</a></sup> As a result of its conscription program, the IDF maintains approximately 176,500 active troops and an additional 465,000 reservists, giving Israel one of the world's highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">percentage of citizens with military training</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IISS_military_554-0"><a href="#cite_note-IISS_military-554">[547]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls,_May_2021._I.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1346" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls%2C_May_2021._I.jpg/220px-IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls%2C_May_2021._I.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls%2C_May_2021._I.jpg/330px-IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls%2C_May_2021._I.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls%2C_May_2021._I.jpg/440px-IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls%2C_May_2021._I.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IDF_Air_Defense_fighters_during_Operation_Guardian_of_the_Walls,_May_2021._I.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Iron_Dome" title="Iron Dome">Iron Dome</a> is the world's first operational anti-<a href="/wiki/Rocket_artillery" title="Rocket artillery">artillery rocket</a> defense system.</div></div></div>
<p>The nation's military relies heavily on high-tech <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_equipment_of_Israel" title="Military equipment of Israel">weapons</a> systems <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Israel" title="Defense industry of Israel">designed and manufactured in Israel</a> as well as some foreign imports. The <a href="/wiki/Arrow_(Israeli_missile)" title="Arrow (Israeli missile)">Arrow</a> missile is one of the world's few operational <a href="/wiki/Anti-ballistic_missile" title="Anti-ballistic missile">anti-ballistic missile</a> systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[548]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Python_(missile)" title="Python (missile)">Python</a> air-to-air missile series is often considered one of the most crucial weapons in its military history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[549]</a></sup> Israel's <a href="/wiki/Spike_(missile)" title="Spike (missile)">Spike</a> missile is one of the most widely exported <a href="/wiki/Anti-tank_guided_missile" title="Anti-tank guided missile">anti-tank guided missiles</a> (ATGMs) in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[550]</a></sup> Israel's <a href="/wiki/Iron_Dome" title="Iron Dome">Iron Dome</a> anti-missile air defense system gained worldwide acclaim after intercepting hundreds of <a href="/wiki/Qassam_rocket" title="Qassam rocket">Qassam</a>, <a href="/wiki/BM-21_Grad" title="BM-21 Grad">122 mm Grad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fajr-5" title="Fajr-5">Fajr-5</a> artillery <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_rocket_attacks_on_Israel" title="Palestinian rocket attacks on Israel">rockets fire by Palestinian militants</a> from the Gaza Strip.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson_558-0"><a href="#cite_note-Johnson-558">[551]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tory_559-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tory-559">[552]</a></sup> Since the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a>, Israel has developed a network of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reconnaissance_satellites" title="Reconnaissance satellites">reconnaissance satellites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[553]</a></sup> The success of the <i><a href="/wiki/Ofeq" title="Ofeq">Ofeq</a></i> program has made Israel <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_first_orbital_launches_by_country" title="Timeline of first orbital launches by country">one of seven countries</a> capable of launching such satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[554]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel is widely believed to <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_Israel" title="Nuclear weapons and Israel">possess nuclear weapons</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[555]</a></sup> and per a 1993 report, chemical and biological <a href="/wiki/Israel_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Israel and weapons of mass destruction">weapons of mass destruction</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[556]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The text near this tag is dated. (November 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> Israel has not signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Non-Proliferation_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons">Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[557]</a></sup> and maintains a <a href="/wiki/Policy_of_deliberate_ambiguity" title="Policy of deliberate ambiguity">policy of deliberate ambiguity</a> toward its nuclear capabilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[558]</a></sup> The Israeli Navy's <a href="/wiki/Dolphin-class_submarine" title="Dolphin-class submarine">Dolphin submarines</a> are believed to be armed with nuclear <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Popeye_Turbo" title="Popeye Turbo">Popeye Turbo</a> missiles, offering <a href="/wiki/Second_strike" title="Second strike">second-strike</a> capability.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-566"><a href="#cite_note-566">[559]</a></sup> Since the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> in 1991, when Israel was attacked by <a href="/wiki/Al_Hussein_(missile)" title="Al Hussein (missile)">Iraqi Scud missiles</a>, all homes in Israel are required to have a reinforced security room, <a href="/wiki/Merkhav_Mugan" title="Merkhav Mugan">Merkhav Mugan</a>, impermeable to chemical and biological substances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[560]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since Israel's establishment, military expenditure constituted a significant portion of the country's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a>, with peak of 30.3% of GDP spent on defense in 1975.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[561]</a></sup> In 2016, Israel ranked 6th in the world by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditure_share_of_GDP" title="List of countries by military expenditure share of GDP">defense spending as a percentage of GDP</a>, with 5.7%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[562]</a></sup> and 15th <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">by total military expenditure</a>, with $18 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-570"><a href="#cite_note-570">[563]</a></sup> Since 1974, the United States has been a particularly notable contributor of <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_military_relations#Military_aid_and_procurement" title="Israel–United States military relations">military aid to Israel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[564]</a></sup> Under a <a href="/wiki/Memorandum_of_understanding" title="Memorandum of understanding">memorandum of understanding</a> signed in 2016, the U.S. is expected to provide the country with $3.8 billion per year, or around 20% of Israel's defense budget, from 2018 to 2028.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[565]</a></sup> Israel ranked 5th globally for <a href="/wiki/Arms_industry" title="Arms industry">arms exports</a> in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[566]</a></sup> The majority of Israel's arms exports are unreported for security reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574"><a href="#cite_note-574">[567]</a></sup> Israel is consistently rated low in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>, ranking 141st out of 163 nations for peacefulness in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GPI_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-GPI-575">[568]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Israel" title="Economy of Israel">Economy of Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ayalon_Highway,_Tel_Aviv_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2644" data-file-width="3424" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Ayalon_Highway%2C_Tel_Aviv_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Ayalon_Highway%2C_Tel_Aviv_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Ayalon_Highway%2C_Tel_Aviv_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Ayalon_Highway%2C_Tel_Aviv_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Ayalon_Highway%2C_Tel_Aviv_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Ayalon_Highway%2C_Tel_Aviv_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ayalon_Highway,_Tel_Aviv_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Diamond_Exchange_District" title="Diamond Exchange District">Diamond Exchange District</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ramat_Gan" title="Ramat Gan">Ramat Gan</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3120" data-file-width="4208" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg/220px-Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg/330px-Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg/440px-Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange_-_New_Building_Lobby_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_Stock_Exchange" title="Tel Aviv Stock Exchange">Tel Aviv Stock Exchange</a></div></div></div>
<p>Israel is considered the most advanced country in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> in economic and industrial development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chua_2003_219–220_576-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chua_2003_219–220-576">[569]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[570]</a></sup> Israel's quality <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Israel" title="List of universities and colleges in Israel">university education</a> and the establishment of a highly motivated and educated populace is largely responsible for spurring the country's high technology boom and rapid economic development.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-David_Adler_386-1"><a href="#cite_note-David_Adler-386">[379]</a></sup> In 2010, it joined the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_40-2"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-40">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[571]</a></sup> The country is ranked 20th in the <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">Global Competitiveness Report</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rank_2019_579-0"><a href="#cite_note-rank_2019-579">[572]</a></sup> and 35th on the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Ease_of_doing_business_index" title="Ease of doing business index"><i>Ease of Doing Business</i> index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[573]</a></sup> Israel was also ranked 5th in the world by share of people in high-skilled employment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[574]</a></sup> Israeli economic data covers the economic territory of Israel, including the Golan Heights, East Jerusalem and Israeli settlements in the West Bank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOECD2011_436-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOECD2011-436">[429]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite limited natural resources, intensive development of the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Israel" title="Agriculture in Israel">agricultural</a> and industrial sectors over the past decades has made Israel largely self-sufficient in food production, apart from grains and beef. Imports to Israel, totaling $96.5 billion in 2020, include raw materials, military equipment, investment goods, rough diamonds, fuels, grain, and consumer goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_297-5"><a href="#cite_note-cia-297">[290]</a></sup> Leading exports include machinery and equipment, software, <a href="/wiki/Diamond_industry_in_Israel" title="Diamond industry in Israel">cut diamonds</a>, agricultural products, chemicals, and textiles and apparel; in 2020, Israeli exports reached $114 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_297-6"><a href="#cite_note-cia-297">[290]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Israel" title="Bank of Israel">Bank of Israel</a> holds $173 billion of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign-exchange_reserves" title="Foreign-exchange reserves">foreign-exchange reserves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia_297-7"><a href="#cite_note-cia-297">[290]</a></sup> Since the 1970s, Israel has received <a href="/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93United_States_military_relations" title="Israel–United States military relations">military aid</a> from the United States, as well as economic assistance in the form of <a href="/wiki/Loan_guarantee" title="Loan guarantee">loan guarantees</a>, which now account for roughly half of Israel's <a href="/wiki/External_debt" title="External debt">external debt</a>. Israel has <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_external_debt" title="List of countries by external debt">one of the lowest</a> external debts in the developed world, and is a lender in terms of net external debt (<a href="/wiki/Net_international_investment_position" title="Net international investment position">assets vs. liabilities abroad</a>), which in 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> stood at a surplus of $69 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[575]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel has the second-largest number of <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup companies</a> in the world after the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[576]</a></sup> and the third-largest number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_companies_quoted_on_the_Nasdaq" title="List of Israeli companies quoted on the Nasdaq">NASDAQ-listed companies</a> after the U.S. and China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[577]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[578]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[579]</a></sup> built their first overseas <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> facilities in Israel, and other high-tech multi-national corporations, such as <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hewlett-Packard" title="Hewlett-Packard">Hewlett-Packard</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cisco_Systems" title="Cisco Systems">Cisco Systems</a>, <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a> and <a href="/wiki/Motorola" title="Motorola">Motorola</a> have opened <a href="/wiki/List_of_multinational_companies_with_research_and_development_centres_in_Israel" title="List of multinational companies with research and development centres in Israel">research and development centres in the country</a>. In 2007, American investor <a href="/wiki/Warren_Buffett" title="Warren Buffett">Warren Buffett</a>'s holding company <a href="/wiki/Berkshire_Hathaway" title="Berkshire Hathaway">Berkshire Hathaway</a> bought an Israeli company, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iscar" title="Iscar">Iscar</a>, its first <a href="/wiki/List_of_assets_owned_by_Berkshire_Hathaway" title="List of assets owned by Berkshire Hathaway">acquisition</a> outside the United States, for $4 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[580]</a></sup>
</p><p>Days of working time in Israel are Sunday through Thursday (for a five-day <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Workweek" title="Workweek">workweek</a>), or Friday (for a six-day workweek). In observance of <i><a href="/wiki/Shabbat" title="Shabbat">Shabbat</a></i>, in places where Friday is a work day and the majority of population is Jewish, Friday is a "short day", usually lasting until 14:00 in the winter, or 16:00 in the summer. Several proposals have been raised to adjust the work week with the majority of the world, and make Sunday a non-working day, while extending working time of other days or replacing Friday with Sunday as a work day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[581]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Israel" title="Science and technology in Israel">Science and technology in Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Israeli inventions and discoveries">List of Israeli inventions and discoveries</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Matam_hi-tech_park_(Haifa).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1589" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Matam_hi-tech_park_%28Haifa%29.jpg/220px-Matam_hi-tech_park_%28Haifa%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Matam_hi-tech_park_%28Haifa%29.jpg/330px-Matam_hi-tech_park_%28Haifa%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Matam_hi-tech_park_%28Haifa%29.jpg/440px-Matam_hi-tech_park_%28Haifa%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Matam_hi-tech_park_(Haifa).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Matam,_Haifa" title="Matam, Haifa">Matam</a> high-tech park in Haifa</div></div></div>
<p>Israel's development of cutting-edge technologies in software, communications and the life sciences have <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Wadi" title="Silicon Wadi">evoked comparisons</a> with <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">Silicon Valley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[582]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[583]</a></sup> Israel is first in the world in <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_research_and_development_spending" title="List of countries by research and development spending">expenditure on research and development</a> as a percentage of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_R&amp;D_591-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECD_R&amp;D-591">[584]</a></sup> It is ranked 15th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021, down from 10th in 2019 and 5th in the 2019 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bloomberg_Innovation_Index" title="Bloomberg Innovation Index">Bloomberg Innovation Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[585]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593"><a href="#cite_note-593">[586]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[587]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595"><a href="#cite_note-595">[588]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[589]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloomberg_innovation_597-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloomberg_innovation-597">[590]</a></sup> Israel has 140 scientists, technicians, and engineers per 10,000 employees, the highest number in the world, for comparison the U.S has 85 per 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[591]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-599"><a href="#cite_note-599">[592]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600"><a href="#cite_note-600">[593]</a></sup> Israel has produced six <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_Nobel_laureates" title="List of Israeli Nobel laureates">Nobel Prize-winning</a> scientists since 2004<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nobel_601-0"><a href="#cite_note-nobel-601">[594]</a></sup> and has been frequently ranked as one of the countries with the highest ratios of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_papers" title="Scientific papers">scientific papers</a> per capita in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-602"><a href="#cite_note-602">[595]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[596]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[597]</a></sup> Israel has led the world in <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell" title="Stem cell">stem-cell</a> research papers per capita since 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-scell_605-0"><a href="#cite_note-scell-605">[598]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_universities_and_colleges" title="List of Israeli universities and colleges">Israeli universities</a> are ranked among the top 50 world universities in computer science (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technion" title="Technion">Technion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University" title="Tel Aviv University">Tel Aviv University</a>), mathematics (<a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a>) and chemistry (<a href="/wiki/Weizmann_Institute_of_Science" title="Weizmann Institute of Science">Weizmann Institute of Science</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ARWU_412-1"><a href="#cite_note-ARWU-412">[405]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2012, Israel was ranked ninth in the world by the Futron's <a href="/wiki/Space_Competitiveness_Index" title="Space Competitiveness Index">Space Competitiveness Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[599]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Space_Agency" title="Israel Space Agency">Israel Space Agency</a> coordinates all Israeli space research programs with scientific and commercial goals, and have indigenously designed and built at least 13 commercial, research and spy satellites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[600]</a></sup> Some of Israel's satellites are ranked among the world's most advanced space systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[601]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shavit_2" title="Shavit 2">Shavit</a> is a space <a href="/wiki/Launch_vehicle" title="Launch vehicle">launch vehicle</a> produced by Israel to launch small <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellites</a> into <a href="/wiki/Low_Earth_orbit" title="Low Earth orbit">low Earth orbit</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[602]</a></sup> It was first launched in 1988, making Israel the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_first_orbital_launches_by_country" title="Timeline of first orbital launches by country">eighth nation</a> to have a space launch capability. In 2003, <a href="/wiki/Ilan_Ramon" title="Ilan Ramon">Ilan Ramon</a> became Israel's first astronaut, serving as payload specialist of <a href="/wiki/STS-107" title="STS-107">STS-107</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Columbia_disaster" title="Space Shuttle Columbia disaster">fatal mission</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Columbia" title="Space Shuttle Columbia">Space Shuttle <i>Columbia</i></a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-610"><a href="#cite_note-610">[603]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ongoing shortage of <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Israel" title="Water supply and sanitation in Israel">water in the country</a> has spurred innovation in <a href="/wiki/Water_conservation" title="Water conservation">water conservation</a> techniques, and a substantial <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_research_in_Israel" title="Agricultural research in Israel">agricultural modernization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drip_irrigation" title="Drip irrigation">drip irrigation</a>, was <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Israeli inventions and discoveries">invented in Israel</a>. Israel is also at the technological forefront of <a href="/wiki/Desalination" title="Desalination">desalination</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_recycling" title="Water recycling">water recycling</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sorek_desalination_plant" title="Sorek desalination plant">Sorek desalination plant</a> is the largest seawater <a href="/wiki/Reverse_osmosis" title="Reverse osmosis">reverse osmosis</a> (SWRO) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Desalination_facilities" title="Desalination facilities">desalination facility</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-611"><a href="#cite_note-611">[604]</a></sup> By 2014, Israel's desalination programs provided roughly 35% of Israel's drinking water and it is expected to supply 40% by 2015 and 70% by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612"><a href="#cite_note-612">[605]</a></sup> As of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, more than 50 percent of the water for Israeli households, agriculture and industry is artificially produced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kershner_613-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kershner-613">[606]</a></sup> The country hosts an annual Water Technology and Environmental Control Exhibition &amp; Conference (WATEC) that attracts thousands of people from across the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-614"><a href="#cite_note-614">[607]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615"><a href="#cite_note-615">[608]</a></sup> In 2011, Israel's <a href="/wiki/Water_industry" title="Water industry">water technology industry</a> was worth around $2 billion a year with annual exports of products and services in the tens of millions of dollars. As a result of innovations in reverse osmosis technology, Israel is set to become a net <a href="/wiki/Water_export" title="Water export">exporter of water</a> in the coming years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-616"><a href="#cite_note-616">[609]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg"><img alt="A horizontal parabolic dish, with a triangular structure on its top." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2504" data-file-width="3340" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg/220px-Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg/330px-Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg/440px-Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Solar_dish_at_Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center_in_Israel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The world's largest <a href="/wiki/Parabolic_reflector" title="Parabolic reflector">solar parabolic dish</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Ben-Gurion_National_Solar_Energy_Center" title="Ben-Gurion National Solar Energy Center">Ben-Gurion National Solar Energy Center</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Register_617-0"><a href="#cite_note-Register-617">[610]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Israel has embraced <a href="/wiki/Solar_power_in_Israel" title="Solar power in Israel">solar energy</a>; its engineers are on the cutting edge of solar energy technology<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPR_618-0"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-618">[611]</a></sup> and its solar companies work on projects around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBC_619-0"><a href="#cite_note-CBC-619">[612]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BW_620-0"><a href="#cite_note-BW-620">[613]</a></sup> Over 90% of Israeli homes use solar energy for hot water, the highest per capita in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Solar_energy_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-Solar_energy-316">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Environment_California_SWH_621-0"><a href="#cite_note-Environment_California_SWH-621">[614]</a></sup> According to government figures, the country saves 8% of its electricity consumption per year because of its solar energy use in heating.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[615]</a></sup> The high annual incident <a href="/wiki/Irradiance" title="Irradiance">solar irradiance</a> at its geographic <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitude</a> creates ideal conditions for what is an internationally renowned solar research and development industry in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Negev_Desert" title="Negev Desert">Negev Desert</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPR_618-1"><a href="#cite_note-NPR-618">[611]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBC_619-1"><a href="#cite_note-CBC-619">[612]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BW_620-1"><a href="#cite_note-BW-620">[613]</a></sup> Israel had a modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_network" title="Electric vehicle network">electric car infrastructure</a> involving a countrywide network of <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">charging stations</a> to facilitate the charging and exchange of car batteries. It was thought that this would have lowered Israel's oil dependency and lowered the fuel costs of hundreds of Israel's motorists that use cars powered only by electric batteries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623"><a href="#cite_note-623">[616]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[617]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[618]</a></sup> The Israeli model was being studied by several countries and being implemented in Denmark and Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-626"><a href="#cite_note-626">[619]</a></sup> However, Israel's trailblazing electric car company <a href="/wiki/Better_Place_(company)" title="Better Place (company)">Better Place</a> shut down in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-627"><a href="#cite_note-627">[620]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Israel" title="Transport in Israel">Transport in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3113" data-file-width="4160" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg/220px-4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg/330px-4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg/440px-4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:4X-ECC_LLBG_09-05-2014b.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ben_Gurion_International_Airport" title="Ben Gurion International Airport">Ben Gurion International Airport</a></div></div></div>
<p>Israel has 19,224 kilometres (11,945 mi) of paved <a href="/wiki/Roads_in_Israel" title="Roads in Israel">roads</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-628"><a href="#cite_note-628">[621]</a></sup> and 3 million motor vehicles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vehicles_629-0"><a href="#cite_note-vehicles-629">[622]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_vehicles_per_capita" title="List of countries by vehicles per capita">number of motor vehicles per 1,000 persons</a> is 365, relatively low with respect to developed countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vehicles_629-1"><a href="#cite_note-vehicles-629">[622]</a></sup> Israel has 5,715 buses on scheduled routes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-630"><a href="#cite_note-630">[623]</a></sup> operated by several carriers, the largest and oldest of which is <a href="/wiki/Egged_(company)" title="Egged (company)">Egged</a>, serving most of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-631"><a href="#cite_note-631">[624]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Israel" title="Rail transport in Israel">Railways</a> stretch across 1,277 kilometres (793 mi) and are operated solely by government-owned <a href="/wiki/Israel_Railways" title="Israel Railways">Israel Railways</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_rails_632-0"><a href="#cite_note-cbs_rails-632">[625]</a></sup> Following major investments beginning in the early to mid-1990s, the number of train passengers per year has grown from 2.5 million in 1990, to 53 million in 2015; railways are also transporting 7.5 million tons of cargo, per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cbs_rails_632-1"><a href="#cite_note-cbs_rails-632">[625]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel is served by two international <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Israel" title="List of airports in Israel">airports</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben_Gurion_Airport" title="Ben Gurion Airport">Ben Gurion Airport</a>, the country's main hub for international air travel near Tel Aviv, and <a href="/wiki/Ramon_Airport" title="Ramon Airport">Ramon Airport</a>, which serves the southernmost port city of Eilat. Ben Gurion, Israel's largest airport, handled over 15 million passengers in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-633"><a href="#cite_note-633">[626]</a></sup> The country has three main ports: the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Haifa" title="Port of Haifa">Port of Haifa</a>, the country's oldest and largest, on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mediterranean" title="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> coast, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashdod_Port" title="Ashdod Port">Ashdod Port</a>; and the smaller <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Eilat" title="Port of Eilat">Port of Eilat</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Israel" title="Tourism in Israel">Tourism in Israel</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_archaeological_sites_in_Israel_and_Palestine" title="List of archaeological sites in Israel and Palestine">List of archaeological sites in Israel and Palestine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3552" data-file-width="5288" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg/220px-Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg/330px-Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg/440px-Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ein_Bokek_-_Dead_Sea2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ein_Bokek" title="Ein Bokek">Ein Bokek</a> resort on the shore of the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea" title="Dead Sea">Dead Sea</a></div></div></div>
<p>Tourism, especially <a href="/wiki/Religious_tourism" title="Religious tourism">religious tourism</a>, is an important industry in Israel, with the country's temperate climate, <a href="/wiki/List_of_beaches_in_Israel" title="List of beaches in Israel">beaches</a>, <a href="/wiki/Archaeology_of_Israel" title="Archaeology of Israel">archaeological</a>, other <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Israel" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Israel">historical</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_biblical_places" title="List of biblical places">biblical</a> sites, and unique geography also drawing tourists. Israel's security problems have taken their toll on the industry, but the number of incoming tourists is on the rebound.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634"><a href="#cite_note-634">[627]</a></sup> In 2017, a record of 3.6 million tourists visited Israel, yielding a 25 percent growth since 2016 and contributed NIS 20 billion to the Israeli economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-635"><a href="#cite_note-635">[628]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-636"><a href="#cite_note-636">[629]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-637"><a href="#cite_note-637">[630]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-638"><a href="#cite_note-638">[631]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Israel" title="Energy in Israel">Energy in Israel</a></div>
<p>Israel began producing natural gas from its own offshore gas fields in 2004. Between 2005 and 2012, Israel had imported gas from Egypt via the al-<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arish%E2%80%93Ashkelon_pipeline" title="Arish–Ashkelon pipeline">Arish–Ashkelon pipeline</a>, which was terminated due to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Egyptian_crisis_(2011%E2%80%9314)" title="Egyptian crisis (2011–14)">Egyptian Crisis of 2011–14</a>. In 2009, a <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_in_Israel" title="Natural gas in Israel">natural gas</a> reserve, <a href="/wiki/Tamar_gas_field" title="Tamar gas field">Tamar</a>, was found near the coast of Israel. A second natural gas reserve, <a href="/wiki/Leviathan_gas_field" title="Leviathan gas field">Leviathan</a>, was discovered in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-639"><a href="#cite_note-639">[632]</a></sup> The natural gas reserves in these two fields (Leviathan has around 19 trillion cubic feet) could make Israel energy secure for more than 50 years. In 2013, Israel began commercial production of natural gas from the Tamar field. As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Israel produced over 7.5 billion cubic meters (bcm) of <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-640"><a href="#cite_note-640">[633]</a></sup> Israel had 199 billion cubic meters (bcm) of proven reserves of natural gas as of the start of 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-641"><a href="#cite_note-641">[634]</a></sup> The Leviathan gas field started production in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-642"><a href="#cite_note-642">[635]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ketura_Sun" title="Ketura Sun">Ketura Sun</a> is Israel's first commercial solar field. Built in early 2011 by the <a href="/wiki/Arava_Power_Company" title="Arava Power Company">Arava Power Company</a> on <a href="/wiki/Ketura,_Israel" title="Ketura, Israel">Kibbutz Ketura</a>, Ketura Sun covers twenty acres and is expected to produce green energy amounting to 4.95 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megawatts" title="Megawatts">megawatts</a> (MW). The field consists of 18,500 <a href="/wiki/Photovoltaics" title="Photovoltaics">photovoltaic</a> panels made by <a href="/wiki/Suntech_Power" title="Suntech Power">Suntech</a>, which will produce about 9 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gigawatt-hour" title="Gigawatt-hour">gigawatt-hours</a> (GWh) of electricity per year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-643"><a href="#cite_note-643">[636]</a></sup> In the next twenty years, the field will spare the production of some 125,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-644"><a href="#cite_note-644">[637]</a></sup> The field was inaugurated on 15 June 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-645"><a href="#cite_note-645">[638]</a></sup> On 22 May 2012 <a href="/wiki/Arava_Power_Company" title="Arava Power Company">Arava Power Company</a> announced that it had reached financial close on an additional 58.5 MW for 8 projects to be built in the Arava and the Negev valued at 780 million NIS or approximately $204 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-646"><a href="#cite_note-646">[639]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Real_estate">Real estate</span></h3>
<p>Housing prices in Israel are listed in the top third,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-647"><a href="#cite_note-647">[640]</a></sup> with an average of 150 salaries required to buy an apartment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-648"><a href="#cite_note-648">[641]</a></sup> As of 2022, there are about 2.7 million properties in Israel, with an annual increase of more than 50,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-649"><a href="#cite_note-649">[642]</a></sup> However, the demand for housing exceeds supply, with a shortage of about 200,000 apartments as of 2021,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-650"><a href="#cite_note-650">[643]</a></sup> and thus rising house prices. As a result, by 2021 housing prices rose by 5.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-651"><a href="#cite_note-651">[644]</a></sup> High prices do not stop Israelis from buying properties. In 2021, Israelis took a record of NIS 116.1 billion in mortgages, an increase of 50% from 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-652"><a href="#cite_note-652">[645]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Israel" title="Culture of Israel">Culture of Israel</a></div>
<p>Israel's diverse culture stems from the diversity of its population. Jews from diaspora communities around the world brought their cultural and religious traditions back with them, creating a melting pot of Jewish customs and beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-653"><a href="#cite_note-653">[646]</a></sup> Arab influences are present in many cultural spheres,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MendelRanta2016p137_654-0"><a href="#cite_note-MendelRanta2016p137-654">[647]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MendelRanta2016p140_655-0"><a href="#cite_note-MendelRanta2016p140-655">[648]</a></sup> such as <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Israel" title="Architecture of Israel">architecture</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-656"><a href="#cite_note-656">[649]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Israel" title="Music of Israel">music</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-657"><a href="#cite_note-657">[650]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_cuisine" title="Israeli cuisine">cuisine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-658"><a href="#cite_note-658">[651]</a></sup> Israel is the only country in the world where life revolves around the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_calendar" title="Hebrew calendar">Hebrew calendar</a>. <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Israel" title="Public holidays in Israel">Work and school holidays</a> are determined by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish_holiday" title="Jewish holiday">Jewish holidays</a>, and the official day of rest is Saturday, the <a href="/wiki/Shabbat" title="Shabbat">Jewish Sabbath</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-659"><a href="#cite_note-659">[652]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Israeli_literature" title="Israeli literature">Israeli literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Agnon.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="868" data-file-width="651" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Agnon.jpg/170px-Agnon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Agnon.jpg/255px-Agnon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Agnon.jpg/340px-Agnon.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Agnon.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shmuel_Yosef_Agnon" title="Shmuel Yosef Agnon">Shmuel Yosef Agnon</a>, laureate of the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Israeli_literature" title="Israeli literature">Israeli literature</a> is primarily <a href="/wiki/Modern_Hebrew_poetry" title="Modern Hebrew poetry">poetry</a> and prose written in <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Revival_of_the_Hebrew_language" title="Revival of the Hebrew language">renaissance</a> of Hebrew as a spoken language since the mid-19th century, although a small body of literature is published in other languages, such as English. By law, two copies of all printed matter published in Israel must be deposited in the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Israel" title="National Library of Israel">National Library of Israel</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_University_of_Jerusalem" title="Hebrew University of Jerusalem">Hebrew University of Jerusalem</a>. In 2001, the law was amended to include audio and video recordings, and other non-print media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-660"><a href="#cite_note-660">[653]</a></sup> In 2016, 89 percent of the 7,300 books transferred to the library were in Hebrew.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-661"><a href="#cite_note-661">[654]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1966, <a href="/wiki/Shmuel_Yosef_Agnon" title="Shmuel Yosef Agnon">Shmuel Yosef Agnon</a> shared the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> with German Jewish author <a href="/wiki/Nelly_Sachs" title="Nelly Sachs">Nelly Sachs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-662"><a href="#cite_note-662">[655]</a></sup> Leading Israeli poets have been <a href="/wiki/Yehuda_Amichai" title="Yehuda Amichai">Yehuda Amichai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathan_Alterman" title="Nathan Alterman">Nathan Alterman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leah_Goldberg" title="Leah Goldberg">Leah Goldberg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Bluwstein" title="Rachel Bluwstein">Rachel Bluwstein</a>. Internationally famous contemporary Israeli novelists include <a href="/wiki/Amos_Oz" title="Amos Oz">Amos Oz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Etgar_Keret" title="Etgar Keret">Etgar Keret</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Grossman" title="David Grossman">David Grossman</a>. The Israeli-Arab satirist <a href="/wiki/Sayed_Kashua" title="Sayed Kashua">Sayed Kashua</a> (who writes in Hebrew) is also internationally known.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Israel has also been the home of <a href="/wiki/Emile_Habibi" title="Emile Habibi">Emile Habibi</a>, whose novel <i><a href="/wiki/The_Secret_Life_of_Saeed:_The_Pessoptimist" title="The Secret Life of Saeed: The Pessoptimist">The Secret Life of Saeed: The Pessoptimist</a></i>, and other writings, won him the Israel prize for Arabic literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-663"><a href="#cite_note-663">[656]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prize_664-0"><a href="#cite_note-prize-664">[657]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Israel" title="Music of Israel">Music of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dance_in_Israel" title="Dance in Israel">Dance in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg"><img alt="Several dozen musicians in formal dress, holding their instruments, behind a conductor" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1368" data-file-width="1824" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg/220px-Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg/330px-Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg/440px-Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Israel Philharmonic Orchestra">Israel Philharmonic Orchestra</a> conducted by <a href="/wiki/Zubin_Mehta" title="Zubin Mehta">Zubin Mehta</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Music_of_Israel" title="Music of Israel">Israeli music</a> contains musical influences from all over the world; <a href="/wiki/Mizrahi_music" title="Mizrahi music">Mizrahi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sephardic_music" title="Sephardic music">Sephardic music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hasidic_Judaism" title="Hasidic Judaism">Hasidic</a> melodies, <a href="/wiki/Greek_music_in_Israel" title="Greek music in Israel">Greek music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pop_rock" title="Pop rock">pop rock</a> are all part of the music scene.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-665"><a href="#cite_note-665">[658]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-666"><a href="#cite_note-666">[659]</a></sup> Among Israel's world-renowned<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-667"><a href="#cite_note-667">[660]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-668"><a href="#cite_note-668">[661]</a></sup> orchestras is the <a href="/wiki/Israel_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Israel Philharmonic Orchestra">Israel Philharmonic Orchestra</a>, which has been in operation for over seventy years and today performs more than two hundred concerts each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-669"><a href="#cite_note-669">[662]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Itzhak_Perlman" title="Itzhak Perlman">Itzhak Perlman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pinchas_Zukerman" title="Pinchas Zukerman">Pinchas Zukerman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ofra_Haza" title="Ofra Haza">Ofra Haza</a> are among the internationally acclaimed musicians born in Israel. <a href="/wiki/Israel_in_the_Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Israel in the Eurovision Song Contest">Israel has participated</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest" title="Eurovision Song Contest">Eurovision Song Contest</a> nearly every year since 1973, winning the competition four times and hosting it twice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-670"><a href="#cite_note-670">[663]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-671"><a href="#cite_note-671">[664]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Eilat" title="Eilat">Eilat</a> has hosted its own international music festival, the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea_Jazz_Festival" title="Red Sea Jazz Festival">Red Sea Jazz Festival</a>, every summer since 1987.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-672"><a href="#cite_note-672">[665]</a></sup> The nation's canonical <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk songs</a>, known as "Songs of the Land of Israel," deal with the experiences of the pioneers in building the Jewish homeland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-673"><a href="#cite_note-673">[666]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema_and_theatre">Cinema and theatre</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Israel" title="Cinema of Israel">Cinema of Israel</a></div>
<p>Ten Israeli films <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_submissions_for_the_Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="List of Israeli submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">have been final nominees</a> for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Best Foreign Language Film</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">Academy Awards</a> since the establishment of Israel. The 2009 movie <i><a href="/wiki/Ajami_(film)" title="Ajami (film)">Ajami</a></i> was the third consecutive nomination of an Israeli film.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-674"><a href="#cite_note-674">[667]</a></sup> Palestinian Israeli filmmakers have made a number of films dealing with the Arab-Israeli conflict and the status of Palestinians within Israel, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mohammed_Bakri" title="Mohammed Bakri">Mohammed Bakri</a>'s 2002 film <i><a href="/wiki/Jenin,_Jenin" title="Jenin, Jenin">Jenin, Jenin</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Syrian_Bride" title="The Syrian Bride">The Syrian Bride</a></i>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Continuing the strong theatrical traditions of the <a href="/wiki/Yiddish_theatre" title="Yiddish theatre">Yiddish theatre</a> in Eastern Europe, Israel maintains a vibrant theatre scene. Founded in 1918, <a href="/wiki/Habima_Theatre" title="Habima Theatre">Habima Theatre</a> in Tel Aviv is Israel's oldest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Repertory_theater" title="Repertory theater">repertory theater</a> company and national theater.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-675"><a href="#cite_note-675">[668]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Israel" title="Media of Israel">Media of Israel</a></div>
