<p>The 2017 <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_Press_(report)" title="Freedom of the Press (report)">Freedom of the Press</a></i> annual report by <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> ranked Israel as the <a href="/wiki/MENA" title="MENA">Middle East and North Africa</a>'s most free country, and 64th globally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-676"><a href="#cite_note-676">[669]</a></sup> In the 2017 <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> by <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>, Israel (including "Israel extraterritorial" since 2013 ranking)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-677"><a href="#cite_note-677">[670]</a></sup> was placed 91st of 180 countries, first in the Middle East and North Africa region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-678"><a href="#cite_note-678">[671]</a></sup> Reporters Without Borders noted that  "Palestinian journalists are systematically subjected to violence as a result of their coverage of events in the West Bank".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-679"><a href="#cite_note-679">[672]</a></sup> More than fifty Palestinian journalists have been killed by Israel since 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guyer_2022_680-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guyer_2022-680">[673]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums">Museums</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a more comprehensive list, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_museums" title="List of Israeli museums">List of Israeli museums</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_(14755133799).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3062" data-file-width="4752" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/220px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/330px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg/440px-Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_%2814755133799%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Billy_Rose_Art_Garden_(14755133799).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shrine_of_the_Book" title="Shrine of the Book">Shrine of the Book</a>, repository of the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a> in Jerusalem</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Israel_Museum" title="Israel Museum">Israel Museum</a> in Jerusalem is one of Israel's most important cultural institutions<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imj_681-0"><a href="#cite_note-imj-681">[674]</a></sup> and houses the <a href="/wiki/Dead_Sea_Scrolls" title="Dead Sea Scrolls">Dead Sea Scrolls</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-682"><a href="#cite_note-682">[675]</a></sup> along with an extensive collection of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Judaica" title="Judaica">Judaica</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_art" title="European art">European art</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imj_681-1"><a href="#cite_note-imj-681">[674]</a></sup> Israel's national <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">Holocaust</a> museum, <a href="/wiki/Yad_Vashem" title="Yad Vashem">Yad Vashem</a>, is the world central archive of Holocaust-related information.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-683"><a href="#cite_note-683">[676]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/ANU_-_Museum_of_the_Jewish_People" title="ANU - Museum of the Jewish People">ANU - Museum of the Jewish People</a> on the campus of <a href="/wiki/Tel_Aviv_University" title="Tel Aviv University">Tel Aviv University</a>, is an interactive museum devoted to the history of Jewish communities around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-684"><a href="#cite_note-684">[677]</a></sup> Apart from the major museums in large cities, there are high-quality art spaces in many towns and <a href="/wiki/Kibbutz" title="Kibbutz">kibbutzim</a>. Mishkan LeOmanut in kibbutz <a href="/wiki/Ein_Harod_(Meuhad)" title="Ein Harod (Meuhad)">Ein Harod Meuhad</a> is the largest art museum in the north of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-685"><a href="#cite_note-685">[678]</a></sup>
</p><p>Israel has the highest number of museums per capita in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-686"><a href="#cite_note-686">[679]</a></sup> Several Israeli museums are devoted to Islamic culture, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Museum" title="Rockefeller Museum">Rockefeller Museum</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L._A._Mayer_Institute_for_Islamic_Art" title="L. A. Mayer Institute for Islamic Art">L. A. Mayer Institute for Islamic Art</a>, both in Jerusalem. The Rockefeller specializes in archaeological remains from the Ottoman and other periods of Middle East history. It is also the home of the first <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hominid" title="Hominid">hominid</a> fossil skull found in Western Asia, called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Galilee_Man" title="Galilee Man">Galilee Man</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-687"><a href="#cite_note-687">[680]</a></sup> A cast of the skull is on display at the Israel Museum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-688"><a href="#cite_note-688">[681]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Israeli_cuisine" title="Israeli cuisine">Israeli cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Food_in_Israel.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1620" data-file-width="2390" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Food_in_Israel.jpg/220px-Food_in_Israel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Food_in_Israel.jpg/330px-Food_in_Israel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Food_in_Israel.jpg/440px-Food_in_Israel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Food_in_Israel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A meal including <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_fries" title="French fries">French fries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israeli_salad" title="Israeli salad">Israeli salad</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Israeli_cuisine" title="Israeli cuisine">Israeli cuisine</a> includes local dishes as well as <a href="/wiki/Jewish_cuisine" title="Jewish cuisine">Jewish cuisine</a> brought to the country by immigrants from the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_diaspora" title="Jewish diaspora">diaspora</a>. Since the establishment of the state in 1948, and particularly since the late 1970s, an Israeli <a href="/wiki/Fusion_cuisine" title="Fusion cuisine">fusion cuisine</a> has developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-raviv_689-0"><a href="#cite_note-raviv-689">[682]</a></sup> Israeli cuisine has adopted, and continues to adapt, elements of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_Mizrahi_Jews" title="Cuisine of the Mizrahi Jews">Mizrahi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_Sephardic_Jews" title="Cuisine of the Sephardic Jews">Sephardi</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_cuisine" title="Ashkenazi cuisine">Ashkenazi</a> styles of cooking. It incorporates many foods traditionally eaten in the <a href="/wiki/Levantine_cuisine" title="Levantine cuisine">Levantine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_cuisine" title="Arab cuisine">Arab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Middle_Eastern_cuisine" title="Middle Eastern cuisine">Middle Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">Mediterranean</a> cuisines, such as <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shakshouka" title="Shakshouka">shakshouka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Couscous" title="Couscous">couscous</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Za%27atar" title="Za'atar">za'atar</a>. <a href="/wiki/Schnitzel" title="Schnitzel">Schnitzel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pizza" title="Pizza">pizza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hamburger" title="Hamburger">hamburgers</a>, <a href="/wiki/French_fries" title="French fries">French fries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Salad" title="Salad">salad</a> are also common in Israel.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Roughly half of the Israeli-Jewish population attests to keeping <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kosher" title="Kosher">kosher</a> at home.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-690"><a href="#cite_note-690">[683]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bernstein_691-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bernstein-691">[684]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kosher_restaurant" title="Kosher restaurant">Kosher restaurants</a>, though rare in the 1960s, make up around a quarter of the total as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, perhaps reflecting the largely secular values of those who dine out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-raviv_689-1"><a href="#cite_note-raviv-689">[682]</a></sup> Hotel restaurants are much more likely to serve kosher food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-raviv_689-2"><a href="#cite_note-raviv-689">[682]</a></sup> The non-kosher retail market was traditionally sparse, but grew rapidly and considerably following <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1990s_Post-Soviet_aliyah" title="1990s Post-Soviet aliyah">the influx of immigrants from the post-Soviet states</a> during the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bernstein_692-0"><a href="#cite_note-bernstein-692">[685]</a></sup> Together with non-kosher fish, rabbits and ostriches, <a href="/wiki/Pork" title="Pork">pork</a>—often called "white meat" in Israel<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bernstein_692-1"><a href="#cite_note-bernstein-692">[685]</a></sup>—is produced and consumed, though <a href="/wiki/Religious_restrictions_on_the_consumption_of_pork" title="Religious restrictions on the consumption of pork">it is forbidden</a> by both Judaism and Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-693"><a href="#cite_note-693">[686]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Israel" title="Sport in Israel">Sport in Israel</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teddy_Stadium,_Jerusalem_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2251" data-file-width="4018" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Teddy_Stadium%2C_Jerusalem_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Teddy_Stadium,_Jerusalem_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Teddy_Stadium" title="Teddy Stadium">Teddy Stadium</a> of Jerusalem</div></div></div>
<p>The most popular spectator sports in Israel are <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-694"><a href="#cite_note-694">[687]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Premier_League" title="Israeli Premier League">Israeli Premier League</a> is the country's premier football league, and the <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Basketball_Premier_League" title="Israeli Basketball Premier League">Israeli Basketball Premier League</a> is the premier basketball league.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-695"><a href="#cite_note-695">[688]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maccabi_Haifa_F.C." title="Maccabi Haifa F.C.">Maccabi Haifa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maccabi_Tel_Aviv_F.C." title="Maccabi Tel Aviv F.C.">Maccabi Tel Aviv</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hapoel_Tel_Aviv_F.C." title="Hapoel Tel Aviv F.C.">Hapoel Tel Aviv</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beitar_Jerusalem_F.C." title="Beitar Jerusalem F.C.">Beitar Jerusalem</a> are the largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_football_clubs_in_Israel" title="List of football clubs in Israel">football clubs</a>. Maccabi Tel Aviv, Maccabi Haifa and Hapoel Tel Aviv have competed in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League" title="UEFA Champions League">UEFA Champions League</a> and Hapoel Tel Aviv reached the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UEFA_Cup" title="UEFA Cup">UEFA Cup</a> quarter-finals. Israel hosted and won the <a href="/wiki/1964_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="1964 AFC Asian Cup">1964 AFC Asian Cup</a>; in 1970 the <a href="/wiki/Israel_national_football_team" title="Israel national football team">Israel national football team</a> qualified for the <a href="/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1970 FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>, the only time it participated in the World Cup. The <a href="/wiki/1974_Asian_Games" title="1974 Asian Games">1974 Asian Games</a>, held in Tehran, were the last Asian Games in which Israel <a href="/wiki/Israel_at_the_Asian_Games" title="Israel at the Asian Games">participated</a>, plagued by the Arab countries that <a href="/wiki/Boycotts_of_Israel_in_sports" title="Boycotts of Israel in sports">refused</a> to compete with Israel. Israel was excluded from the <a href="/wiki/1978_Asian_Games" title="1978 Asian Games">1978 Asian Games</a> and since then has not competed in Asian sport events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-696"><a href="#cite_note-696">[689]</a></sup> In 1994, <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">UEFA</a> agreed to admit Israel, and its football teams now compete in Europe.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2016)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Maccabi_Tel_Aviv_B.C." title="Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.">Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.</a> has won the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_European_Champions_Cup_and_EuroLeague_records_and_statistics" title="FIBA European Champions Cup and EuroLeague records and statistics">European championship</a> in basketball six times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-697"><a href="#cite_note-697">[690]</a></sup> In 2016, the country was chosen as a host for the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2017" title="EuroBasket 2017">EuroBasket 2017</a>.
</p><p>Israel has won <a href="/wiki/Israel_at_the_Olympics" title="Israel at the Olympics">nine Olympic medals</a> since its first win <a href="/wiki/1992_Summer_Olympics" title="1992 Summer Olympics">in 1992</a>, including a gold medal in <a href="/wiki/Sailing_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Mistral_One_Design" title="Sailing at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men's Mistral One Design">windsurfing</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-698"><a href="#cite_note-698">[691]</a></sup> Israel has won <a href="/wiki/Israel_at_the_Paralympics" title="Israel at the Paralympics">over 100</a> gold medals in the <a href="/wiki/Paralympic_Games" title="Paralympic Games">Paralympic Games</a> and is ranked 20th in the <a href="/wiki/All-time_Paralympic_Games_medal_table" title="All-time Paralympic Games medal table">all-time medal count</a>. The <a href="/wiki/1968_Summer_Paralympics" title="1968 Summer Paralympics">1968 Summer Paralympics</a> were hosted by Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-699"><a href="#cite_note-699">[692]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Maccabiah_Games" title="Maccabiah Games">Maccabiah Games</a>, an Olympic-style event for <a href="/wiki/List_of_Jews_in_sports" title="List of Jews in sports">Jewish</a> and Israeli athletes, was inaugurated in the 1930s, and has been held every four years since then. Israeli tennis champion <a href="/wiki/Shahar_Pe%27er" title="Shahar Pe'er">Shahar Pe'er</a> ranked 11th in the world on 31 January 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-700"><a href="#cite_note-700">[693]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Krav_Maga" title="Krav Maga">Krav Maga</a>, a martial art developed by Jewish ghetto defenders during the struggle against <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">fascism</a> in Europe, is used by the Israeli security forces and police. Its effectiveness and practical approach to self-defense, have won it widespread admiration and adherence around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-701"><a href="#cite_note-701">[694]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Chess">Chess</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2722" data-file-width="2943" decoding="async" height="203" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg/220px-BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg/330px-BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg/440px-BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BorisGelfandSicilianDefence.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Boris_Gelfand" title="Boris Gelfand">Boris Gelfand</a>, chess <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">Grandmaster</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is a leading sport in Israel and is enjoyed by people of all ages. There are many Israeli grandmasters and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Israeli_chess_players" title="List of Israeli chess players">Israeli chess players</a> have won a number of youth world championships.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-702"><a href="#cite_note-702">[695]</a></sup> Israel stages an annual international <a href="/wiki/Israeli_Chess_Championship" title="Israeli Chess Championship">championship</a> and hosted the <a href="/wiki/World_Team_Chess_Championship" title="World Team Chess Championship">World Team Chess Championship</a> in 2005. The Ministry of Education and the <a href="/wiki/FIDE" title="FIDE">World Chess Federation</a> agreed upon a project of teaching chess within Israeli schools, and it has been introduced into the curriculum of some schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-703"><a href="#cite_note-703">[696]</a></sup> The city of <a href="/wiki/Beersheba" title="Beersheba">Beersheba</a> has become a national chess center, with the game being taught in the city's kindergartens. Owing partly to Soviet immigration, it is home to the largest number of <a href="/wiki/Grandmaster_(chess)" title="Grandmaster (chess)">chess grandmasters</a> of any city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-704"><a href="#cite_note-704">[697]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-705"><a href="#cite_note-705">[698]</a></sup> The Israeli chess team won the silver medal at the <a href="/wiki/38th_Chess_Olympiad" title="38th Chess Olympiad">2008 Chess Olympiad</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-706"><a href="#cite_note-706">[699]</a></sup> and the bronze, coming in third among 148 teams, at the <a href="/wiki/39th_Chess_Olympiad" title="39th Chess Olympiad">2010 Olympiad</a>. Israeli grandmaster <a href="/wiki/Boris_Gelfand" title="Boris Gelfand">Boris Gelfand</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Chess_World_Cup_2009" title="Chess World Cup 2009">Chess World Cup 2009</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-707"><a href="#cite_note-707">[700]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2012#Candidates_tournament" title="World Chess Championship 2012">2011 Candidates Tournament</a> for the right to challenge the world champion. He lost the <a href="/wiki/World_Chess_Championship_2012" title="World Chess Championship 2012">World Chess Championship 2012</a> to reigning world champion <a href="/wiki/Viswanathan_Anand" title="Viswanathan Anand">Anand</a> after a speed-chess tie breaker.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Recognition by other UN member states: <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">Australia</a> (<a href="/wiki/West_Jerusalem" title="West Jerusalem">West Jerusalem</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ausj_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-ausj-1">[1]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> (<a href="/wiki/West_Jerusalem" title="West Jerusalem">West Jerusalem</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> (<a href="/wiki/West_Jerusalem" title="West Jerusalem">West Jerusalem</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">Honduras</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nauru" title="Nauru">Nauru</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-10">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Jerusalem is Israel's largest city if including <a href="/wiki/East_Jerusalem" title="East Jerusalem">East Jerusalem</a>, which is widely recognized as occupied territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[8]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Arabic had previously been an official language of the State of Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang1_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-lang1-11">[9]</a></sup> In 2018 <a href="/wiki/Basic_Law:_Israel_as_the_Nation-State_of_the_Jewish_People" title="Basic Law: Israel as the Nation-State of the Jewish People">its classification</a> was changed to a 'special status in the state' with its use by state institutions to be set in law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang2_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-lang2-12">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang3_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-lang3-13">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lang4_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-lang4-14">[12]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-oecd-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-oecd_19-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Israeli population and economic data covers the economic territory of Israel, including the Golan Heights, East Jerusalem and Israeli settlements in the West Bank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOECD2011_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOECD2011-436">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[430]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Law" title="Jerusalem Law">Jerusalem Law</a> states that "Jerusalem, complete and united, is the capital of Israel" and the city serves as the seat of the government, home to the President's residence, government offices, supreme court, and <a href="/wiki/Knesset" title="Knesset">parliament</a>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_478" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 478">United Nations Security Council Resolution 478</a> (20 August 1980; 14–0, U.S. abstaining) declared the Jerusalem Law "null and void" and called on member states to withdraw their diplomatic missions from Jerusalem (see <a href="#CITEREFKellerman1993">Kellerman 1993</a>, p. 140). See <a href="/wiki/Status_of_Jerusalem" title="Status of Jerusalem">Status of Jerusalem</a> for more information.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-36">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tens of thousands of Jews in Arab countries left their homes because of the 1948 war as well, pushed by a combination of anti-Semitic feeling and legislation, religious feeling, Zionist activity, economic factors, the end of colonial rule, and other reasons.The decision to leave varied by circumstance, as well as by country and social class. Approximately 260,000 Jews from the Arab world moved to Israel during and immediately after the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischbach200826–27_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischbach200826–27-35">[30]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-249"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-249">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"In hindsight we can say that 1977 was a turning point ..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman2002169–170_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman2002169–170-248">[242]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Citations">Citations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-ausj-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ausj_1-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-australia-46576716" rel="nofollow">"Australia recognises West Jerusalem as Israeli capital"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">BBC News</a></i>. 15 December 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 August</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=BBC+News&amp;rft.atitle=Australia+recognises+West+Jerusalem+as+Israeli+capital&amp;rft.date=2018-12-15&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworld-australia-46576716&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.mid.ru/en/foreign_policy/news/-/asset_publisher/cKNonkJE02Bw/content/id/2717182" rel="nofollow">"Foreign Ministry statement regarding Palestinian-Israeli settlement"</a>. <i>www.mid.ru</i>. 6 April 2017.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.mid.ru&amp;rft.atitle=Foreign+Ministry+statement+regarding+Palestinian-Israeli+settlement&amp;rft.date=2017-04-06&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mid.ru%2Fen%2Fforeign_policy%2Fnews%2F-%2Fasset_publisher%2FcKNonkJE02Bw%2Fcontent%2Fid%2F2717182&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.jpost.com/Breaking-News/Czech-Republic-announces-it-recognizes-West-Jerusalem-as-Israels-capital-517241" rel="nofollow">"Czech Republic announces it recognizes West Jerusalem as Israel's capital"</a>. <i>Jerusalem Post</i>. 6 December 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 December</span> 2017</span>. <q>The Czech Republic currently, before the peace between Israel and Palestine is signed, recognizes Jerusalem to be in fact the capital of Israel in the borders of the demarcation line from 1967." The Ministry also said that it would only consider relocating its embassy based on "results of negotiations.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Jerusalem+Post&amp;rft.atitle=Czech+Republic+announces+it+recognizes+West+Jerusalem+as+Israel%27s+capital&amp;rft.date=2017-12-06&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.jpost.com%2FBreaking-News%2FCzech-Republic-announces-it-recognizes-West-Jerusalem-as-Israels-capital-517241&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.timesofisrael.com/honduras-recognizes-jerusalem-as-israels-capital/" rel="nofollow">"Honduras recognizes Jerusalem as Israel's capital"</a>. <i>The Times of Israel</i>. 29 August 2019.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Times+of+Israel&amp;rft.atitle=Honduras+recognizes+Jerusalem+as+Israel%27s+capital&amp;rft.date=2019-08-29&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.timesofisrael.com%2Fhonduras-recognizes-jerusalem-as-israels-capital%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a class="external text" href="https://www.infobae.com/america/mundo/2017/12/24/guatemala-se-suma-a-eeuu-y-tambien-trasladara-su-embajada-en-israel-a-jerusalen/" rel="nofollow">"Guatemala se suma a EEUU y también trasladará su embajada en Israel a Jerusalén"</a> [Guatemala joins US, will also move embassy to Jerusalem]. <i>Infobae</i> (in Spanish). 24 December 2017.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Infobae&amp;rft.atitle=Guatemala+se+suma+a+EEUU+y+tambi%C3%A9n+trasladar%C3%A1+su+embajada+en+Israel+a+Jerusal%C3%A9n&amp;rft.date=2017-12-24&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.infobae.com%2Famerica%2Fmundo%2F2017%2F12%2F24%2Fguatemala-se-suma-a-eeuu-y-tambien-trasladara-su-embajada-en-israel-a-jerusalen%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span> Guatemala's embassy was located in Jerusalem until the 1980s, when it was moved to Tel Aviv.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-HDI-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-HDI_23-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-HDI_23-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr2020.pdf" rel="nofollow"><i>Human Development Report 2020 The Next Frontier: Human Development and the Anthropocene</i></a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. United Nations Development Programme. 15 December 2020. pp. 343–346. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-92-1-126442-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-92-1-126442-5"><bdi>978-92-1-126442-5</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">16 December</span> 2020</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Human+Development+Report+2020+The+Next+Frontier%3A+Human+Development+and+the+Anthropocene&amp;rft.pages=343-346&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations+Development+Programme&amp;rft.date=2020-12-15&amp;rft.isbn=978-92-1-126442-5&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fhdr.undp.org%2Fsites%2Fdefault%2Ffiles%2Fhdr2020.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Akram, Susan M., Michael Dumper, Michael Lynk, and Iain Scobbie, eds. 2010. <i>International Law and the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict: A Rights-Based Approach to Middle East Peace</i>. Routledge. p. 119: "UN General Assembly Resolution 181 recommended the creation of an international zone, or corpus separatum, in Jerusalem to be administered by the UN for a 10-year period, after which there would be a referendum to determine its future. This approach applies equally to West and East Jerusalem and is not affected by the occupation of East Jerusalem in 1967. To a large extent it is this approach that still guides the diplomatic behaviour of states and thus has greater force in international law."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Canaan-historical-region-Middle-East" rel="nofollow">Encyclopædia Britannica</a> article on Canaan</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Golden-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Golden_27-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Golden_27-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Jonathan M Golden,<a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=EResmS5wOnkC&amp;pg=PA3" rel="nofollow"><i>Ancient Canaan and Israel: An Introduction,</i></a> OUP, 2009 pp. 3–4.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Finkelstein-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Finkelstein_28-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Finkelstein_28-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Finkelstein_28-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFinkelsteinSilberman2001">Finkelstein, Israel; Silberman, Neil Asher (2001). <i>The Bible unearthed : archaeology's new vision of ancient Israel and the origin of its stories</i> (1st Touchstone ed.). New York: Simon &amp; Schuster. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-684-86912-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-684-86912-4"><bdi>978-0-684-86912-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Bible+unearthed+%3A+archaeology%27s+new+vision+of+ancient+Israel+and+the+origin+of+its+stories&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.edition=1st+Touchstone&amp;rft.pub=Simon+%26+Schuster&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-684-86912-4&amp;rft.aulast=Finkelstein&amp;rft.aufirst=Israel&amp;rft.au=Silberman%2C+Neil+Asher&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Pitcher-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Pitcher_29-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Pitcher_29-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=tu02muKUVJ0C&amp;pg=PA229" rel="nofollow">The Pitcher Is Broken: Memorial Essays for Gosta W. Ahlstrom, Steven W. Holloway, Lowell K. Handy, Continuum, 1 May 1995</a> Quote: "For Israel, the description of the battle of Qarqar in the Kurkh Monolith of Shalmaneser III (mid-ninth century) and for Judah, a Tiglath-pileser III text mentioning (Jeho-) Ahaz of Judah (IIR67 = K. 3751), dated 734–733, are the earliest published to date."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-47"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-47">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">William G. Dever, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=IGR7-OSz7bUC&amp;pg=PA186" rel="nofollow"><i>Did God Have a Wife?: Archaeology and Folk Religion in Ancient Israel</i></a>, Wm. </li>

<li id="cite_note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"And he said, Thy name shall be called no more Jacob, but Israel: for as a prince hast thou power with God and with men, and hast prevailed." <li id="cite_note-NollMerneptah-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NollMerneptah_62-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">K.L. Noll, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=hMeRK7B1EsMC&amp;pg=PA139" rel="nofollow"><i>Canaan and Israel in Antiquity: A Textbook on History and Religion,</i></a> A&amp;C Black, 2012, rev.ed. pp. 137ff.</span>

<li id="cite_note-ThompsonMerneptah-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ThompsonMerneptah_63-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Thomas_L._Thompson" title="Thomas L. Thompson">Thomas L. Thompson</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=RwrrUuHFb6UC&amp;pg=PA275" rel="nofollow"><i>Early History of the Israelite People: From the Written &amp; Archaeological Sources,</i></a> Brill, 2000 pp. 275–276: 'They are rather a very specific group among the population of Palestine which bears a name that occurs here for the first time that at a much later stage in Palestine's history bears a substantially different signification.'</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-64"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-64">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Israel_(name)" title="Israel (name)">personal name "Israel"</a> appears much earlier, in material from <a href="/wiki/Ebla" title="Ebla">Ebla</a>. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHasel1994">Hasel, Michael G. (1 January 1994). "Israel in the Merneptah Stela". <i>Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research</i>. <b>296</b> (296): 45–61. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F1357179" rel="nofollow">10.2307/1357179</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/1357179" rel="nofollow">1357179</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:164052192" rel="nofollow">164052192</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Bulletin+of+the+American+Schools+of+Oriental+Research&amp;rft.atitle=Israel+in+the+Merneptah+Stela&amp;rft.volume=296&amp;rft.issue=296&amp;rft.pages=45-61&amp;rft.date=1994-01-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A164052192%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F1357179%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F1357179&amp;rft.aulast=Hasel&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael+G.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span>; <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBertman2005">Bertman, Stephen (14 July 2005). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1C4NKp4zgIQC&amp;q=ebla%20israel%20ishmael%20abraham&amp;pg=PA317" rel="nofollow"><i>Handbook to Life in Ancient Mesopotamia</i></a>. OUP. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-518364-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-518364-1"><bdi>978-0-19-518364-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Handbook+to+Life+in+Ancient+Mesopotamia&amp;rft.pub=OUP&amp;rft.date=2005-07-14&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-518364-1&amp;rft.aulast=Bertman&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1C4NKp4zgIQC%26q%3Debla%2520israel%2520ishmael%2520abraham%26pg%3DPA317&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span> and <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMeindert_Dijkstra2010">Meindert Dijkstra (2010). "Origins of Israel between history and ideology".  In <a href="/wiki/Lester_L._Grabbe" title="Lester L. Grabbe">Becking, Bob</a>; Grabbe, Lester (eds.). <i>Between Evidence and Ideology Essays on the History of Ancient Israel read at the Joint Meeting of the Society for Old Testament Study and the Oud Testamentisch Werkgezelschap Lincoln, July 2009</i>. Brill. p. 47. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-04-18737-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-04-18737-5"><bdi>978-90-04-18737-5</bdi></a>. <q>As a West Semitic personal name it existed long before it became a tribal or a geographical name. This is not without significance, though is it rarely mentioned. We learn of a maryanu named ysr"il (*Yi¡sr—a"ilu) from Ugarit living in the same period, but the name was already used a thousand years before in Ebla. The word Israel originated as a West Semitic personal name. One of the many names that developed into the name of the ancestor of a clan, of a tribe and finally of a people and a nation.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Origins+of+Israel+between+history+and+ideology&amp;rft.btitle=Between+Evidence+and+Ideology+Essays+on+the+History+of+Ancient+Israel+read+at+the+Joint+Meeting+of+the+Society+for+Old+Testament+Study+and+the+Oud+Testamentisch+Werkgezelschap+Lincoln%2C+July+2009&amp;rft.pages=47&amp;rft.pub=Brill&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-04-18737-5&amp;rft.au=Meindert+Dijkstra&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-65"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-65">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLemche1998">Lemche, Niels Peter (1998). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=JIoY7PagAOAC&amp;pg=PAPA35" rel="nofollow"><i>The Israelites in History and Tradition</i></a>. Westminster John Knox Press. p. 35. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-664-22727-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-664-22727-2"><bdi>978-0-664-22727-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Israelites+in+History+and+Tradition&amp;rft.pages=35&amp;rft.pub=Westminster+John+Knox+Press&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-664-22727-2&amp;rft.aulast=Lemche&amp;rft.aufirst=Niels+Peter&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DJIoY7PagAOAC%26pg%3DPAPA35&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Miller1986-66"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Miller1986_66-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMillerHayes1986">Miller, James Maxwell; Hayes, John Haralson (1986). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historyofancient00mill" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of Ancient Israel and Judah</i></a>. Westminster John Knox Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-664-21262-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-664-21262-9"><bdi>978-0-664-21262-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Ancient+Israel+and+Judah&amp;rft.pub=Westminster+John+Knox+Press&amp;rft.date=1986&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-664-21262-9&amp;rft.aulast=Miller&amp;rft.aufirst=James+Maxwell&amp;rft.au=Hayes%2C+John+Haralson&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fhistoryofancient00mill&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-67">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mark Smith in "The Early History of God: Yahweh and Other Deities of Ancient Israel" states "Despite the long regnant model that the Canaanites and Israelites were people of fundamentally different culture, archaeological data now casts doubt on this view. The material culture of the region exhibits numerous common points between Israelites and Canaanites in the Iron I period (c. 1200–1000 BCE). The record would suggest that the Israelite culture largely overlapped with and derived from Canaanite culture... In short, Israelite culture was largely Canaanite in nature. Given the information available, one cannot maintain a radical cultural separation between Canaanites and Israelites for the Iron I period." (pp. 6–7). Smith, Mark (2002) "The Early History of God: Yahweh and Other Deities of Ancient Israel" (Eerdman's)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-68"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-68">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Rendsberg, Gary (2008). "Israel without the Bible". In Frederick E. Greenspahn. The Hebrew Bible: New Insights and Scholarship. NYU Press, pp. 3–5</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-69"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-69">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGnuse1997">Gnuse, Robert Karl (1997). <i>No Other Gods: Emergent Monotheism in Israel</i>. England: Sheffield Academic Press Ltd. pp. 28, 31. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-85075-657-0" title="Special:BookSources/1-85075-657-0"><bdi>1-85075-657-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=No+Other+Gods%3A+Emergent+Monotheism+in+Israel&amp;rft.place=England&amp;rft.pages=28%2C+31&amp;rft.pub=Sheffield+Academic+Press+Ltd&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=1-85075-657-0&amp;rft.aulast=Gnuse&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert+Karl&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEShahin20056-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShahin20056_78-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFShahin2005">Shahin 2005</a>, p. 6.</span>

<li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDever2001">Dever, William (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6-VxwC5rQtwC" rel="nofollow"><i>What Did the Biblical Writers Know, and When Did They Know It?</i></a>. Eerdmans. pp. 98–99. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-927120-37-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-927120-37-2"><bdi>978-3-927120-37-2</bdi></a>. <q>After a century of exhaustive investigation, all respectable archaeologists have given up hope of recovering any context that would make Abraham, Isaac, or Jacob credible "historical figures" [...] archaeological investigation of Moses and the Exodus has similarly been discarded as a fruitless pursuit.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=What+Did+the+Biblical+Writers+Know%2C+and+When+Did+They+Know+It%3F&amp;rft.pages=98-99&amp;rft.pub=Eerdmans&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-927120-37-2&amp;rft.aulast=Dever&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D6-VxwC5rQtwC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id='cite_note-FOOTNOTEFaust2015p.476:_"While_there_is_a_consensus_among_scholars_that_the_Exodus_did_not_take_place_in_the_manner_described_in_the_Bible,_surprisingly_most_scholars_agree_that_the_narrative_has_a_historical_core,_and_that_some_of_the_highland_settlers_came,_one_way_or_another,_from_Egypt.."-80'><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href='#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFaust2015p.476:_"While_there_is_a_consensus_among_scholars_that_the_Exodus_did_not_take_place_in_the_manner_described_in_the_Bible,_surprisingly_most_scholars_agree_that_the_narrative_has_a_historical_core,_and_that_some_of_the_highland_settlers_came,_one_way_or_another,_from_Egypt.."_80-0'>^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFaust2015">Faust 2015</a>, p.476: "While there is a consensus among scholars that the Exodus did not take place in the manner described in the Bible, surprisingly most scholars agree that the narrative has a historical core, and that some of the highland settlers came, one way or another, from Egypt..".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTERedmount200161-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTERedmount200161_81-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFRedmount2001">Redmount 2001</a>, p. 61: "A few authorities have concluded that the core events of the Exodus saga are entirely literary fabrications. But most biblical scholars still subscribe to some variation of the Documentary Hypothesis, and support the basic historicity of the biblical narrative."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:03-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:03_82-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDever2001">Dever, William (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6-VxwC5rQtwC" rel="nofollow"><i>What Did the Biblical Writers Know, and When Did They Know It?</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-lipschits-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-lipschits_83-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLipschits2014">Lipschits, Oded (2014). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=yErYBAAAQBAJ" rel="nofollow">"The History of Israel in the Biblical Period"</a>. <li id="cite_note-Kuhrtp438-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kuhrtp438_84-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKuhrt1995">Kuhrt, Amiele (1995). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/ancientneareastc00akuh/page/438" rel="nofollow"><i>The Ancient Near East</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-Wright-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Wright_85-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFWright2014">Wright, Jacob L. <li id="cite_note-Finkelstein,_Israel,_(2020)-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Finkelstein,_Israel,_(2020)_86-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Finkelstein, Israel, (2020). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com.bo/books?id=wH3-DwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA33&amp;redir_esc=y#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">"Saul and Highlands of Benjamin Update: The Role of Jerusalem"</a>, in Joachim J. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002146–7-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002146–7_87-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFinkelsteinSilberman2002">Finkelstein &amp; Silberman 2002</a>, pp. 146–7:Put simply, while Judah was still economically marginal and backward, Israel was booming. ... In the next chapter we will see how the northern kingdom suddenly appeared on the ancient Near Eastern stage as a major regional power</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:0-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:0_88-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFIsrael.">Israel., Finkelstein. <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/949151323" rel="nofollow"><i>The forgotten kingdom : the archaeology and history of Northern Israel</i></a>. p. 74. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-58983-910-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-58983-910-6"><bdi>978-1-58983-910-6</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/949151323" rel="nofollow">949151323</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+forgotten+kingdom+%3A+the+archaeology+and+history+of+Northern+Israel&amp;rft.pages=74&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F949151323&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-58983-910-6&amp;rft.aulast=Israel.&amp;rft.aufirst=Finkelstein&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F949151323&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-:04-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:04_89-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFinkelstein2013">Finkelstein, Israel (2013). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/880456140" rel="nofollow"><i>The Forgotten Kingdom: the archaeology and history of Northern Israel</i></a>. pp. 65–66, 73, 78, 87–94. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-58983-911-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-58983-911-3"><bdi>978-1-58983-911-3</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/880456140" rel="nofollow">880456140</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Forgotten+Kingdom%3A+the+archaeology+and+history+of+Northern+Israel&amp;rft.pages=65-66%2C+73%2C+78%2C+87-94&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F880456140&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-58983-911-3&amp;rft.aulast=Finkelstein&amp;rft.aufirst=Israel&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F880456140&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFFinkelstein2011">Finkelstein, Israel (1 November 2011). <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1179/033443511x13099584885303" rel="nofollow">"Observations on the Layout of Iron Age Samaria"</a>. <i>Tel Aviv</i>. <b>38</b> (2): 194–207. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1179%2F033443511x13099584885303" rel="nofollow">10.1179/033443511x13099584885303</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0334-4355" rel="nofollow">0334-4355</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:128814117" rel="nofollow">128814117</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Tel+Aviv&amp;rft.atitle=Observations+on+the+Layout+of+Iron+Age+Samaria&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=194-207&amp;rft.date=2011-11-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A128814117%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=0334-4355&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1179%2F033443511x13099584885303&amp;rft.aulast=Finkelstein&amp;rft.aufirst=Israel&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fdoi.org%2F10.1179%2F033443511x13099584885303&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:42-91"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:42_91-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Broshi, M., &amp; Finkelstein, I. (1992). <a class="external text" href="https://www.academia.edu/40790691/M_Broshi_and_I_Finkelstein_The_Population_of_Palestine_in_Iron_Age_II_BASOR_287_1992_pp_47_60" rel="nofollow">"The Population of Palestine in Iron Age II"</a>. <i>Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research</i>, <i>287</i>(1), 47–60.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002307-92"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFinkelsteinSilberman2002307_92-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFinkelsteinSilberman2002">Finkelstein &amp; Silberman 2002</a>, p. 307: "Intensive excavations throughout Jerusalem have shown that the city was indeed systematically destroyed by the Babylonians. The conflagration seems to have been general. When activity on the ridge of the City of David resumed in the Persian period, the-new suburbs on the western hill that had flourished since at least the time of Hezekiah were not reoccupied."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-93"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-93">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLipschits1999">Lipschits, Oded (1999). <a class="external text" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.1179/tav.1999.1999.2.155" rel="nofollow">"The History of the Benjamin Region under Babylonian Rule"</a>. <i>Tel Aviv</i>. <b>26</b> (2): 155–190. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1179%2Ftav.1999.1999.2.155" rel="nofollow">10.1179/tav.1999.1999.2.155</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0334-4355" rel="nofollow">0334-4355</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Tel+Aviv&amp;rft.atitle=The+History+of+the+Benjamin+Region+under+Babylonian+Rule&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=155-190&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1179%2Ftav.1999.1999.2.155&amp;rft.issn=0334-4355&amp;rft.aulast=Lipschits&amp;rft.aufirst=Oded&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdx.doi.org%2F10.1179%2Ftav.1999.1999.2.155&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-97"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-97">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i>Harper's Bible Dictionary</i>, ed. by Achtemeier, etc., Harper &amp; Row, San Francisco, 1985, p. 103</span>
