<li id="cite_note-Grabbe355-98"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Grabbe355_98-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGrabbe2004">Grabbe, Lester L. (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=-MnE5T_0RbMC&amp;pg=PAPA355&amp;dq=%22gave%2Bthe%2BJews%2Bpermission%2Bto%2Breturn%2Bto%2BYehud%2Bprovince%2Band%2Bto%2Brebuild%2Bthe%22" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of the Jews and Judaism in the Second Temple Period: Yehud – A History of the Persian Province of Judah v. 1</i></a>. T &amp; T Clark. p. 355. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-567-08998-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-567-08998-4"><bdi>978-0-567-08998-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+the+Jews+and+Judaism+in+the+Second+Temple+Period%3A+Yehud+%E2%80%93+A+History+of+the+Persian+Province+of+Judah+v.+1&amp;rft.pages=355&amp;rft.pub=T+%26+T+Clark&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-567-08998-4&amp;rft.aulast=Grabbe&amp;rft.aufirst=Lester+L.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D-MnE5T_0RbMC%26pg%3DPAPA355%26dq%3D%2522gave%252Bthe%252BJews%252Bpermission%252Bto%252Breturn%252Bto%252BYehud%252Bprovince%252Band%252Bto%252Brebuild%252Bthe%2522&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-99">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHelyerMcDonald2013">Helyer, Larry R.; McDonald, Lee Martin (2013). "The Hasmoneans and the Hasmonean Era".  In Green, Joel B.; McDonald, Lee Martin (eds.). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/961153992" rel="nofollow"><i>The World of the New Testament: Cultural, Social, and Historical Contexts</i></a>. Baker Academic. pp. 45–47. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8010-9861-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8010-9861-1"><bdi>978-0-8010-9861-1</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/961153992" rel="nofollow">961153992</a>. <q>The ensuing power struggle left Hyrcanus with a free hand in Judea, and he quickly reasserted Jewish sovereignty... Hyrcanus then engaged in a series of military campaigns aimed at territorial expansion. He first conquered areas in the Transjordan. He then turned his attention to Samaria, which had long separated Judea from the northern Jewish settlements in Lower Galilee. In the south, Adora and Marisa were conquered; (Aristobulus') primary accomplishment was annexing and Judaizing the region of Iturea, located between the Lebanon and Anti-Lebanon mountains</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Hasmoneans+and+the+Hasmonean+Era&amp;rft.btitle=The+World+of+the+New+Testament%3A+Cultural%2C+Social%2C+and+Historical+Contexts&amp;rft.pages=45-47&amp;rft.pub=Baker+Academic&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F961153992&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8010-9861-1&amp;rft.aulast=Helyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Larry+R.&amp;rft.au=McDonald%2C+Lee+Martin&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F961153992&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-100">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBen-Sasson1976">Ben-Sasson, H.H. (1976). <i>A History of the Jewish People</i>. Harvard University Press. p. 226. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-674-39731-2" title="Special:BookSources/0-674-39731-2"><bdi>0-674-39731-2</bdi></a>. <q>The expansion of Hasmonean Judea took place gradually. Under Jonathan, Judea annexed southern Samaria and began to expand in the direction of the coast plain... The main ethnic changes were the work of John Hyrcanus... it was in his days and those of his son Aristobulus that the annexation of Idumea, Samaria and Galilee and the consolidation of Jewish settlement in Trans-Jordan was completed. Alexander Jannai, continuing the work of his predecessors, expanded Judean rule to the entire coastal plain, from the Carmel to the Egyptian border... and to additional areas in Trans-Jordan, including some of the Greek cities there.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+the+Jewish+People&amp;rft.pages=226&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1976&amp;rft.isbn=0-674-39731-2&amp;rft.aulast=Ben-Sasson&amp;rft.aufirst=H.H.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-101"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-101">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBen-Eliyahu2019">Ben-Eliyahu, Eyal (30 April 2019). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/1103519319" rel="nofollow"><i>Identity and Territory: Jewish Perceptions of Space in Antiquity</i></a>. p. 13. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-520-29360-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-520-29360-1"><bdi>978-0-520-29360-1</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/1103519319" rel="nofollow">1103519319</a>. <q>From the beginning of the Second Temple period until the Muslim conquest—the land was part of imperial space. This was true from the early Persian period, as well as the time of Ptolemy and the Seleucids. The only exception was the Hasmonean Kingdom, with its sovereign Jewish rule—first over Judah and later, in Alexander Jannaeus's prime, extending to the coast, the north, and the eastern banks of the Jordan.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Identity+and+Territory%3A+Jewish+Perceptions+of+Space+in+Antiquity&amp;rft.pages=13&amp;rft.date=2019-04-30&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F1103519319&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-520-29360-1&amp;rft.aulast=Ben-Eliyahu&amp;rft.aufirst=Eyal&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F1103519319&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:4-102"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:4_102-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWestwood2017">Westwood, Ursula (1 April 2017). <a class="external text" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.18647/3311/jjs-2017" rel="nofollow">"A History of the Jewish War, AD 66–74"</a>. <i>Journal of Jewish Studies</i>. <b>68</b> (1): 189–193. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.18647%2F3311%2Fjjs-2017" rel="nofollow">10.18647/3311/jjs-2017</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0022-2097" rel="nofollow">0022-2097</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Jewish+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=A+History+of+the+Jewish+War%2C+AD+66%E2%80%9374&amp;rft.volume=68&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=189-193&amp;rft.date=2017-04-01&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.18647%2F3311%2Fjjs-2017&amp;rft.issn=0022-2097&amp;rft.aulast=Westwood&amp;rft.aufirst=Ursula&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdx.doi.org%2F10.18647%2F3311%2Fjjs-2017&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:5-103"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:5_103-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKaresh2006">Karesh, Sara E. (2006). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/1162305378" rel="nofollow"><i>Encyclopedia of Judaism</i></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-78785-171-0" title="Special:BookSources/1-78785-171-0"><bdi>1-78785-171-0</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/1162305378" rel="nofollow">1162305378</a>. <q>Until the modern period, the destruction of the Temple was the most cataclysmic moment in the history of the Jewish people. Without the Temple, the Sadducees no longer had any claim to authority, and they faded away. The sage Yochanan ben Zakkai, with permission from Rome, set up the outpost of Yavneh to continue develop of Pharisaic, or rabbinic, Judaism.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+of+Judaism&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F1162305378&amp;rft.isbn=1-78785-171-0&amp;rft.aulast=Karesh&amp;rft.aufirst=Sara+E.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F1162305378&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-104">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFGoldenberg1977">Goldenberg, Robert (1977). <a class="external text" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/jaarel/xlv.3.353" rel="nofollow">"The Broken Axis: Rabbinic Judaism and the Fall of Jerusalem"</a>. <i>Journal of the American Academy of Religion</i>. <b>XLV</b> (3): 353. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1093%2Fjaarel%2Fxlv.3.353" rel="nofollow">10.1093/jaarel/xlv.3.353</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0002-7189" rel="nofollow">0002-7189</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+the+American+Academy+of+Religion&amp;rft.atitle=The+Broken+Axis%3A+Rabbinic+Judaism+and+the+Fall+of+Jerusalem&amp;rft.volume=XLV&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=353&amp;rft.date=1977&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1093%2Fjaarel%2Fxlv.3.353&amp;rft.issn=0002-7189&amp;rft.aulast=Goldenberg&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdx.doi.org%2F10.1093%2Fjaarel%2Fxlv.3.353&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Taylor-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Taylor_105-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTaylor2012">Taylor, J. E. (15 November 2012). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=XWIMFY4VnI4C&amp;pg=PA243" rel="nofollow"><i>The Essenes, the Scrolls, and the Dead Sea</i></a>. Oxford University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780199554485" title="Special:BookSources/9780199554485"><bdi>9780199554485</bdi></a>. <q>These texts, combined with the relics of those who hid in caves along the western side of the Dead Sea, tells us a great deal. What is clear from the evidence of both skeletal remains and artefacts is that the Roman assault on the Jewish population of the Dead Sea was so severe and comprehensive that no one came to retrieve precious legal documents, or bury the dead. Up until this date the Bar Kokhba documents indicate that towns, villages and ports where Jews lived were busy with industry and activity. Afterwards there is an eerie silence, and the archaeological record testifies to little Jewish presence until the Byzantine era, in En Gedi. This picture coheres with what we have already determined in Part I of this study, that the crucial date for what can only be described as genocide, and the devastation of Jews and Judaism within central Judea, was 135 CE and not, as usually assumed, 70 CE, despite the siege of Jerusalem and the Temple's destruction</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Essenes%2C+the+Scrolls%2C+and+the+Dead+Sea&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2012-11-15&amp;rft.isbn=9780199554485&amp;rft.aulast=Taylor&amp;rft.aufirst=J.+E.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DXWIMFY4VnI4C%26pg%3DPA243&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-106">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Werner Eck, "Sklaven und Freigelassene von Römern in Iudaea und den angrenzenden Provinzen," Novum Testamentum 55 (2013): 1–21</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-107"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-107">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRavivBen_David2021">Raviv, Dvir; Ben David, Chaim (2021). <a class="external text" href="https://www.cambridge.org/core/product/identifier/S1047759421000271/type/journal_article" rel="nofollow">"Cassius Dio's figures for the demographic consequences of the Bar Kokhba War: Exaggeration or reliable account?"</a>. <i>Journal of Roman Archaeology</i>. <b>34</b> (2): 585–607. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS1047759421000271" rel="nofollow">10.1017/S1047759421000271</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1047-7594" rel="nofollow">1047-7594</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:245512193" rel="nofollow">245512193</a>. <q>Scholars have long doubted the historical accuracy of Cassius Dio's account of the consequences of the Bar Kokhba War (Roman History 69.14). According to this text, considered the most reliable literary source for the Second Jewish Revolt, the war encompassed all of Judea: the Romans destroyed 985 villages and 50 fortresses, and killed 580,000 rebels. This article reassesses Cassius Dio's figures by drawing on new evidence from excavations and surveys in Judea, Transjordan, and the Galilee. Three research methods are combined: an ethno-archaeological comparison with the settlement picture in the Ottoman Period, comparison with similar settlement studies in the Galilee, and an evaluation of settled sites from the Middle Roman Period (70–136CE). The study demonstrates the potential contribution of the archaeological record to this issue and supports the view of Cassius Dio's demographic data as a reliable account, which he based on contemporaneous documentation.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Roman+Archaeology&amp;rft.atitle=Cassius+Dio%27s+figures+for+the+demographic+consequences+of+the+Bar+Kokhba+War%3A+Exaggeration+or+reliable+account%3F&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=585-607&amp;rft.date=2021&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A245512193%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=1047-7594&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS1047759421000271&amp;rft.aulast=Raviv&amp;rft.aufirst=Dvir&amp;rft.au=Ben+David%2C+Chaim&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cambridge.org%2Fcore%2Fproduct%2Fidentifier%2FS1047759421000271%2Ftype%2Fjournal_article&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-:02-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:02_108-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:02_108-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMor2016">Mor, Menahem (18 April 2016). <a class="external text" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/9789004314634" rel="nofollow"><i>The Second Jewish Revolt</i></a>. BRILL. pp. 483–484. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1163%2F9789004314634" rel="nofollow">10.1163/9789004314634</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-04-31463-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-04-31463-4"><bdi>978-90-04-31463-4</bdi></a>. <q>Land confiscation in Judaea was part of the suppression of the revolt policy of the Romans and punishment for the rebels. But the very claim that the sikarikon laws were annulled for settlement purposes seems to indicate that Jews continued to reside in Judaea even after the Second Revolt. There is no doubt that this area suffered the severest damage from the suppression of the revolt. Settlements in Judaea, such as Herodion and Bethar, had already been destroyed during the course of the revolt, and Jews were expelled from the districts of Gophna, Herodion, and Aqraba. However, it should not be claimed that the region of Judaea was completely destroyed. Jews continued to live in areas such as Lod (Lydda), south of the Hebron Mountain, and the coastal regions. In other areas of the Land of Israel that did not have any direct connection with the Second Revolt, no settlement changes can be identified as resulting from it.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Second+Jewish+Revolt&amp;rft.pages=483-484&amp;rft.pub=BRILL&amp;rft.date=2016-04-18&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1163%2F9789004314634&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-04-31463-4&amp;rft.aulast=Mor&amp;rft.aufirst=Menahem&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdx.doi.org%2F10.1163%2F9789004314634&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-H.H._Ben-Sasson,_1976,_page_334-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-H.H._Ben-Sasson,_1976,_page_334_109-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">H.H. Ben-Sasson, <i>A History of the Jewish People</i>, Harvard University Press, 1976, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-674-39731-2" title="Special:BookSources/0-674-39731-2">0-674-39731-2</a>, page 334: "In an effort to wipe out all memory of the bond between the Jews and the land, Hadrian changed the name of the province from Judaea to Syria-Palestina, a name that became common in non-Jewish literature."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Ariel_Lewin_p._33-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Ariel_Lewin_p._33_110-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ariel Lewin. <i>The archaeology of Ancient Judea and Palestine</i>. Getty Publications, 2005 p. 33. "It seems clear that by choosing a seemingly neutral name – one juxtaposing that of a neighboring province with the revived name of an ancient geographical entity (Palestine), already known from the writings of Herodotus – Hadrian was intending to suppress any connection between the Jewish people and that land." <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-89236-800-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-89236-800-4">0-89236-800-4</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-111">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Oppenheimer, A'haron and Oppenheimer, Nili. <i>Between Rome and Babylon: Studies in Jewish Leadership and Society</i>. Mohr Siebeck, 2005, p. 2.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-112"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-112">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCohn-Sherbok1996">Cohn-Sherbok, Dan (1996). <i>Atlas of Jewish History</i>. Routledge. p. 58. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-08800-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-08800-8"><bdi>978-0-415-08800-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Atlas+of+Jewish+History&amp;rft.pages=58&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-08800-8&amp;rft.aulast=Cohn-Sherbok&amp;rft.aufirst=Dan&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-113">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFLehmann2007">Lehmann, Clayton Miles (18 January 2007). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20130407005423/http://sunburst.usd.edu/~clehmann/erp/Palestine/palestin.htm" rel="nofollow">"Palestine"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia of the Roman Provinces</i>. <li id="cite_note-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-114">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorçöl2006">Morçöl 2006</a>, p. 304</span>

<li id="cite_note-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-115">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Darkening Age: The Christian Destruction of the Classical World by Catherine Nixey 2018</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-116">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Judaism in late antiquity, Jacob Neusner, Bertold Spuler, Hady R Idris, Brill, 2001, p. 155</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Kessler2010-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kessler2010_117-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEdward_Kessler2010">Edward Kessler (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=87Woe7kkPM4C&amp;pg=PA72" rel="nofollow"><i>An Introduction to Jewish-Christian Relations</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p. 72. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-70562-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-70562-2"><bdi>978-0-521-70562-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=An+Introduction+to+Jewish-Christian+Relations&amp;rft.pages=72&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-70562-2&amp;rft.au=Edward+Kessler&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D87Woe7kkPM4C%26pg%3DPA72&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-118">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEhrlich2022">Ehrlich, Michael (2022). <a class="external text" href="http://worldcat.org/oclc/1302180905" rel="nofollow"><i>The Islamization of the Holy Land, 634-1800</i></a>. Leeds, UK: Arc Humanities Press. pp. 3–4. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-64189-222-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-64189-222-3"><bdi>978-1-64189-222-3</bdi></a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/OCLC_(identifier)" title="OCLC (identifier)">OCLC</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/oclc/1302180905" rel="nofollow">1302180905</a>. <q>The Jewish community strove to recover from the catastrophic results of the Bar Kokhva revolt (132–135 CE). Although some of these attempts were relatively successful, the Jews never fully recovered. During the Late Roman and Byzantine periods, many Jews emigrated to thriving centres in the diaspora, especially Iraq, whereas some converted to Christianity and others continued to live in the Holy Land, especially in Galilee and the coastal plain. During the Byzantine period, the three provinces of Palestine included more than thirty cities, namely, settlements with a bishop see. After the Muslim conquest in the 630s, most of these cities declined and eventually disappeared. As a result, in many cases the local ecclesiastical administration weakened, while in others it simply ceased to exist. Consequently, many local Christians converted to Islam. Thus, almost twelve centuries later, when the army led by Napoleon Bonaparte arrived in the Holy Land, most of the local population was Muslim.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Islamization+of+the+Holy+Land%2C+634-1800&amp;rft.place=Leeds%2C+UK&amp;rft.pages=3-4&amp;rft.pub=Arc+Humanities+Press&amp;rft.date=2022&amp;rft_id=info%3Aoclcnum%2F1302180905&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-64189-222-3&amp;rft.aulast=Ehrlich&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fworldcat.org%2Foclc%2F1302180905&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-CHJ2-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-CHJ2_119-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDavid_Goodblatt2006">David Goodblatt (2006). "The Political and Social History of the Jewish Community in the Land of Israel, c. 235–638".  In Steven Katz (ed.). <i>The Cambridge History of Judaism</i>. Vol. IV. pp. 404–430. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-77248-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-77248-8"><bdi>978-0-521-77248-8</bdi></a>. <q>Few would disagree that, in the century and a half before our period begins, the Jewish population of Judah () suffered a serious blow from which it never recovered. The destruction of the Jewish metropolis of Jerusalem and its environs and the eventual refounding of the city... had lasting repercussions. [...] However, in other parts of Palestine the Jewish population remained strong [...] What does seem clear is a different kind of change. Immigration of Christians and the conversion of pagans, Samaritans and Jews eventually produced a Christian majority</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Political+and+Social+History+of+the+Jewish+Community+in+the+Land+of+Israel%2C+c.+235%E2%80%93638&amp;rft.btitle=The+Cambridge+History+of+Judaism&amp;rft.pages=404-430&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-77248-8&amp;rft.au=David+Goodblatt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-120"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-120">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBar2003">Bar, Doron (2003). <a class="external text" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/s0022046903007309" rel="nofollow">"The Christianisation of Rural Palestine during Late Antiquity"</a>. <i>The Journal of Ecclesiastical History</i>. <b>54</b> (3): 401–421. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2Fs0022046903007309" rel="nofollow">10.1017/s0022046903007309</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0022-0469" rel="nofollow">0022-0469</a>. <q>The dominant view of the history of Palestine during the Byzantine period links the early phases of the consecration of the land during the fourth century and the substantial external financial investment that accompanied the building of churches on holy sites on the one hand with the Christianisation of the population on the other. Churches were erected primarily at the holy sites, 12 while at the same time Palestine's position and unique status as the Christian 'Holy Land' became more firmly rooted. All this, coupled with immigration and conversion, allegedly meant that the Christianisation of Palestine took place much more rapidly than that of other areas of the Roman empire, brought in its wake the annihilation of the pagan cults and meant that by the middle of the fifth century there was a clear Christian majority.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Journal+of+Ecclesiastical+History&amp;rft.atitle=The+Christianisation+of+Rural+Palestine+during+Late+Antiquity&amp;rft.volume=54&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=401-421&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2Fs0022046903007309&amp;rft.issn=0022-0469&amp;rft.aulast=Bar&amp;rft.aufirst=Doron&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fdx.doi.org%2F10.1017%2Fs0022046903007309&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-121">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKohen2007">Kohen, Elli (2007). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=r-9qJRP20MIC&amp;pg=PA26" rel="nofollow"><i>History of the Byzantine Jews: A Microcosmos in the Thousand Year Empire</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/University_Press_of_America" title="University Press of America">University Press of America</a>. pp. 26–31. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7618-3623-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7618-3623-0"><bdi>978-0-7618-3623-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=History+of+the+Byzantine+Jews%3A+A+Microcosmos+in+the+Thousand+Year+Empire&amp;rft.pages=26-31&amp;rft.pub=University+Press+of+America&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7618-3623-0&amp;rft.aulast=Kohen&amp;rft.aufirst=Elli&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dr-9qJRP20MIC%26pg%3DPA26&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-122"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-122">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Palestine/Roman-Palestine" rel="nofollow">"Roman Palestine"</a>. <i>www.britannica.com</i>. Encyclopedia Britannica.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.britannica.com&amp;rft.atitle=Roman+Palestine&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.britannica.com%2Fplace%2FPalestine%2FRoman-Palestine&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-MosheGil-123"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-MosheGil_123-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGil1997">Gil, Moshe (1997). <i>A History of Palestine, 634–1099</i>. Cambridge University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-59984-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-59984-9"><bdi>978-0-521-59984-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Palestine%2C+634%E2%80%931099&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-59984-9&amp;rft.aulast=Gil&amp;rft.aufirst=Moshe&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Cooper2009-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cooper2009_124-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAllan_D._Cooper2009">Allan D. Cooper (2009). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Uyh8kdcuA1kC&amp;pg=PAPA132" rel="nofollow"><i>The geography of genocide</i></a>. University Press of America. p. 132. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7618-4097-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7618-4097-8"><bdi>978-0-7618-4097-8</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 January</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+geography+of+genocide&amp;rft.pages=132&amp;rft.pub=University+Press+of+America&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7618-4097-8&amp;rft.au=Allan+D.+Cooper&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DUyh8kdcuA1kC%26pg%3DPAPA132&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-125"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-125">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Carmel, Alex. <i>The History of Haifa Under Turkish Rule</i>. Haifa: Pardes, 2002 (<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/965-7171-05-9" title="Special:BookSources/965-7171-05-9">965-7171-05-9</a>), pp. 16–17</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-634to1099-126"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-634to1099_126-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMoshe_Gil1992">Moshe Gil (1992). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=tSM4AAAAIAAJ&amp;q=1100+%22haifa%22+fatimid+jews&amp;pg=PA829" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of Palestine, 634–1099</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p. 829. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-40437-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-40437-2"><bdi>978-0-521-40437-2</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 May</span> 2015</span>. <q>Haifa was taken [...] in August 1100 or June 1101, according to Muslim sources which contradict one another. Albert of Aachen does not mention the date in a clear manner either. From what he says, it appears that it was mainly the Jewish inhabitants of the city who defended the fortress of Haifa. In his rather strange Latin style, he mentions that there was a Jewish population in Haifa, and that they fought bravely within the walls of the city. He explains that the Jews there were protected people of the Muslims (the Fatimids). They fought side by side with units of the Fatimid army, striking back at Tancred's army from above the walls of the citadel (... <i>Judaei civis comixtis Sarracenorum turmis</i>) until the Crusaders overcame them and they were forced to abandon the walls. The Muslims and the Jews then managed to escape from the fortress with their lives, while the rest of the population fled the city <i>en masse</i>. Whoever remained was slaughtered, and huge quantities of spoils were taken. [...] [Note #3: Albert of Aachen (Albericus, Albertus Aquensis), <i>Historia Hierosolymitanae Expeditionis</i>, in: <a href="/wiki/Recueil_des_historiens_des_croisades" title="Recueil des historiens des croisades"><i>RHC</i></a> (Occ.), IV. p. 523; etc.]</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Palestine%2C+634%E2%80%931099&amp;rft.pages=829&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-40437-2&amp;rft.au=Moshe+Gil&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DtSM4AAAAIAAJ%26q%3D1100%2B%2522haifa%2522%2Bfatimid%2Bjews%26pg%3DPA829&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Resnick2012-127"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Resnick2012_127-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFIrven_M._Resnick2012">Irven M. Resnick (2012). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=LarC4PG9osUC&amp;pg=PAPA49" rel="nofollow"><i>Marks of Distinctions: Christian Perceptions of Jews in the High Middle Ages</i></a>. CUA Press. pp. 48–49. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-1969-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-1969-1"><bdi>978-0-8132-1969-1</bdi></a>. <q>citizens of the Jewish race, who lived in the city by the favour and consent of the king of Egypt in return for payment of tribute, got on the walls bearing arms and put up a very stubborn defence, until the Christians, weighed down by various blows over the period of two weeks, absolutely despaired and held back their hands from any attack. [...] the Jewish citizens, mixed with Saracen troops, at once fought back manfully,... and counter-attacked. [Albert of Aachen, <i>Historia Ierosolimitana</i> 7.23, ed. and transl. Susan B. Edgington (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2007), 516 and 521.]</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Marks+of+Distinctions%3A+Christian+Perceptions+of+Jews+in+the+High+Middle+Ages&amp;rft.pages=48-49&amp;rft.pub=CUA+Press&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8132-1969-1&amp;rft.au=Irven+M.+Resnick&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DLarC4PG9osUC%26pg%3DPAPA49&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/place/Palestine#ref45065" rel="nofollow">"Palestine – Ottoman rule"</a>. <i>www.britannica.com</i>. <li id="cite_note-142"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-142">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/leagcov.asp#art22" rel="nofollow">"The Covenant of the League of Nations"</a>. <i>Article 22</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-164"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-164">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHughes2009">Hughes, M (2009). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160221163210/http://v-scheiner.brunel.ac.uk/bitstream/2438/7251/4/The%20banality%20of%20brutality.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The banality of brutality: British armed forces and the repression of the Arab Revolt in Palestine, 1936–39"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>English Historical Review</i>. <b>CXXIV</b> (507): 314–354. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1093%2Fehr%2Fcep002" rel="nofollow">10.1093/ehr/cep002</a>. <li id="cite_note-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-176">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120806072438/http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/F5A49E57095C35B685256BCF0075D9C2" rel="nofollow">"A/RES/106 (S-1)"</a>. <i>General Assembly resolution</i>. <li id="cite_note-177"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-177">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120610173759/http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/07175DE9FA2DE563852568D3006E10F3" rel="nofollow">"A/364"</a>. <i>Special Committee on Palestine</i>. <li id="cite_note-178"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-178">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20110103014616/http://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/2248AF9A92B498718525694B007239C6" rel="nofollow">"Background Paper No. 47 (ST/DPI/SER.A/47)"</a>. United Nations. 20 April 1949. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 July</span> 2007</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Background+Paper+No.+47+%28ST%2FDPI%2FSER.A%2F47%29&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations&amp;rft.date=1949-04-20&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Funispal.un.org%2FUNISPAL.NSF%2F0%2F2248AF9A92B498718525694B007239C6&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-179"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-179">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Hoffman, Bruce: <i>Anonymous Soldiers</i> (2015)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-180"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-180">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Nathan_Thrall" title="Nathan Thrall">Nathan Thrall</a>, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1oXZDAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA227" rel="nofollow"><i>The Only Language They Understand: Forcing Compromise in Israel and Palestine</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Holt_and_Company" title="Henry Holt and Company">Henry Holt and Company</a> 2017 <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-627-79710-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-627-79710-8">978-1-627-79710-8</a> pp. 41,227 n.9.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris200875-181"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris200875_181-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>, p. 75: "The night of 29–30 November passed in the Yishuv's settlements in noisy public rejoicing. Most had sat glued to their radio sets broadcasting live from Flushing Meadow. A collective cry of joy went up when the two-thirds mark was achieved: a state had been sanctioned by the international community."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008396-182"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008396_182-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008396_182-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>, p. 396: "The immediate trigger of the 1948 War was the November 1947 UN partition resolution. The Zionist movement, except for its fringes, accepted the proposal.", "The Arab war aim, in both stages of the hostilities, was, at a minimum, to abort the emergence of a Jewish state or to destroy it at inception. The Arab states hoped to accomplish this by conquering all or large parts of the territory allotted to the Jews by the United Nations. And some Arab leaders spoke of driving the Jews into the sea and ridding Palestine "of the Zionist plague." The struggle, as the Arabs saw it, was about the fate of Palestine/ the Land of Israel, all of it, not over this or that part of the country. But, in public, official Arab spokesmen often said that the aim of the May 1948 invasion was to "save" Palestine or "save the Palestinians," definitions more agreeable to Western ears."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris200866-183"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris200866_183-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>, p. 66: at 1946 "The League demanded independence for Palestine as a "unitary" state, with an Arab majority and minority rights for the Jews.", p. 67: at 1947 "The League's Political Committee met in Sofar, Lebanon, on 16–19 September, and urged the Palestine Arabs to fight partition, which it called "aggression," "without mercy." The League promised them, in line with Bludan, assistance "in manpower, money and equipment" should the United Nations endorse partition.", p. 72: at December 1947 "The League vowed, in very general language, "to try to stymie the partition plan and prevent the establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine.""</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEBregman200240–41-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBregman200240–41_184-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBregman2002">Bregman 2002</a>, pp. 40–41.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-185"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-185">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGelber2006">Gelber, Yoav (2006). <i>Palestine 1948</i>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris200877–78-186"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris200877–78_186-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>, p. 77–78.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-187"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-187">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTal2003">Tal, David (2003). <i>War in Palestine, 1948: Israeli and Arab Strategy and Diplomacy</i>. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008-188"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008_188-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Declaration-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Declaration_189-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170317223538/http://www.mfa.gov.il/mfa/foreignpolicy/peace/guide/pages/declaration%20of%20establishment%20of%20state%20of%20israel.aspx" rel="nofollow">"Declaration of Establishment of State of Israel"</a>. Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 14 May 1948. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.mfa.gov.il/mfa/foreignpolicy/peace/guide/pages/declaration%20of%20establishment%20of%20state%20of%20israel.aspx" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 17 March 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 March</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Declaration+of+Establishment+of+State+of+Israel&amp;rft.pub=Israel+Ministry+of+Foreign+Affairs&amp;rft.date=1948-05-14&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mfa.gov.il%2Fmfa%2Fforeignpolicy%2Fpeace%2Fguide%2Fpages%2Fdeclaration%2520of%2520establishment%2520of%2520state%2520of%2520israel.aspx&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-190"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-190">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Clifford, Clark, "Counsel to the President: A Memoir", 1991, p. 20.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-191"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-191">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFJacobs2012">Jacobs, Frank (7 August 2012). <a class="external text" href="http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/07/the-elephant-in-the-map-room/" rel="nofollow">"The Elephant in the Map Room"</a>. <i>Borderlines</i>. The New York Times<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 September</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Borderlines&amp;rft.atitle=The+Elephant+in+the+Map+Room&amp;rft.date=2012-08-07&amp;rft.aulast=Jacobs&amp;rft.aufirst=Frank&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fopinionator.blogs.nytimes.com%2F2012%2F08%2F07%2Fthe-elephant-in-the-map-room%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-192"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-192">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">'The entry into (the) war of the Arab countries poses a complex legal problem. The crossing of the borders can constitute an act of aggression or a threat against peace, justifying a condamnation and an intervention by the United Nations, but if the armies penetrate only the Arab part of the partition plan, they can be considered as called on (to do so) by the population and at this stage their <b>intervention</b> would not in itself be a threat against the peace. That would only start were the Jewish part attacked. Now, the Arab armies do directly threaten Jewish territory at certain points while in others the Jews have already largely taken up positions in Arab territory. ('L'entrée en guerre des pays arabes pose un problem juridique complexe. Le franchissement des frontières peut constituer un acte d'aggression ou une menace contre la paix, justifiant une condannation et une intervention des Nations unies, mais si les armées pénètrent seulement dans la partie arabe du plan de partage, elles peuvent être considérées comme appelées par la population et à ce stade leur intervention ne serait pas par elle-même une menace contre la paix. Elle ne commencerait qu'avec l'attaque de la partie juive. Or, en certains points, les armées arabes menacent directement le territoire juif et dans d'autres les Juifs se sont déjà largement installés en territoire arabe.' <a href="/wiki/Henry_Laurens_(scholar)" title="Henry Laurens (scholar)">Henry Laurens</a>, <i>La Question de Palestine,</i> <a href="/wiki/Fayard" title="Fayard">Fayard</a> Paris 2007 vol.3 p.104</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-193"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-193">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKarsh2002">Karsh, Efraim (2002). <i>The Arab–Israeli conflict: The Palestine War 1948</i>. Osprey Publishing. p. 50. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84176-372-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-84176-372-9"><bdi>978-1-84176-372-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Arab%E2%80%93Israeli+conflict%3A+The+Palestine+War+1948&amp;rft.pages=50&amp;rft.pub=Osprey+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-84176-372-9&amp;rft.aulast=Karsh&amp;rft.aufirst=Efraim&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-194"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-194">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBen-Sasson1985">Ben-Sasson 1985</a>, p. 1058</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008205-195"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008205_195-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>, p. 205.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-196"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-196">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFRabinovichReinharz,_Jehuda2007">Rabinovich, Itamar; Reinharz, Jehuda (2007). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/isbn_9780874519624/page/74" rel="nofollow"><i>Israel in the Middle East: Documents and Readings on Society, Politics, and Foreign Relations, Pre-1948 to the Present</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-197"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-197">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDavid_Tal2004">David Tal (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Vs2PAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PAPR4" rel="nofollow"><i>War in Palestine, 1948: Israeli and Arab Strategy and Diplomacy</i></a>. Routledge. p. 469. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-135-77513-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-135-77513-1"><bdi>978-1-135-77513-1</bdi></a>. <q>some of the Arab armies invaded Palestine in order to prevent the establishment of a Jewish state, Transjordan...</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=War+in+Palestine%2C+1948%3A+Israeli+and+Arab+Strategy+and+Diplomacy&amp;rft.pages=469&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-135-77513-1&amp;rft.au=David+Tal&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DVs2PAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPAPR4&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008187-198"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008187_198-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>, p. 187: "A week before the armies marched, Azzam told Kirkbride: "It does not matter how many [ Jews] there are. We will sweep them into the sea." ... Ahmed Shukeiry, one of Haj Amin al-Husseini's aides (and, later, the founding chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization), simply described the aim as "the elimination of the Jewish state." ... al-Quwwatli told his people: "Our army has entered ... we shall win and we shall eradicate Zionism""</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris2008198-199"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris2008198_199-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMorris2008">Morris 2008</a>, p. 198: "the Jews felt that the Arabs aimed to reenact the Holocaust and that they faced certain personal and collective slaughter should they lose"</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-204"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-204">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070912101430/http://domino.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/1ce874ab1832a53e852570bb006dfaf6/0b3ab8d2a7c0273d8525694b00726d1b" rel="nofollow">"Two Hundred and Seventh Plenary Meeting"</a>. <li id="cite_note-205"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-205">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFWilliam_Roger_Louis1984">William Roger Louis (1984). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ATQQ0FMS1FQC&amp;pg=PAPA579" rel="nofollow"><i>The British Empire in the Middle East, 1945–1951: Arab Nationalism, the United States, and Postwar Imperialism</i></a>. Clarendon Press. p. 579. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-822960-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-822960-5"><bdi>978-0-19-822960-5</bdi></a>. <q>"The transcript makes it clear that British policy acted as a brake on Jordan. "King Abdullah was personally anxious to come to agreement with Israel", Kirkbride stated, "and in fact it was our restraining influence which had so far prevented him from doing so". Knox Helm confirmed that the Israelis hoped to have a settlement with Jordan, and that they now genuinely wished to live peacefully within their frontiers, if only for economic reasons".</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+British+Empire+in+the+Middle+East%2C+1945%E2%80%931951%3A+Arab+Nationalism%2C+the+United+States%2C+and+Postwar+Imperialism&amp;rft.pages=579&amp;rft.pub=Clarendon+Press&amp;rft.date=1984&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-822960-5&amp;rft.au=William+Roger+Louis&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DATQQ0FMS1FQC%26pg%3DPAPA579&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-213">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBard2003">Bard, Mitchell (2003). <i>The Founding of the State of Israel</i>. Greenhaven Press. p. 15.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Founding+of+the+State+of+Israel&amp;rft.pages=15&amp;rft.pub=Greenhaven+Press&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.aulast=Bard&amp;rft.aufirst=Mitchell&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-214"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-214">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHakohen2003">Hakohen, Devorah (2003). <i>Immigrants in Turmoil: Mass Immigration to Israel and Its Repercussions in the 1950s and After</i>. Syracuse University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8156-2969-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8156-2969-6"><bdi>978-0-8156-2969-6</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Immigrants+in+Turmoil%3A+Mass+Immigration+to+Israel+and+Its+Repercussions+in+the+1950s+and+After&amp;rft.pub=Syracuse+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8156-2969-6&amp;rft.aulast=Hakohen&amp;rft.aufirst=Devorah&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span>; for ma'abarot population, see p. 269.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-215"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-215">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Clive Jones, Emma Murphy, <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=A144y7qwRJMC&amp;pg=PA37" rel="nofollow"><i>Israel: Challenges to Identity, Democracy, and the State,</i></a> <a href="/wiki/Routledge" title="Routledge">Routledge</a> 2002 p. 37: "Housing units earmarked for the Oriental Jews were often reallocated to European Jewish immigrants; Consigning Oriental Jews to the privations of <i>ma'aborot</i> (transit camps) for longer periods."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-216"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-216">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFSegev2007">Segev 2007</a>, pp. 155–157</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-217"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-217">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFShindler2002">Shindler 2002</a>, pp. 49–50</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-218"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-218">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKameel_B._Nasr1996">Kameel B. Nasr (1996). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=QRXURzwdXS4C&amp;pg=PAPA40" rel="nofollow"><i>Arab and Israeli Terrorism: The Causes and Effects of Political Violence, 1936–1993</i></a>. McFarland. pp. 40–. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7864-3105-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7864-3105-2"><bdi>978-0-7864-3105-2</bdi></a>. <q>Fedayeen to attack...almost always against civilians</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Arab+and+Israeli+Terrorism%3A+The+Causes+and+Effects+of+Political+Violence%2C+1936%E2%80%931993&amp;rft.pages=40-&amp;rft.pub=McFarland&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7864-3105-2&amp;rft.au=Kameel+B.+Nasr&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DQRXURzwdXS4C%26pg%3DPAPA40&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-219"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-219">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGilbert2005">Gilbert 2005</a>, p. 58</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-220"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-220">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFIsaac_Alteras1993">Isaac Alteras (1993). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ydRHCPWngioC&amp;pg=PAPA192" rel="nofollow"><i>Eisenhower and Israel: U.S.-Israeli Relations, 1953–1960</i></a>. University Press of Florida. pp. 192–. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8130-1205-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8130-1205-6"><bdi>978-0-8130-1205-6</bdi></a>. <q>the removal of the Egyptian blockade of the Straits of Tiran at the entrance of the Gulf of Aqaba. The blockade closed Israel's sea lane to East Africa and the Far East, hindering the development of Israel's southern port of Eilat and its hinterland, the Nege. Another important objective of the Israeli war plan was the elimination of the terrorist bases in the Gaza Strip, from which daily fedayeen incursions into Israel made life unbearable for its southern population. And last but not least, the concentration of the Egyptian forces in the Sinai Peninsula, armed with the newly acquired weapons from the Soviet bloc, prepared for an attack on Israel. Here, Ben-Gurion believed, was a time bomb that had to be defused before it was too late. Reaching the Suez Canal did not figure at all in Israel's war objectives. </q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Eisenhower+and+Israel%3A+U.S.-Israeli+Relations%2C+1953%E2%80%931960&amp;rft.pages=192-&amp;rft.pub=University+Press+of+Florida&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8130-1205-6&amp;rft.au=Isaac+Alteras&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DydRHCPWngioC%26pg%3DPAPA192&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-221"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-221">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDominic_Joseph_Caraccilo2011">Dominic Joseph Caraccilo (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=FDA8dQyaQ9MC&amp;pg=PAPA113" rel="nofollow"><i>Beyond Guns and Steel: A War Termination Strategy</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. pp. 113–. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-39149-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-39149-1"><bdi>978-0-313-39149-1</bdi></a>. <q>The escalation continued with the Egyptian blockade of the Straits of Tiran, and Nasser's nationalization of the Suez Canal in July 1956. On October 14, Nasser made clear his intent:"I am not solely fighting against Israel itself. My task is to deliver the Arab world from destruction through Israel's intrigue, which has its roots abroad. Our hatred is very strong. There is no sense in talking about peace with Israel. There is not even the smallest place for negotiations." Less than two weeks later, on October 25, Egypt signed a tripartite agreement with Syria and Jordan placing Nasser in command of all three armies. The continued blockade of the Suez Canal and Gulf of Aqaba to Israeli shipping, combined with the increased fedayeen attacks and the bellicosity of recent Arab statements, prompted Israel, with the backing of Britain and France, to attack Egypt on October 29, 1956.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Beyond+Guns+and+Steel%3A+A+War+Termination+Strategy&amp;rft.pages=113-&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-39149-1&amp;rft.au=Dominic+Joseph+Caraccilo&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DFDA8dQyaQ9MC%26pg%3DPAPA113&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-222"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-222">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAlan_Dowty2005">Alan Dowty (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=9iFxq6NPPgEC&amp;pg=PAPA102" rel="nofollow"><i>Israel/Palestine</i></a>. Polity. pp. 102–. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7456-3202-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7456-3202-5"><bdi>978-0-7456-3202-5</bdi></a>. <q>Gamal Abdel Nasser, who declared in one speech that "Egypt has decided to dispatch her heroes, the disciples of Pharaoh and the sons of Islam and they will cleanse the land of Palestine....There will be no peace on Israel's border because we demand vengeance, and vengeance is Israel's death."...The level of violence against Israelis, soldiers and civilians alike, seemed to be rising inexorably.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Israel%2FPalestine&amp;rft.pages=102-&amp;rft.pub=Polity&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7456-3202-5&amp;rft.au=Alan+Dowty&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D9iFxq6NPPgEC%26pg%3DPAPA102&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-223"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-223">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/5195582.stm" rel="nofollow">"Suez Crisis: Key players"</a>. 21 July 2006<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">19 July</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Suez+Crisis%3A+Key+players&amp;rft.date=2006-07-21&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.bbc.co.uk%2F1%2Fhi%2F5195582.stm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-224"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-224">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFSchoenherr2005">Schoenherr, Steven (15 December 2005). <a class="external text" href="http://sunnycv.com/steve/20th/suez.html" rel="nofollow">"The Suez Crisis"</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-225"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-225">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGorstJohnman,_Lewis1997">Gorst, Anthony; Johnman, Lewis (1997). <i>The Suez Crisis</i>. Routledge. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-11449-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-11449-3"><bdi>978-0-415-11449-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Suez+Crisis&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-11449-3&amp;rft.aulast=Gorst&amp;rft.aufirst=Anthony&amp;rft.au=Johnman%2C+Lewis&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-226"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-226">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBenny_Morris2011">Benny Morris (25 May 2011). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=jGtVsBne7PgC" rel="nofollow"><i>Righteous Victims: A History of the Zionist-Arab Conflict, 1881–1998</i></a>. Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group. pp. 300, 301. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-307-78805-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-307-78805-4"><bdi>978-0-307-78805-4</bdi></a>. <q>[p. 300] In exchange (for Israeli withdrawal) the United states had indirectly promised to guarantee Israel's right of passage through the straits (to the Red sea) and its right to self defense if the Egyptian closed them....(p 301) The 1956 war resulted in a significant reduction of...Israeli border tension. Egypt refrained from reactivating the Fedaeen, and...Egypt and Jordan made great effort to curb infiltration</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Righteous+Victims%3A+A+History+of+the+Zionist-Arab+Conflict%2C+1881%E2%80%931998&amp;rft.pages=300%2C+301&amp;rft.pub=Knopf+Doubleday+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2011-05-25&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-307-78805-4&amp;rft.au=Benny+Morris&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DjGtVsBne7PgC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEBascomb2009219–229-227"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBascomb2009219–229_227-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBascomb2009">Bascomb 2009</a>, p. 219–229.</span>

<li id="cite_note-229"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-229">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFShlomo_Shpiro2006">Shlomo Shpiro (2006). <li id="cite_note-Haaretz2019-230"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Haaretz2019_230-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFCohen2019">Cohen, Avner (3 May 2019). <a class="external text" href="https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium.MAGAZINE-how-a-standoff-with-the-u-s-almost-blew-up-israel-s-nuclear-program-1.7193419" rel="nofollow">"How a Standoff with the U.S. Almost Blew up Israel's Nuclear Program"</a>. <i>Haaretz</i>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Haaretz&amp;rft.atitle=How+a+Standoff+with+the+U.S.+Almost+Blew+up+Israel%27s+Nuclear+Program&amp;rft.date=2019-05-03&amp;rft.aulast=Cohen&amp;rft.aufirst=Avner&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.haaretz.com%2Fisrael-news%2F.premium.MAGAZINE-how-a-standoff-with-the-u-s-almost-blew-up-israel-s-nuclear-program-1.7193419&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-231"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-231">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://nsarchive.gwu.edu/briefing-book/nuclear-vault/2019-05-02/battle-letters-1963-john-f-kennedy-david-ben-gurion-levi-eshkol-us-inspections-dimona" rel="nofollow">"The Battle of the Letters, 1963: John F. <li id="cite_note-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-232">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The Politics of Miscalculation in the Middle East", by Richard B. Parker (1993 Indiana University Press) p. 38</span>

<li id="cite_note-233"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-233">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMaoz1995">Maoz, Moshe (1995). <i>Syria and Israel: From War to Peacemaking</i>. Oxford University Press. p. 70. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-828018-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-828018-7"><bdi>978-0-19-828018-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Syria+and+Israel%3A+From+War+to+Peacemaking&amp;rft.pages=70&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1995&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-828018-7&amp;rft.aulast=Maoz&amp;rft.aufirst=Moshe&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-234"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-234">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/june/5/newsid_2654000/2654251.stm" rel="nofollow">"On This Day 5 Jun"</a>. BBC. 5 June 1967<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-236"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-236">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGat2003">Gat, Moshe (2003). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ntLdA8QIgXIC&amp;q=On+the+night+of+May+22-23,+Nasser+declared+the+Gulf+of+Aqaba+closed+to+Israeli+shipping&amp;pg=PA202" rel="nofollow"><i>Britain and the Conflict in the Middle East, 1964–1967: The Coming of the Six-Day War</i></a>. Greenwood Publishing Group. p. 202. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-275-97514-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-275-97514-2"><bdi>978-0-275-97514-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Britain+and+the+Conflict+in+the+Middle+East%2C+1964%E2%80%931967%3A+The+Coming+of+the+Six-Day+War&amp;rft.pages=202&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-275-97514-2&amp;rft.aulast=Gat&amp;rft.aufirst=Moshe&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DntLdA8QIgXIC%26q%3DOn%2Bthe%2Bnight%2Bof%2BMay%2B22-23%2C%2BNasser%2Bdeclared%2Bthe%2BGulf%2Bof%2BAqaba%2Bclosed%2Bto%2BIsraeli%2Bshipping%26pg%3DPA202&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIsrael"></span></span>
